cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Arrests
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 001. Arrests
cards.front: Arrests
cards.backPlain: An arrest occurs when police take an individual into custody for purposes of criminal prosecution or interrogation. 1. Probable cause is always required for any valid arrest. 1.1 Probable cause means trustworthy facts or knowledge sufficient for a reasonable person to believe that the suspect has committed or is planning to commit a crime. 2. Warrants are rarely required for arrests. 2.1 Police generally do not need a warrant before arresting a person in a public place. 2.2 Exception: Non-emergency home arrests require a warrant and reasonable belief that the suspect is at home; police must have an arrest warrant to arrest an individual in their home. 2.3 Police may only enter the home if they have reason to believe the suspect is in the home. 3. A search warrant is required for police to execute an arrest of a suspect in a third party's home. 3.1 A search warrant is not required for an emergency arrest occurring in the arrestee's own home.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an arrest, and when are an arrest warrant and a search warrant required for arrests in homes and public places?

A {{c14::search warrant}} is required for police to execute an arrest of a suspect in a {{c15::third party's home}}. 3.1 A search warrant is not required for an {{c16::emergency (exigent circumstances) arrest}} occurring in the arrestee's own home.
cards.easyContent: An arrest is taking a person into custody for prosecution or interrogation and always requires probable cause; a warrant is usually not needed in public, but non-emergency home arrests require an arrest warrant and arrests in a third party's home generally require a search warrant.
cards.mediumContent: An arrest occurs when police take an individual into custody for criminal prosecution or interrogation, and probable cause is always required. Police generally do not need a warrant to arrest in public, but a non-emergency arrest inside the suspect's home requires an arrest warrant and reason to believe the suspect is inside. To arrest a suspect inside a third party's home, police generally must obtain a search warrant. A search warrant is not needed for an emergency arrest in the arrestee's own home.
cards.hardContent: An arrest occurs when police take an individual into custody for purposes of criminal prosecution or interrogation. Probable cause—trustworthy facts or knowledge sufficient for a reasonable person to believe the suspect has committed or is planning to commit a crime—is always required for a valid arrest. Warrants are rarely required: police generally may arrest without a warrant in a public place. However, non-emergency home arrests require an arrest warrant and a reasonable belief that the suspect is at home, and officers may only enter the home if they have reason to believe the suspect is inside. When police seek to arrest a suspect in a third party's home, they generally must obtain a search warrant for that location. A search warrant is not required if there are exigent circumstances justifying an emergency arrest in the arrestee's own home.
cards.mnemonic: P-W-H-3P: Probable cause; Warrant-free in Public; Home needs warrant; 3rd Party needs search.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::arrest}} is taking someone into custody and always requires {{c2::probable cause}}. No warrant is needed in {{c3::public}}, but a {{c4::non-emergency home}} arrest needs an {{c5::arrest warrant}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Detentions
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 002. Detentions
cards.front: Detentions
cards.backPlain: A detention is a governmental seizure of a person that is less than a full custodial arrest. 1. Common governmental detentions: 1.1 Stop and frisk (a "stop"): 1.1.1 Requires reasonable suspicion. 1.2 Automobile stop: 1.2.1 Requires reasonable suspicion. 1.3 Stationhouse detention: 1.3.1 Probable cause is required to compel a person to enter a government location for fingerprinting, questioning, or similar purposes. 1.4 Detention to obtain a search warrant: 1.4.1 Requires probable cause. 1.4.2 If police have probable cause to believe a suspect has contraband hidden in her home, they may prevent her from entering her home for a reasonable time while they obtain a search warrant. 1.4.3 The purpose must be to prevent destruction of evidence. 1.5 Detention of occupants of premises: 1.5.1 If police have a valid warrant to search premises, they may detain occupants for the duration of the proper search.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a detention, and what levels of suspicion are required for common types of governmental detentions?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::detention}} is a {{c2::governmental seizure}} of a person that is {{c3::less than a full custodial arrest}}. 1. Common governmental detentions: 1.1 {{c4::Stop and frisk}} (a "stop"): 1.1.1 Requires {{c5::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.2 {{c6::Automobile stop}}: 1.2.1 Requires {{c7::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.3 {{c8::Stationhouse detention}}: 1.3.1 {{c9::Probable cause}} is required to compel a person to enter a government location for fingerprinting, questioning, or similar purposes. 1.4 {{c10::Detention to obtain a search warrant}}: 1.4.1 Requires {{c11::probable cause}}. 1.4.2 If police have probable cause to believe a suspect has contraband hidden in her home, they may {{c12::prevent her from entering her home for a reasonable time}} while they obtain a search warrant. 1.4.3 The purpose must be to {{c13::prevent destruction of evidence}}. 1.5 {{c14::Detention of occupants of premises}}: 1.5.1 If police have a valid warrant to search premises, they may {{c15::detain occupants for the duration of the proper search}}.
cards.easyContent: A detention is a governmental seizure that falls short of a full arrest; brief stops and frisks and car stops require reasonable suspicion, while more intrusive detentions like stationhouse detention or preventing entry to a home require probable cause.
cards.mediumContent: A detention is a governmental seizure of a person that is less than a full custodial arrest. Stop-and-frisk and automobile stops require reasonable suspicion. Stationhouse detentions and detentions to obtain a search warrant require probable cause; police with probable cause to believe contraband is in a home may prevent a suspect from entering for a reasonable time to prevent destruction of evidence while they obtain a warrant. When police execute a valid search warrant for premises, they may detain occupants for the duration of the search.
cards.hardContent: A detention is a governmental seizure of a person that is less than a full custodial arrest. Common detentions include: (1) stop and frisk, which requires reasonable suspicion that crime is afoot; (2) automobile stops, which likewise require reasonable suspicion of a violation; (3) stationhouse detentions, for which probable cause is required to compel a person to come to a government location for fingerprinting, questioning, or similar purposes; (4) detentions to obtain a search warrant, which require probable cause and allow officers, when they have probable cause to believe contraband is hidden in a suspect's home, to prevent her from entering for a reasonable time while they secure a warrant, so long as the purpose is to prevent destruction of evidence; and (5) detention of occupants of premises, under which officers executing a valid search warrant may detain occupants for the duration of the proper search.
cards.mnemonic: Detentions: RS for street and car; PC for station and house.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::detention}} is a governmental seizure {{c2::less than a full custodial arrest}}. {{c3::Stop-and-frisk and car stops}} need {{c4::reasonable suspicion}}; {{c5::stationhouse detentions}} need {{c6::probable cause}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Automobile Stops and Checkpoints
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 003. Automobile Stops and Checkpoints
cards.front: Automobile Stops and Checkpoints
cards.backPlain: 1. Automobile stop: 1.1 Reasonable suspicion is required. 1.2 To stop or pull over a vehicle, police must have reasonable suspicion that a law has been violated. 1.3 Pretextual stops: An ulterior motive for a stop is permissible if police have probable cause of a traffic violation. 2. Accompanying searches (police may search): 2.1 Police may frisk passengers and search the passenger compartment (but not the trunk) if the officer reasonably believes weapons may be present. 2.2 Police can order passengers out of the vehicle. 2.3 The entire car may be searched if probable cause arises pursuant to the automobile search exception. 2.4 An automobile may also be searched incident to a lawful arrest, subject to the limits on searches incident to arrest. 3. Police checkpoints: 3.1 Checkpoints must relate to a vehicle-specific purpose. 3.2 Requirement: A police checkpoint or roadblock that stops cars without individualized suspicion (e.g., DUI checkpoints) must: 3.2.1 Stop cars using a neutral, articulable standard (e.g., every fourth car); and 3.2.2 Serve purposes related to automobiles and their mobility. 3.3 For example, DUI checkpoints that relate to road safety are valid, but drug checkpoints aimed at general crime control are insufficiently related to driving and are unconstitutional.
cards.frontPrompt: What level of suspicion is required for automobile stops, what searches may accompany such stops, and when are police checkpoints constitutional?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Automobile stop}}: 1.1 {{c2::Reasonable suspicion}} is required. 1.2 To stop or pull over a vehicle, police must have reasonable suspicion that a {{c3::law has been violated}}. 1.3 {{c4::Pretextual stops}}: An ulterior motive for a stop is permissible if police have {{c5::probable cause of a traffic violation}}. 2. {{c6::Accompanying searches}} (police may search): 2.1 Police may frisk passengers and search the {{c7::passenger compartment}} (but not the trunk) if the officer reasonably believes {{c8::weapons may be present}}. 2.2 Police can {{c9::order passengers out of the vehicle}}. 2.3 The {{c10::entire car}} may be searched if {{c11::probable cause}} arises pursuant to the {{c12::automobile search exception}}. 2.4 An automobile may also be searched {{c13::incident to a lawful arrest}}, subject to the limits on searches incident to arrest. 3. {{c14::Police checkpoints}}: 3.1 Checkpoints must relate to a {{c15::vehicle-specific purpose}}. 3.2 A police checkpoint or roadblock that stops cars without {{c16::individualized suspicion}} (e.g., DUI checkpoints) must: 3.2.1 Stop cars using a {{c17::neutral, articulable standard}} (e.g., every fourth car); and 3.2.2 Serve purposes related to {{c18::automobiles and their mobility}}. 3.3 For example, {{c19::DUI checkpoints}} that relate to {{c20::road safety}} are valid, but {{c21::drug checkpoints}} aimed at {{c22::general crime control}} are unconstitutional.
cards.easyContent: Police may stop a car on reasonable suspicion that a law has been violated and may frisk passengers and search areas for weapons or evidence under established exceptions; checkpoints without individualized suspicion are valid only if they use neutral criteria and are tied to roadway or vehicle safety, like DUI checkpoints.
cards.mediumContent: An automobile stop requires reasonable suspicion that a law has been violated, and pretextual stops are valid if police have probable cause of a traffic violation. During a valid stop, officers may frisk passengers and search the passenger compartment (not the trunk) if they reasonably believe weapons may be present, may order passengers out, may search the entire car if probable cause arises under the automobile exception, and may search the vehicle incident to a lawful arrest within the usual limits. Police checkpoints that stop cars without individualized suspicion are constitutional only if they use a neutral, articulable standard (such as every fourth car) and serve a vehicle-related purpose, like DUI checkpoints for road safety; drug checkpoints for general crime control are invalid.
cards.hardContent: An automobile stop is a seizure of the vehicle and its occupants that requires reasonable suspicion that a law has been violated. Pretextual stops are permitted as long as officers have objective probable cause for a traffic violation, regardless of their subjective motives. During a valid stop, officers may, when they reasonably believe weapons may be present, frisk passengers and search the passenger compartment (but not the trunk) for weapons; they may also order passengers out of the vehicle for officer safety. If probable cause develops that the vehicle contains contraband or evidence, the entire car, including containers, may be searched under the automobile search exception. Additionally, officers may search a vehicle incident to a lawful arrest within the limits applicable to searches incident to arrest. Police checkpoints and roadblocks that stop vehicles without individualized suspicion are constitutional only when they are based on a neutral, articulable standard (e.g., every fourth car) and are designed to serve purposes related to automobiles and their mobility, such as roadway safety; DUI checkpoints are valid, whereas drug checkpoints aimed at general crime control are unconstitutional.
cards.mnemonic: CAR-DUI: Car stop needs RS; DUI checkpoints need Neutral, Vehicle-related purpose.
cards.clozeLite: An automobile stop requires {{c1::reasonable suspicion}}, but {{c2::pretextual stops}} are valid with {{c3::probable cause}}; {{c4::DUI checkpoints}} are valid only if {{c5::neutral and vehicle-related}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Determining the Validity of a Search or Seizure
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 004. Determining the Validity of a Search or Seizure
cards.front: Determining the Validity of a Search or Seizure
cards.backPlain: To determine whether a search or seizure is valid under the Fourth Amendment, use a structured approach: 1. General Rule & Framework 1.1 Government searches and seizures of evidence must be reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. 1.2 Reasonableness generally requires a valid search warrant unless a recognized warrant exception applies. 2. High-Level Analysis Steps 2.1 Applicability: Does the Fourth Amendment apply (i.e., is there qualifying government conduct rather than purely private conduct, unless private actors are directed by government agents)? 2.2 Standing: Does the defendant have a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place or item searched? 2.3 Warrant vs. Exceptions: Was there a valid search warrant? If not, does the search fall within a recognized warrant exception (such as search incident to arrest, plain view, automobile search, consent, exigent circumstances, or stop and frisk)?
cards.frontPrompt: Outline the main steps to analyze whether a search or seizure is valid under the Fourth Amendment, including applicability, standing, and the warrant vs. exceptions framework.
cards.cloze: To determine whether a search or seizure is valid under the Fourth Amendment, use a structured approach: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: Government searches and seizures of evidence must be {{c2::reasonable}} under the {{c3::Fourth Amendment}}. 2. {{c4::Applicability}}: Is there qualifying {{c5::government conduct}} (including private actors directed by government agents), rather than {{c6::purely private conduct}}? 3. {{c7::Standing}}: Does the defendant have a {{c8::reasonable expectation of privacy}} in the place or item searched? 4. {{c9::Warrant vs. exceptions}}: Was there a valid {{c10::search warrant}}? If not, must the search be justified by a {{c11::recognized warrant exception}} (e.g., {{c12::search incident to arrest}}, {{c13::plain view}}, {{c14::automobile search}}, {{c15::consent}}, {{c16::exigent circumstances}}, or {{c17::stop and frisk}})?
cards.easyContent: Use a three-step Fourth Amendment search/seizure framework: (1) Does the Fourth Amendment apply (government conduct vs. purely private conduct)? (2) Does the defendant have standing via a reasonable expectation of privacy? (3) Was there a valid warrant, or does a main warrant exception apply (search incident, plain view, automobile, consent, exigent, or stop and frisk)?
cards.mediumContent: To determine the validity of a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment: (1) Confirm the Amendment applies by identifying government conduct, including private actors directed by government agents, and excluding purely private conduct. (2) Confirm the defendant has standing by showing a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place or item searched. (3) Ask whether there was a valid search warrant; if not, the search must fall within a recognized exception such as search incident to arrest, plain view, automobile search, consent, exigent circumstances, or stop and frisk.
cards.hardContent: A structured Fourth Amendment analysis proceeds as follows: (1) Applicability: The Fourth Amendment regulates only government conduct, which includes direct government action and private persons acting at the direction of government agents; it does not restrict purely private conduct. (2) Standing: A defendant may challenge a search only if he has a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place or item searched. (3) Warrant vs. Exceptions: A search or seizure is reasonable only if it is supported by a valid search warrant or fits within a recognized exception. The main warrant exceptions to remember are search incident to arrest, plain view, automobile search, valid consent, exigent circumstances, and stop and frisk.
cards.mnemonic: SPACE-S: Search incident, Plain view, Auto, Consent, Exigent, Stop-and-frisk.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) Fourth Amendment applicability and government conduct, (2) standing and reasonable expectation of privacy, and (3) warrant vs. main exceptions framework.
cards.clozeLite: Fourth Amendment validity: (1) {{c1::government conduct (not purely private)}}, (2) {{c2::defendant’s reasonable expectation of privacy}}, (3) {{c3::valid warrant or recognized exception (SPACE-S)}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Reasonable Expectation of Privacy
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 005. Reasonable Expectation of Privacy
cards.front: Reasonable Expectation of Privacy – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. The Fourth Amendment only applies if a person has a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in the place or thing searched and/or the items seized. 2. Standing to challenge a government search requires a REOP, determined by the totality of the circumstances. 3. REOP is limited: there is no REOP in inherently public information or in areas outside the home’s curtilage, but REOP is automatically recognized in certain strong home-related situations (ownership/possession/residence/overnight guest).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) and how does it relate to Fourth Amendment standing at a high level?
cards.cloze: 1. The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} only applies if a person has a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in the place or thing searched and/or the items seized. 2. {{c3::Standing}} to challenge a government search requires a REOP, determined by the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 3. REOP is limited: there is {{c5::no REOP in inherently public information or in areas outside the home’s curtilage}}, but REOP is {{c6::automatically recognized in certain strong home-related situations}} (ownership/possession/residence/overnight guest).
cards.easyContent: The Fourth Amendment applies only if a person has a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP), and a defendant has standing to challenge a search only if they had such an expectation. REOP is judged by the totality of the circumstances and is weaker in public or exposed places, but strongest in home-related situations like where you live or stay overnight.
cards.mediumContent: A reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) is required both for the Fourth Amendment to apply and for a defendant to have standing to challenge a search. REOP is evaluated under the totality of the circumstances: it is generally lacking in inherently public information and areas exposed to the public, and strongest in settings tied to the home, such as premises the defendant owns, possesses, lives in, or uses as an overnight guest.
cards.hardContent: The Fourth Amendment governs only when government conduct invades a person’s reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in a place or thing or in the items seized. Standing to challenge that conduct hinges on whether the defendant personally had such a REOP, assessed under the totality of the circumstances. REOP is not uniform: it is typically lacking in inherently public or exposed information and in areas beyond a home’s curtilage, but it is robust—and often automatically recognized—in home-centered situations, such as where the defendant owns, possesses, or lives in the premises, or is staying there as an overnight guest.
cards.mnemonic: REOP HOME: Have Ownership, Membership, or be an Overnight guest.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) definition of REOP and its role in standing; (2) situations where there is no REOP; (3) automatic standing in home-related situations.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} and {{c2::standing}} both require a {{c3::reasonable expectation of privacy}}, judged by the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}, and {{c5::strongest in home-related settings}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Requirements for a Valid Search Warrant
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 006. Requirements for a Valid Search Warrant
cards.front: Requirements for a Valid Search Warrant
cards.backPlain: A search is ordinarily valid only if conducted under a properly executed search warrant, unless a warrant exception applies. A valid warrant requires three core things: (1) probable cause, usually established by a police affidavit setting out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found; (2) particularity, meaning the warrant must describe with reasonable precision the place to be searched and the items to be seized; and (3) issuance by a neutral and detached magistrate. Even if a warrant is later found invalid, the exclusionary rule does not apply if officers relied on it in objective good faith, subject to narrow exceptions (e.g., no probable cause at all, facial defect, police deceit, or a magistrate who has abandoned the judicial role).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the core constitutional requirements for a valid search warrant, and how does the good-faith exception fit into the analysis?
cards.cloze: A search is ordinarily valid only if conducted under a properly executed {{c1::search warrant}}, unless a warrant exception applies. A valid warrant requires three core things: (1) {{c2::probable cause}}, usually established by a police {{c3::affidavit}} setting out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found; (2) {{c4::particularity}}, meaning the warrant must describe with reasonable precision the {{c5::place to be searched}} and the {{c6::items to be seized}}; and (3) issuance by a {{c7::neutral and detached magistrate}}. Even if a warrant is later found invalid, the {{c8::exclusionary rule}} does not apply if officers relied on it in objective {{c9::good faith}}, subject to narrow exceptions (e.g., {{c10::no probable cause at all}}, {{c11::facial defect}}, {{c12::police deceit}}, or a {{c13::magistrate who has abandoned the judicial role}}).
cards.easyContent: A valid search warrant generally requires probable cause, particularity about the place to be searched and items to be seized, and issuance by a neutral and detached magistrate. Even if the warrant later turns out to be invalid, evidence usually is not excluded if officers relied on it in objective good faith, subject to narrow exceptions.
cards.mediumContent: Unless a warrant exception applies, the government must obtain a search warrant to conduct a valid search. The warrant must be supported by probable cause, typically shown in a factual affidavit; must particularly describe the place to be searched and the items to be seized; and must be issued by a neutral and detached magistrate. Under the good-faith exception, evidence is not excluded if police act in objective good-faith reliance on a warrant, unless the affidavit is wholly lacking in probable cause, the warrant is facially defective, the police misled the magistrate, or the magistrate abandoned the judicial role.
cards.hardContent: A search is ordinarily valid only if conducted under a properly executed search warrant, unless a recognized exception applies. A valid warrant requires: (1) probable cause, usually established by a police affidavit setting out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found; (2) particularity, meaning the warrant must describe with reasonable precision the place to be searched and the items to be seized; and (3) issuance by a neutral and detached magistrate. Even if the warrant is later found invalid, the exclusionary rule does not apply if officers relied on it in objective good faith, except where (a) the affidavit is wholly lacking in probable cause such that no reasonable officer would rely on it; (b) the warrant is facially defective; (c) the police or government officials lied to or misled the magistrate; or (d) the magistrate has wholly abandoned the judicial role.
cards.mnemonic: Valid warrant = PNP: Probable cause, particularity, Neutral magistrate; good faith usually saves.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) general warrant requirement; (2) probable cause and affidavit / false statement rule; (3) particularity requirement; (4) neutral and detached magistrate and good-faith exception with its exceptions.
cards.clozeLite: A valid search warrant requires {{c1::probable cause}}, {{c2::particularity}} in describing place and items, and {{c3::a neutral and detached magistrate}}; the {{c4::good-faith exception}} limits {{c5::exclusion of evidence}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Execution of Search Warrants
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 007. Execution of Search Warrants
cards.front: Execution of Search Warrants
cards.backPlain: 1. Timing: 1.1. A search warrant must be executed without unreasonable delay after it is issued. 2. Knock-and-announce requirement: 2.1. Police must knock and announce their purpose, then wait a reasonable time for admittance before entering on their own accord. 2.2. Exception: Knock-and-announce is not required if officers have reasonable suspicion that announcing their presence would be dangerous, futile, or would inhibit the investigation. 3. Scope of search: 3.1. The search is limited to what is reasonably necessary to discover items described in the warrant. 3.2. Police can detain people found on the searched premises. 3.3. But police cannot search detained persons unless they are specifically named in the warrant or a valid warrantless search exception exists.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the rules governing timing, knock-and-announce, and scope when executing a valid search warrant, including detention and search of persons on the premises?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Timing}}: 1.1. A search warrant must be executed without {{c2::unreasonable delay}} after it is issued. 2. {{c3::Knock-and-announce}} requirement: 2.1. Police must {{c4::knock and announce their purpose}}, then wait a {{c5::reasonable time}} for admittance before entering on their own accord. 2.2. Exception: Knock-and-announce is not required if officers have {{c6::reasonable suspicion}} that announcing their presence would be {{c7::dangerous}}, {{c8::futile}}, or would {{c9::inhibit the investigation}}. 3. {{c10::Scope of search}}: 3.1. The search is limited to what is {{c11::reasonably necessary to discover items described in the warrant}}. 3.2. Police can {{c12::detain people}} found on the searched premises. 3.3. But police cannot {{c13::search detained persons}} unless they are {{c14::specifically named in the warrant}} or a {{c15::valid warrantless search exception}} exists.
cards.easyContent: A search warrant must be executed without unreasonable delay, and officers generally must knock, announce, and wait a reasonable time before entering unless doing so would be dangerous, futile, or compromise the investigation. The search is limited to the places and items described, and while officers may detain people on the premises, they may not search them absent specific authorization or a warrant exception.
cards.mediumContent: Officers must execute a warrant without unreasonable delay after issuance. They ordinarily must knock, announce their presence and purpose, and wait a reasonable time before entering, unless they have reasonable suspicion that compliance would be dangerous, futile, or would seriously inhibit the investigation. The scope of the search is limited to areas reasonably necessary to find items described in the warrant. Officers may detain occupants of the premises but may only search those persons if they are named in the warrant or another valid exception to the warrant requirement applies.
cards.hardContent: In executing a search warrant, police must act within a reasonable time, executing the warrant without unreasonable delay after issuance. They are generally required to knock, announce their presence and purpose, and wait a reasonable time for admittance before entering. However, if officers have reasonable suspicion that announcing would be dangerous, futile, or would inhibit the investigation (for example, by allowing destruction of evidence), the knock-and-announce requirement is excused. The scope of the search is confined to what is reasonably necessary to locate the items described in the warrant. Police may detain individuals found on the premises during the search for officer safety and to facilitate the search, but they may not search those individuals unless they are specifically named in the warrant or a valid warrantless search exception applies (such as search incident to lawful arrest).
cards.mnemonic: T-K-S-P: Timely, Knock, Scope limited, People only if named/exception.
cards.clozeLite: Officers executing a warrant must {{c1::knock, announce, and wait a reasonable time}} unless {{c2::danger, futility, or hindrance}} justifies no-knock, and may {{c3::detain but not automatically search}} occupants.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 008. Search Incident to Lawful Arrest
cards.front: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest
cards.backPlain: Search incident to a lawful arrest (SILA) is a categorical exception to the warrant requirement that permits officers, following a lawful arrest, to search the arrestee and certain areas and items closely associated with the arrest for weapons and destructible evidence. Core SILA covers the arrestee’s person and the area within his immediate control, and must be contemporaneous with the arrest. Related doctrines include: (1) limited protective sweeps of adjoining areas when officers reasonably believe there is danger or accomplices; (2) inventory searches of the arrestee’s belongings or impounded property when jailing, if done under standardized procedures; (3) vehicle searches incident to arrest, limited to the passenger compartment when the arrestee is unsecured or officers reasonably believe evidence of the offense of arrest is inside, but not the trunk without probable cause or consent; and (4) special rules for certain items, such as warrantless breathalyzer tests after a probable-cause DUI arrest and the requirement of a warrant to search digital information on seized cell phones.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the search-incident-to-lawful-arrest (SILA) exception allow, and what major related doctrines and limitations should you consider (protective sweeps, inventory searches, vehicles, breath tests, and cell phones)?
cards.cloze: Search incident to a lawful arrest ({{c1::SILA}}) is a categorical exception to the warrant requirement that permits officers, following a {{c2::lawful arrest}}, to search the {{c3::arrestee}} and certain areas and items closely associated with the arrest for weapons and destructible evidence. Core SILA covers the arrestee’s person and the area within his {{c4::immediate control}} and must be {{c5::contemporaneous}} with the arrest. Related doctrines include: (1) limited {{c6::protective sweeps}} of adjoining areas when officers reasonably believe there is danger or accomplices; (2) {{c7::inventory searches}} of the arrestee’s belongings or impounded property when jailing, if done under standardized procedures; (3) {{c8::vehicle searches incident to arrest}}, limited to the passenger compartment when the arrestee is unsecured or officers reasonably believe evidence of the offense of arrest is inside, but not the trunk without probable cause or consent; and (4) special rules for certain items, such as warrantless {{c9::breathalyzer}} tests after a probable-cause DUI arrest and the requirement of a {{c10::warrant}} to search digital information on seized {{c11::cell phones}}.
cards.easyContent: Search incident to a lawful arrest (SILA) lets officers, without a warrant, search the arrestee and the area within his immediate control at the time of arrest. Related doctrines expand what officers may check for safety and evidence: brief protective sweeps of nearby spaces, inventory searches at booking under standardized rules, limited vehicle searches of the passenger compartment incident to arrest, and special rules for breath tests and cell phones (breath tests usually allowed after a DUI arrest; phone data generally requires a warrant).
cards.mediumContent: Search incident to a lawful arrest (SILA) is a categorical exception allowing officers, after a lawful arrest, to search the arrestee and the area within his immediate control, so long as the search is contemporaneous with the arrest and confined to places the arrestee could access weapons or destroy evidence. Related doctrines include: (1) protective sweeps—brief checks of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest area based on a reasonable belief of danger or accomplices; (2) inventory searches of the arrestee’s belongings or impounded property at booking, if conducted pursuant to standardized procedures; (3) vehicle searches incident to arrest of the passenger compartment, including containers, when the arrestee is unsecured and can access the interior, or when officers reasonably believe the vehicle contains evidence of the offense of arrest, but not the trunk absent probable cause or consent; and (4) item-specific rules like warrantless breathalyzer tests after a probable-cause drunk-driving arrest and the requirement of a warrant before searching digital contents of seized cell phones.
cards.hardContent: The search-incident-to-lawful-arrest (SILA) exception permits officers, without a warrant, to search a lawfully arrested person and the area within his immediate control, provided the underlying arrest is lawful, the search is contemporaneous with the arrest, and it is limited to locations the arrestee could access to obtain weapons or destroy evidence. SILA interacts with several related doctrines: (1) Protective sweeps—officers may conduct a cursory inspection of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest area when they have a reasonable belief that accomplices may be present or there is danger, and may expand the sweep based on articulable facts suggesting a threat. (2) Inventory searches—when an arrestee is taken to jail, officers may inventory his belongings or other seized property, including impounded vehicles, pursuant to standardized, good-faith procedures. (3) Vehicle searches incident to arrest—after arresting a recent occupant, officers may search the vehicle’s passenger compartment, including containers and the glove box, if at the time of the search the arrestee is unsecured and can reach the interior, or if it is reasonable to believe the vehicle contains evidence of the offense of arrest; the trunk may not be searched incident to arrest absent probable cause (e.g., supporting an automobile-exception search) or consent. (4) Item-specific limits—warrantless breathalyzer tests are generally permissible after a lawful, probable-cause drunk-driving arrest, but officers ordinarily may not search the digital contents of a cell phone seized incident to arrest without first obtaining a warrant.
cards.mnemonic: SILA: Search Immediately after Lawful Arrest—person and reachable area.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four children: (1) core SILA rule and scope; (2) protective sweeps and inventory searches; (3) vehicle searches incident to arrest; (4) breath tests and cell-phone limitation.
cards.clozeLite: SILA lets officers, after a {{c1::lawful arrest}}, search the {{c2::arrestee}} and {{c3::area within his immediate control}} if {{c4::contemporaneous}} with the arrest.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Plain View Searches
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 009. Plain View Searches
cards.front: Plain View Searches
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Police may observe and use their senses from any place where they are legitimately present when conducting a search or investigation. 2. Seizure based on plain view (police may seize evidence in plain view without a warrant if): 2.1. Police are legitimately on the premises from which they viewed the evidence to be seized. 2.2. Criminal activity or contraband is immediately apparent. 2.3. Police have probable cause to believe that the plainly viewed evidence is contraband or relates to a crime. 3. Scope of plain view searches: 3.1. Includes anything viewable from land or public property, even if only viewable through binoculars. 3.2. "Plain smell" is included within the plain view doctrine. 3.3. If a smell gives rise to probable cause from a place of legitimate police presence, they can search that item. 4. Limitations: 4.1. Police cannot use technology not generally available to the public to view evidence that would otherwise be hidden (e.g., infrared scanners that can view through walls). 4.2. Note: Use of drones for plain view searches is unsettled law and thus unlikely to appear on the MBE.
cards.frontPrompt: When may police seize evidence under the plain view doctrine, including plain smell, and what limits are there on technology and vantage point?

Police have {{c6::probable cause}} to believe that the plainly viewed evidence is contraband or relates to a crime. 3. Scope of plain view searches: 3.1. Includes anything viewable from {{c7::land or public property}}, even if only viewable through {{c8::binoculars}}. 3.2. {{c9::"Plain smell"}} is included within the plain view doctrine. 3.3. If a smell gives rise to {{c10::probable cause}} from a place of legitimate police presence, they can {{c11::search that item}}. 4. Limitations: 4.1. Police cannot use technology {{c12::not generally available to the public}} to view evidence that would otherwise be hidden (e.g., {{c13::infrared scanners that can view through walls}}). 4.2. Note: Use of {{c14::drones}} for plain view searches is unsettled law and thus unlikely to appear on the MBE.
cards.easyContent: Under the plain view doctrine, officers lawfully present may seize items they can immediately recognize as contraband or evidence, if they have probable cause to associate the item with criminal activity. Plain view includes what officers can see and even smell from lawful vantage points, but not what they can detect only by using high-tech devices not generally available to the public.
cards.mediumContent: Police may use their senses from any place where they are legitimately present, and may seize evidence in plain view without a warrant if they are lawfully on the premises, the incriminating nature of the item is immediately apparent, and they have probable cause to believe the item is contraband or evidence of a crime. Plain view extends to items visible from public spaces, even using binoculars, and to "plain smell"—odors that give rise to probable cause when officers are lawfully present. However, officers may not use sense-enhancing technology not in general public use, like thermal imagers that see through walls, to transform what is otherwise hidden into plain view.
cards.hardContent: The plain view doctrine allows officers who are legitimately present in a location to observe and rely on what they perceive with their senses. They may seize evidence without a warrant if: (1) they are lawfully on the premises from which they view the item; (2) the criminal nature or contraband status of the item is immediately apparent; and (3) they have probable cause to believe the item is contraband or evidence of a crime. This doctrine covers items visible from land or public property, even if officers use simple aids like binoculars, and it encompasses "plain smell," where an odor perceived from a lawful vantage point gives rise to probable cause and justifies searching the source of the smell. But officers may not use technology not generally available to the public, such as infrared or thermal imaging devices that reveal details inside a home, to claim plain view of what would otherwise be hidden. The use of drones in plain view scenarios is unsettled and unlikely to be a focus on the MBE.
cards.mnemonic: Plain View: Proper place, Probable cause, Problem obvious; smell ok, gadgets no.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::plain view}}, police lawfully present may seize {{c2::immediately apparent contraband or evidence}} if they have {{c3::probable cause}} and use only {{c4::senses or simple aids, not high-tech devices}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Consent to Search
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 010. Consent to Search
cards.front: Consent to Search
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule: With valid consent, police may search anything within the scope of that consent. 2. Requirements for valid consent 2.1 Voluntarily and intelligently made 2.1.1 Police cannot falsely claim legal cause to search. 2.1.2 Police have no obligation to inform suspects that they have a right to refuse consent. 2.2 Authority to consent 2.2.1 The person giving consent must have authority to consent. 2.2.2 Authority to consent must be reasonably apparent. 2.3 Scope of consent 2.3.1 The scope of consent can be limited by the consenting party. 2.3.2 A violation of the scope renders the entire search non-consenting. 2.4 Third-party consent 2.4.1 Third-party consent is allowed if the third party has authority to consent. 2.4.2 Where multiple people have property rights (e.g., ownership, authorized use, occupancy), any single one can consent to the search of any area where that person has authority to consent. 2.4.3 A resident's right to consent or refuse generally trumps a non-resident's. 2.4.4 For example: If both a tenant and landlord are present, the tenant's refusal trumps the landlord's consent. The scope of consent is dictated by the person present with the highest authority to consent. 2.4.5 Refusal trumps consent: If two persons with equal right to possession disagree on consent, there is no valid consent.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for a valid consent to search, including authority, scope, and third-party consent rules?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule: With valid {{c1::consent}}, police may search anything within the {{c2::scope of that consent}}. 2. Requirements for valid consent 2.1 {{c3::Voluntarily and intelligently}} made 2.1.1 Police cannot {{c4::falsely claim legal cause to search}}. 2.1.2 Police have {{c5::no obligation to inform suspects that they have a right to refuse consent}}. 2.2 {{c6::Authority to consent}} 2.2.1 The person giving consent must have {{c7::authority to consent}}. 2.2.2 Authority to consent must be {{c8::reasonably apparent}}. 2.3 {{c9::Scope of consent}} 2.3.1 The scope of consent can be {{c10::limited by the consenting party}}. 2.3.2 A {{c11::violation of the scope}} renders the entire search {{c12::non-consenting}}. 2.4 {{c13::Third-party consent}} 2.4.1 Third-party consent is allowed if the third party has {{c14::authority to consent}}. 2.4.2 Where multiple people have property rights (e.g., ownership, authorized use, occupancy), any single one can consent to the search of any area where that person has {{c15::authority to consent}}. 2.4.3 A {{c16::resident's}} right to consent or refuse generally trumps a {{c17::non-resident's}}. 2.4.4 For example: If both a {{c18::tenant}} and {{c19::landlord}} are present, the tenant's refusal trumps the landlord's consent. The scope of consent is dictated by the person present with the {{c20::highest authority to consent}}. 2.4.5 {{c21::Refusal trumps consent}}: If two persons with equal right to possession disagree on consent, there is {{c22::no valid consent}}.
cards.easyContent: Police may conduct a search based on valid consent that is voluntary, given by someone with authority, and within the scope of that consent.
cards.mediumContent: Consent to search is valid when it is given voluntarily and intelligently, by someone with actual or reasonably apparent authority, and the police stay within the scope defined by the consenting person. Third-party consent is allowed where the third party has authority, but a resident’s refusal generally overrides a non-resident’s consent, and refusal by one of two equal co-occupants negates consent.
cards.hardContent: With valid consent, police may search anything within the scope of that consent. Consent must be voluntarily and intelligently given; officers may not falsely claim legal authority to search, but they need not tell a suspect that consent can be refused. The person granting consent must have actual or reasonably apparent authority. The consenting party may limit the scope, and exceeding that scope renders the search non-consensual. Third-party consent is valid if the third party has authority over the area. Where multiple people share property rights, any one can consent to search areas within that person’s authority, but a resident’s refusal generally trumps a non-resident’s consent. If two co-occupants with equal rights disagree, refusal trumps consent and there is no valid consent.
cards.mnemonic: VAS-T: Voluntary, Authority, Scope, Third-party (refusal trumps).
cards.clozeLite: Consent is valid if {{c1::voluntary and intelligent}}, from {{c2::actual or reasonably apparent authority}}, and within the {{c3::scope defined by the consenter}}; {{c4::co-occupant refusal trumps consent}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Automobile Search Exception
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 011. Automobile Search Exception
cards.front: Automobile Search Exception
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule: If probable cause exists, police may search an entire vehicle (including the trunk) and any containers or compartments inside that may contain the evidence they are searching for. 2. Requirements 2.1 Police must have probable cause to search the vehicle. 2.2 Probable cause must arise before the search begins. 3. Scope of permissible search 3.1 Police can search the entire vehicle and all containers within the vehicle that might contain the object for which they are searching. 3.2 For example: Police may open packages or luggage that might contain evidence relating to the reason they searched the vehicle. 3.3 Police may search passengers and their belongings if those containers might reasonably hold the object of the search.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the automobile search exception, when may police search a vehicle and what is the permissible scope of that search?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule: If {{c1::probable cause}} exists, police may search an {{c2::entire vehicle}} (including the trunk) and any {{c3::containers or compartments}} inside that may contain the evidence they are searching for. 2. Requirements 2.1 Police must have {{c4::probable cause}} to search the vehicle. 2.2 Probable cause must {{c5::arise before the search begins}}. 3. Scope of permissible search 3.1 Police can search the {{c6::entire vehicle}} and {{c7::all containers within the vehicle}} that might contain the object for which they are searching. 3.2 For example: Police may open {{c8::packages or luggage}} that might contain evidence relating to the reason they searched the vehicle. 3.3 Police may search {{c9::passengers and their belongings}} if those containers might reasonably hold the object of the search.
cards.easyContent: If police have probable cause before a search begins, they may search the entire vehicle, including the trunk and containers, for evidence related to that probable cause.
cards.mediumContent: The automobile search exception allows police to search a vehicle without a warrant when they have probable cause, arising before the search, that the vehicle contains evidence of a crime. They may search the entire vehicle, including the trunk, and any containers or passengers’ belongings that could reasonably contain the object of the search.
cards.hardContent: Under the automobile search exception, if police have probable cause that a vehicle contains evidence of a crime, they may conduct a warrantless search of the entire vehicle, including the trunk. Probable cause must exist before the search begins. The scope extends to all containers and compartments within the vehicle that might reasonably hold the object of the search, including packages, luggage, and passengers’ belongings, so long as those containers could contain the evidence sought.
cards.mnemonic: "PC before you drive": Probable Cause before search = whole Car and Containers.
cards.clozeLite: Under the {{c1::automobile search exception}}, police may search a vehicle without a warrant if they have {{c2::probable cause before the search}} and may search {{c3::the entire vehicle, including trunk and containers}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Stop and Frisk
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 012. Stop and Frisk
cards.front: Stop and Frisk
cards.backPlain: 1. General Rule: Police may detain a person for an investigative purpose if they have reasonable suspicion of criminal activity. 2. Allowable scope of stop and frisk 2.1 Length: Detention must be no longer than necessary to verify or dispel the suspicion. 2.2 Frisk: If police have reasonable suspicion the person is armed or dangerous, they may frisk for weapons. 2.3 Plain feel: If police have reasonable belief during the frisk that what they feel is a weapon or contraband, they may seize the suspected item. 2.3.1 Officers cannot manipulate the item to develop reasonable belief. 2.3.2 It must be plain touch only. 2.3.3 Evidence validly seized is admissible. 3. Stop vs. arrest 3.1 A stop is a brief detention, less intrusive than an arrest. 3.2 Police may develop probable cause to arrest based on anything occurring or discovered during the stop and/or frisk. Note: Stop and frisk is often called a Terry stop.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the standard for a stop and frisk, and what are the limits on the length, scope, and plain-feel seizure during such an encounter?
cards.cloze: 1. General Rule: Police may detain a person for an investigative purpose if they have {{c1::reasonable suspicion}} of {{c2::criminal activity}}. 2. Allowable scope of stop and frisk 2.1 Length: Detention must be {{c3::no longer than necessary}} to verify or dispel the suspicion. 2.2 Frisk: If police have reasonable suspicion the person is {{c4::armed or dangerous}}, they may {{c5::frisk for weapons}}. 2.3 {{c6::Plain feel}}: If police have reasonable belief during the frisk that what they feel is a {{c7::weapon or contraband}}, they may seize the suspected item. 2.3.1 Officers cannot {{c8::manipulate the item}} to develop reasonable belief. 2.3.2 It must be {{c9::plain touch only}}. 2.3.3 Evidence validly seized is {{c10::admissible}}. 3. Stop vs. arrest 3.1 A stop is a {{c11::brief detention}}, less intrusive than an {{c12::arrest}}. 3.2 Police may develop {{c13::probable cause to arrest}} based on anything occurring or discovered during the stop and/or frisk. Note: Stop and frisk is often called a {{c14::Terry stop}}.
cards.easyContent: Police may briefly stop a person based on reasonable suspicion of criminal activity, and may frisk for weapons if they reasonably suspect the person is armed or dangerous.
cards.mediumContent: A Terry stop allows police to detain someone on reasonable suspicion of criminal activity for only as long as needed to confirm or dispel that suspicion. If they also have reasonable suspicion the person is armed or dangerous, they may conduct a limited pat-down for weapons, and may seize items under the plain-feel doctrine without manipulating them. Evidence seized in a valid frisk is admissible, and facts from the stop can lead to probable cause to arrest.
cards.hardContent: Under Terry, police may briefly detain a person for investigative purposes if they have reasonable suspicion, based on articulable facts, of criminal activity. The stop’s duration must be no longer than necessary to verify or dispel that suspicion. If officers additionally have reasonable suspicion that the person is armed or dangerous, they may perform a limited frisk for weapons. Under the plain-feel doctrine, if during that lawful pat-down an officer immediately recognizes an object as a weapon or contraband by plain touch, the officer may seize it, but may not manipulate the item to create probable cause. Evidence validly seized is admissible. A stop is a brief, less intrusive detention than an arrest, but information learned during the stop or frisk can supply probable cause to arrest.
cards.mnemonic: RS for Stop, RS + Armed for Frisk, Feel to Seize.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::Terry stop}} requires {{c2::reasonable suspicion of criminal activity}} and permits a {{c3::limited frisk for weapons}} plus {{c4::plain-feel seizure without manipulation}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Exigent Circumstances
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 013. Exigent Circumstances
cards.front: Exigent Circumstances
cards.backPlain: Hot Pursuit and Emergency Searches: 1. General Rule: If exigent circumstances exist, police can search or seize evidence without a warrant. Hot pursuit, evanescent evidence, and emergencies are forms of exigent circumstances justifying a warrantless search or seizure. 2. Hot pursuit 2.1 While actively pursuing a fleeing felon, police can search for anything relating to the pursuit or can search for their own protection. 2.2 The permissible scope is as broad as reasonably necessary to prevent the suspect from escaping or resisting. 2.3 Police can enter into a private dwelling after attempting arrest in a public place if they have probable cause. 3. Evanescent evidence 3.1 Police can search or seize evidence that could disappear if police were required to secure a warrant. 3.2 For example: Drugs that may be discarded or destroyed, or DNA evidence that may not last. 3.3 Reasonableness is judged by the totality of the circumstances. 4. Emergency 4.1 Warrantless searches are justified for emergencies that threaten health or safety if not immediately acted upon. 4.2 For example: Police see someone injured or threatened with injury, bomb threats, or the need to find the source of a food or drug contamination. 4.3 Whether an emergency exists is viewed objectively. Note: A valid plain-view search or seizure can arise from any of the above warrantless searches.
cards.frontPrompt: What exigent circumstances allow warrantless searches or seizures, and what are the rules for hot pursuit, evanescent evidence, and emergency situations?
cards.cloze: Hot Pursuit and Emergency Searches: 1. General Rule: If {{c1::exigent circumstances}} exist, police can {{c2::search or seize evidence without a warrant}}. {{c3::Hot pursuit}}, {{c4::evanescent evidence}}, and {{c5::emergencies}} are forms of exigent circumstances justifying a warrantless search or seizure. 2. {{c6::Hot pursuit}} 2.1 While actively pursuing a {{c7::fleeing felon}}, police can search for anything relating to the pursuit or can search for their own protection. 2.2 The permissible scope is as broad as {{c8::reasonably necessary}} to prevent the suspect from {{c9::escaping or resisting}}. 2.3 Police can {{c10::enter a private dwelling}} after attempting arrest in a public place if they have {{c11::probable cause}}. 3. {{c12::Evanescent evidence}} 3.1 Police can search or seize evidence that could {{c13::disappear if they had to secure a warrant}}. 3.2 For example: {{c14::drugs that may be discarded or destroyed}} or {{c15::DNA evidence that may not last}}. 3.3 Reasonableness is judged by the {{c16::totality of the circumstances}}. 4. {{c17::Emergency}} 4.1 Warrantless searches are justified for emergencies that {{c18::threaten health or safety}} if not immediately acted upon. 4.2 For example: Police see someone {{c19::injured or threatened with injury}}, {{c20::bomb threats}}, or the need to find the source of a {{c21::food or drug contamination}}. 4.3 Whether an emergency exists is viewed {{c22::objectively}}. Note: A valid {{c23::plain-view}} search or seizure can arise from any of the above warrantless searches.
cards.easyContent: Exigent circumstances—such as hot pursuit, evanescent evidence, or emergencies—allow police to conduct warrantless searches or seizures when waiting for a warrant would risk escape, destruction of evidence, or harm to health or safety.
cards.mediumContent: When exigent circumstances exist, police may search or seize without a warrant. In hot pursuit of a fleeing felon, officers may enter dwellings and search as broadly as reasonably necessary to prevent escape or resistance, provided they have probable cause. For evanescent evidence that may quickly disappear, they may act immediately, with reasonableness judged by the totality of the circumstances. In true emergencies threatening health or safety, warrantless entry and search are allowed, assessed under an objective standard, and plain-view seizures arising from these entries are valid.
cards.hardContent: Exigent circumstances justify warrantless searches or seizures where delaying for a warrant would risk escape, evidence destruction, or imminent harm. Hot pursuit of a fleeing felon permits officers to enter private dwellings and search for the suspect or related dangers as broadly as reasonably necessary to prevent escape or resistance, so long as they have probable cause. For evanescent evidence—such as drugs likely to be discarded or DNA that may degrade—police may immediately search or seize, with overall reasonableness evaluated under the totality of the circumstances. Emergency situations that objectively threaten health or safety, such as visible injuries, bomb threats, or urgent efforts to locate a source of food or drug contamination, likewise allow warrantless entry and search. Any plain-view observation and seizure that occurs during these lawful warrantless entries is valid.
cards.mnemonic: HEE: Hot pursuit, Evanescent evidence, Emergencies allow exigent entry.
cards.clozeLite: {{c1::Exigent circumstances}}—{{c2::hot pursuit}}, {{c3::evanescent evidence}}, and {{c4::true emergencies}}—allow {{c5::warrantless searches or seizures}} when delay risks harm or loss.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Administrative and Public School Searches
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 014. Administrative and Public School Searches
cards.front: Administrative and Public School Searches
cards.backPlain: 1. Administrative searches 1.1 Government agencies may conduct routine searches or inspections of highly regulated businesses or industries. 1.2 For example: Building code inspections, inspections for food safety, and airline passenger searches. 1.3 A warrant is required for inspections of private residences or commercial buildings. 1.4 Administrative warrants require less particularity than standard criminal warrants. 1.5 A general and neutral enforcement plan for the searches will suffice to validate the warrant. 2. Public school searches 2.1 To conduct a search, school officials must have reasonable grounds to believe the search is necessary. 2.2 This is a less burdensome standard than probable cause. 2.3 A public school search is reasonable if: 2.3.1 The search offers a moderate chance of finding evidence of wrongdoing. 2.3.2 The procedure for searching is reasonably related to the objectives of the search. 2.3.3 The search is not excessively intrusive in light of the student’s age, sex, and the nature of the infraction. 2.4 Drug tests: Random urinalysis is permissible for public school students participating in extracurricular activities.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the rules governing administrative searches and public school searches, including the standards and warrant requirements?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Administrative searches}} 1.1 Government agencies may conduct routine searches or inspections of {{c2::highly regulated businesses or industries}}. 1.2 For example: {{c3::building code inspections}}, {{c4::inspections for food safety}}, and {{c5::airline passenger searches}}. 1.3 A {{c6::warrant}} is required for inspections of {{c7::private residences or commercial buildings}}. 1.4 Administrative warrants require {{c8::less particularity}} than standard criminal warrants. 1.5 A {{c9::general and neutral enforcement plan}} for the searches will suffice to validate the warrant. 2. {{c10::Public school searches}} 2.1 To conduct a search, school officials must have {{c11::reasonable grounds}} to believe the search is necessary. 2.2 This is a {{c12::less burdensome standard than probable cause}}. 2.3 A public school search is reasonable if: 2.3.1 The search offers a {{c13::moderate chance}} of finding evidence of wrongdoing. 2.3.2 The procedure for searching is {{c14::reasonably related to the objectives}} of the search. 2.3.3 The search is {{c15::not excessively intrusive}} in light of the student’s age, sex, and the nature of the infraction. 2.4 Drug tests: {{c16::Random urinalysis}} is permissible for public school students participating in {{c17::extracurricular activities}}.
cards.easyContent: Administrative agencies may conduct routine inspections of highly regulated industries, often with less particularity than criminal warrants, while public school officials may search students based on reasonable grounds rather than probable cause.
cards.mediumContent: Administrative searches allow government agencies to perform routine inspections of closely regulated businesses, often under general, neutral enforcement plans, though a warrant is still required for private residences or commercial buildings and needs less particularity than a criminal warrant. In public schools, officials may search students when they have reasonable grounds, a standard lower than probable cause, and the search must have a moderate chance of finding evidence, be reasonably related to its objectives, and not be excessively intrusive given the student and the infraction; random drug testing of students in extracurriculars is permitted.
cards.hardContent: Administrative searches permit government agencies to routinely inspect highly regulated businesses or industries—such as through building code, food safety, or airline passenger inspections—often under a general and neutral enforcement plan. When private residences or commercial buildings are inspected, an administrative warrant is required but may be supported by less particularity than a typical criminal warrant. For public school searches, officials need only reasonable grounds, not probable cause, to believe a search is necessary. A school search is reasonable when it presents a moderate chance of uncovering wrongdoing, the search procedures are reasonably related to the search’s objectives, and the search is not excessively intrusive in light of the student’s age, sex, and the nature of the suspected infraction. Random urinalysis drug testing is permissible for students participating in extracurricular activities.
cards.mnemonic: Schools: MOR—Moderate chance, Objectives-related, not unReasonably intrusive.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Border and Immigration Searches
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 015. Border and Immigration Searches
cards.front: Border and Immigration Searches
cards.backPlain: 1. Border searches: 1.1 At borders, officials may conduct routine searches of persons and their effects (including vehicles) without a warrant, probable cause, or reasonable suspicion. 1.2 The "border" is any place where one can arrive in the U.S. from a foreign country (e.g., there is a border at Denver International Airport). 2. Detentions: 2.1 Reasonable suspicion is required. 2.2 Officials may detain a traveler at the border if they have reasonable suspicion she is smuggling contraband. 3. International mail: 3.1 Officials can open and inspect international mail if they have reasonable suspicion it contains contraband. 4. Immigration: 4.1 Officials may raid a business to determine the citizenship status of its employees.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the Fourth Amendment rules for border searches, border detentions, international mail inspections, and immigration workplace raids?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Border searches}}: 1.1 At borders, officials may conduct {{c2::routine searches of persons and their effects (including vehicles)}} without a {{c3::warrant}}, {{c4::probable cause}}, or {{c5::reasonable suspicion}}. 1.2 The "{{c6::border}}" is any place where one can arrive in the U.S. from a foreign country (e.g., there is a border at Denver International Airport). 2. {{c7::Detentions}}: 2.1 {{c8::Reasonable suspicion}} is required. 2.2 Officials may detain a traveler at the border if they have reasonable suspicion she is {{c9::smuggling contraband}}. 3. {{c10::International mail}}: 3.1 Officials can open and inspect international mail if they have reasonable suspicion it contains {{c11::contraband}}. 4. {{c12::Immigration}}: 4.1 Officials may {{c13::raid a business to determine the citizenship status of its employees}}.
cards.easyContent: Routine searches at the border (including airports) can be done without a warrant, probable cause, or reasonable suspicion, but detentions and opening international mail require reasonable suspicion.
cards.mediumContent: Officials may conduct routine searches of persons and effects at the border, broadly defined as any point of entry into the U.S., without a warrant, probable cause, or reasonable suspicion. However, detaining a traveler or opening international mail requires reasonable suspicion, and immigration officials may raid workplaces to determine employees’ citizenship status.
cards.hardContent: Border searches: At borders, officials may conduct routine searches of persons and their effects, including vehicles, without a warrant, probable cause, or reasonable suspicion. The border includes any place where one can arrive in the U.S. from a foreign country (e.g., ports of entry and international airports such as Denver International Airport). Detentions: Reasonable suspicion is required to detain a traveler at the border, such as when officials suspect she is smuggling contraband. International mail: Officials may open and inspect international mail if they have reasonable suspicion it contains contraband. Immigration: Officials may raid a business to determine the citizenship status of its employees.
cards.mnemonic: Border = Broad searches; RS for detentions and foreign mail.
cards.clozeLite: At the {{c1::border}}, officials may do {{c2::routine searches}} with {{c3::no warrant, PC, or RS}}, but {{c4::detaining travelers}} or {{c5::opening international mail}} needs {{c6::reasonable suspicion}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Electronic Surveillance
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 016. Electronic Surveillance
cards.front: Electronic Surveillance
cards.backPlain: Wiretapping and Eavesdropping: 1. General rule: Electronic surveillance (e.g., wiretapping, eavesdropping) that violates a reasonable expectation of privacy constitutes a search under the Fourth Amendment and requires a warrant. 2. Warrant requirements for electronic surveillance: 2.1 Probable cause that a specific crime is being or has been committed. 2.2 The warrant must name the suspects subject to surveillance. 2.3 The warrant must describe with particularity the subject of conversations that can be surveilled. 2.4 Surveillance must be limited to short periods of time. 2.5 Surveillance must terminate when the desired information is obtained and must be turned over to the court. 3. Assumption of risk / one-party consent: 3.1 All speakers assume the risk that the person to whom they are speaking is wired and/or recording the conversation; therefore, police do not need a warrant if they get someone to wear a wire and talk to the suspect. 3.2 A speaker who makes no attempt to keep a conversation private has no reasonable expectation of privacy.

cards.easyContent: Electronic surveillance that invades a reasonable expectation of privacy is a Fourth Amendment search and generally requires a wiretap warrant, but no warrant is needed when an informant wearing a wire is a party to the conversation.
cards.mediumContent: Wiretapping and similar electronic surveillance that intrudes on a reasonable expectation of privacy is a Fourth Amendment search and requires a warrant. The warrant needs probable cause that a specific crime has been or is being committed, must name the suspects, describe the conversations to be intercepted with particularity, be limited in time, and end once the desired information is obtained, with recordings turned over to the court. However, speakers assume the risk that a conversational partner is wired, so police may use a wired informant without a warrant, and there is no reasonable expectation of privacy in conversations a speaker does not try to keep private.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Exclusionary Rule
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 017. Exclusionary Rule
cards.front: Exclusionary Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: The exclusionary rule prohibits the introduction of evidence obtained in violation of the defendant's constitutional rights in a criminal trial. 2. "Fruit of the poisonous tree" doctrine: 2.1 Evidence derived or obtained from illegal government conduct is excludable against the defendant. 2.2 This arises when illegal police action leads to additional evidence. 3. Exceptions (illegally obtained evidence is admissible if the government can break the causal chain between the illegal government conduct and the seized evidence; common ways to break the chain): 3.1 Independent source: The government had an independent source for obtaining the evidence, i.e., independent from the original illegality. 3.2 Inevitable discovery: The government would have discovered the illegally derived evidence even without the illegal conduct. 3.3 Attenuation: The connection between the unlawful search or seizure and the challenged evidence is too remote and attenuated; this includes intervening acts of free will by the defendant (e.g., after an initial illegality, the defendant consciously leads police to the evidence). 4. Remedy for exclusionary rule violations: 4.1 Harmless error review on appeal. 4.2 For admission of illegally seized evidence to be upheld on appeal, the government must show that the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the exclusionary rule (and the fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine) bar, and what are the main exceptions and appellate remedy?

cards.easyContent: The exclusionary rule and fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine bar evidence obtained in violation of the defendant’s constitutional rights, unless the government can show an independent source, inevitable discovery, or attenuation, and appellate courts apply harmless error review.
cards.mediumContent: The exclusionary rule prohibits the introduction of evidence obtained in violation of the defendant’s constitutional rights. Under the fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine, derivative evidence obtained as a result of illegal government conduct is also generally excluded. However, the government can avoid exclusion by breaking the causal chain through an independent source, inevitable discovery, or attenuation based on remoteness or intervening acts of free will by the defendant. On appeal, admission of illegally seized evidence is subject to harmless error review; the government must show the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.
cards.hardContent: The exclusionary rule bars the introduction at a criminal trial of evidence obtained in violation of the defendant’s constitutional rights. The "fruit of the poisonous tree" doctrine extends this bar to evidence derived from illegal government conduct, such as additional evidence discovered as a result of an unlawful search or seizure. The government can admit such evidence if it shows the causal chain is broken, most commonly through: (1) an independent source, where the evidence is obtained from a source independent of the original illegality; (2) inevitable discovery, where the evidence would have been discovered even without the illegal conduct; or (3) attenuation, where the link between the unlawful action and the evidence is too remote or interrupted by intervening acts of free will by the defendant (e.g., the defendant later voluntarily leads police to the evidence). On appeal, violations of the exclusionary rule are reviewed for harmless error; the conviction will be upheld if the government proves beyond a reasonable doubt that admission of the illegally seized evidence was harmless.

cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::exclusionary rule}} and {{c2::fruit of the poisonous tree}} bar evidence from {{c3::constitutional violations}}, unless {{c4::independent source}}, {{c5::inevitable discovery}}, or {{c6::attenuation}} applies.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Limitations on the Exclusionary Rule
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 018. Limitations on the Exclusionary Rule
cards.front: Limitations on the Exclusionary Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: The exclusionary rule applies only to searches or seizures in violation of a federal statute or the U.S. Constitution. 2. The exclusionary rule does not apply to: 2.1 Grand jury proceedings, civil proceedings, parole hearings, or administrative cases. 2.2 Violations of the knock-and-announce rule in executing search warrants. 2.3 Evidence seized as a result of Miranda violations (although such evidence may be excluded under the Fifth Amendment on other grounds). 3. Excluded evidence and impeachment: 3.1 Confessions resulting from Miranda violations or illegally obtained evidence may be used to impeach the defendant's testimony at trial (but only the defendant's testimony). 4. Government good-faith defenses to the exclusionary rule (illegally obtained evidence will not be excluded if the government demonstrates that it relied in good faith on either): 4.1 A reasonably relied upon but defective search warrant. 4.2 A warrant obtained in good faith that is later found invalid, except in limited situations where reliance was unreasonable (e.g., the affidavit was obviously lacking in probable cause, the magistrate wholly abandoned the judicial role, or the warrant was facially deficient). 4.3 A judicial opinion or statute that was later changed or declared invalid.

cards.easyContent: The exclusionary rule only applies to violations of federal law or the U.S. Constitution, not to grand jury, civil, parole, or administrative proceedings, or to knock-and-announce violations, and good-faith reliance on a warrant, statute, or case law can prevent exclusion.
cards.mediumContent: The exclusionary rule applies only to searches or seizures that violate a federal statute or the U.S. Constitution, and does not apply in grand jury, civil, parole, or administrative proceedings, nor to violations of the knock-and-announce rule, or to derivative physical evidence from Miranda violations. Suppressed statements or evidence may still be used to impeach the defendant's own testimony. Additionally, the rule does not require exclusion when officers acted in objectively reasonable good-faith reliance on a defective warrant, or on a judicial opinion or statute later invalidated, unless that reliance itself was unreasonable.
cards.hardContent: The exclusionary rule is limited to searches or seizures that violate federal statutes or the U.S. Constitution. It does not apply in grand jury proceedings, civil cases, parole hearings, or administrative proceedings, and it does not apply to violations of the knock-and-announce rule during execution of a warrant. Physical evidence derived from statements obtained in violation of Miranda is generally admissible, even though the statements themselves may be suppressed. Suppressed confessions resulting from Miranda violations or illegally obtained evidence may nonetheless be used to impeach the defendant's testimony at trial, but only to impeach the defendant, not other witnesses. The government can also invoke the good-faith exception: illegally obtained evidence will not be excluded if officers reasonably relied in good faith on a search warrant that was later found defective or invalid, or on a judicial opinion or statute later changed or held unconstitutional, unless the reliance was itself unreasonable (such as when the affidavit obviously lacked probable cause, the magistrate abandoned the judicial role, or the warrant was facially deficient).

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fifth Amendment Privilege Against Compelled Self Incrimination
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 019. Fifth Amendment Privilege Against Compelled Self Incrimination
cards.front: Fifth Amendment Privilege Against Compelled Self Incrimination
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule: Any person in any proceeding (civil or criminal) may refuse to answer a question if her response might incriminate herself. The privilege is only available for compelled testimonial or communicative evidence. 1.1 Testimonial: verbal or otherwise communicative evidence. 1.2 Lineups and physical evidence: not testimonial. 1.3 Compelled: elicited or induced. 1.3.1 Evidence produced from the defendant's free will is not compelled (e.g., the defendant's existing diary is not compelled). 1.3.2 Lie detector tests, custodial interrogations, and similar procedures are compelled, and the Fifth Amendment privilege will apply. 2. Scope: The privilege applies to natural persons, not entities. 2.1 A legal entity (e.g., corporation, partnership) has no Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination. 3. Exceptions (the privilege does not apply if): 3.1 Grant of immunity: The government grants immunity from prosecution for self-incriminating testimony. 3.2 Incrimination is not possible: For example, the statute of limitations has run. 3.3 Extinguished by waiver: The defendant waives the privilege. 3.3.1 At trial, the prosecution cannot comment on the defendant's silence or failure to testify.
