cards.easyContent: The Fifth Amendment privilege lets a person in any proceeding refuse to give compelled testimonial evidence that could incriminate them, but it does not protect physical evidence or corporations, and it can be lost through immunity, lack of possible incrimination, or waiver.
cards.mediumContent: Any person, in civil or criminal proceedings, may invoke the Fifth Amendment privilege to refuse to answer questions where answers may be self-incriminating. The privilege protects only compelled testimonial or communicative evidence; physical characteristics and participation in lineups are not testimonial. Compulsion includes elicited or induced statements such as in custodial interrogation or lie detector tests, but not voluntary production of preexisting documents like a diary. The privilege is personal to natural persons and does not extend to corporations or partnerships. It does not apply once the government grants immunity, where no real risk of incrimination remains (e.g., statute of limitations has run), or where the defendant has waived the privilege; and the prosecution may not comment on the defendant’s silence at trial.
cards.hardContent: The Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination allows any person in any proceeding, civil or criminal, to refuse to answer questions if the response might incriminate her. The privilege is limited to compelled testimonial or communicative evidence: testimonial evidence includes verbal or otherwise communicative statements, while lineups, fingerprints, and other physical evidence are not testimonial. Compulsion means statements elicited or induced by the government; evidence produced from the defendant’s free will, such as preexisting diaries, is not compelled, whereas lie detector tests, custodial interrogations, and similar elicitation techniques are, so the privilege applies. The privilege applies only to natural persons, not to legal entities such as corporations or partnerships. Exceptions arise where the government grants immunity for the self-incriminating testimony; where incrimination is no longer possible (for example, because the statute of limitations has run); or where the defendant waives the privilege. Even then, at trial the prosecution may not comment on the defendant’s decision to remain silent or failure to testify.
cards.mnemonic: For Fifth, remember C-TEN: Compelled, Testimonial Evidence, Natural person.
cards.clozeLite: The Fifth privilege protects only {{c1::compelled testimonial or communicative evidence}} by a {{c2::natural person}}, not {{c3::physical evidence}} or {{c4::corporations}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Miranda Rights
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 020. Miranda Rights
cards.front: Miranda Rights – Overview
cards.backPlain: Miranda governs when police must give warnings before questioning a suspect and what those warnings must include. 1. When Miranda applies 1.1. Miranda protections apply only when a suspect is both in custody and subjected to interrogation. 1.2. If required warnings are not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s statements are generally inadmissible, subject to narrow exceptions (such as the public-safety exception). 2. Core concepts 2.1. Custody is an objective, reasonable-person standard (whether a reasonable person would feel free to leave). 2.2. Interrogation is limited to police words or conduct reasonably likely to elicit incriminating responses; some questioning (e.g., routine booking) and volunteered statements fall outside Miranda. 3. Required warnings and constitutional basis 3.1. Before custodial interrogation, police must substantially advise the suspect of the right to remain silent, the use of statements against him in court, the right to counsel, and appointment of counsel if indigent. 3.2. Miranda is grounded in the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, not the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main components of Miranda rights: when they apply, what counts as custody and interrogation, what warnings are required, and what is the constitutional basis?
cards.cloze: Miranda governs when police must give warnings before questioning a suspect and what those warnings must include. 1. When Miranda applies 1.1. Miranda protections apply only when a suspect is both in {{c1::custody}} and subjected to {{c2::interrogation}}. 1.2. If required warnings are not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s statements are generally {{c3::inadmissible}}, subject to narrow exceptions (such as the {{c4::public-safety exception}}). 2. Core concepts 2.1. {{c1::Custody}} is an objective, reasonable-person standard (whether a reasonable person would feel free to leave). 2.2. {{c2::Interrogation}} is limited to police words or conduct reasonably likely to elicit {{c5::incriminating responses}}; some questioning (e.g., routine booking) and {{c6::volunteered statements}} fall outside Miranda. 3. Required warnings and constitutional basis 3.1. Before custodial interrogation, police must substantially advise the suspect of the {{c7::right to remain silent}}, that {{c8::anything said can be used against him in court}}, the {{c9::right to counsel}}, and {{c10::appointment of counsel if indigent}}. 3.2. Miranda is grounded in the {{c11::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}, not the {{c12::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}.
cards.easyContent: Miranda applies only to custodial interrogation and requires specific warnings about silence and counsel; un-warned statements are usually inadmissible, subject to narrow exceptions.
cards.mediumContent: Miranda protects suspects during custodial interrogation: when a reasonable person would not feel free to leave and police ask questions or act in ways likely to elicit incriminating responses. The doctrine defines custody and interrogation, carves out non-interrogation situations like booking questions and volunteered statements, and requires warnings about silence, use of statements, and counsel. Failure to warn generally bars use of resulting statements and is treated as a Fifth Amendment problem, not a Sixth Amendment one.
cards.hardContent: Miranda is a Fifth Amendment doctrine that requires police to advise suspects of specific rights before custodial interrogation. It applies only when there is both custody—an objective situation where a reasonable person would not feel free to leave—and interrogation—police words or conduct reasonably likely to elicit incriminating responses. Volunteered statements and routine administrative questions, like booking, are outside Miranda, and there is a narrow public-safety exception. When Miranda applies, officers must substantially inform the suspect of the right to remain silent, that anything said can be used against him in court, the right to counsel, and that counsel will be appointed if he cannot afford one. A failure to give these warnings implicates the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination rather than the Sixth Amendment right to counsel and generally renders resulting statements inadmissible in the prosecution’s case-in-chief.
cards.mnemonic: CIPW: Custody + Interrogation need Proper Warnings.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) when Miranda applies and general rule, (2) definitions of custody and interrogation plus non-interrogation situations and public-safety exception, (3) content of Miranda warnings and constitutional basis.
cards.clozeLite: Miranda applies only to {{c1::custodial interrogation}} and is a {{c2::Fifth Amendment}} doctrine requiring {{c3::warnings about silence and counsel}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Invoking and Waiving Miranda Rights
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 021. Invoking and Waiving Miranda Rights
cards.front: Invoking and Waiving Miranda Rights
cards.backPlain: Overview: Invoking and waiving Miranda rights; due process limits on confessions 1. Terminating custodial interrogation 1.1. An accused may terminate a custodial interrogation at any time by invoking: 1.1.1. The right to remain silent; or 1.1.2. The Fifth Amendment right to counsel. 2. Two main forms of invocation 2.1. Invoking the right to remain silent requires police to cease questioning, with limited ability to later reinitiate. 2.2. Invoking the Fifth Amendment right to counsel requires police to stop all questioning on any topic unless the accused reinitiates and validly waives. 3. Waiver of Miranda rights 3.1. Any waiver must be knowing and voluntary, proven by the prosecution by a preponderance of the evidence. 3.2. Waiver may be express or implied from conduct. 4. Independent Fourteenth Amendment voluntariness requirement 4.1. Regardless of Miranda, due process requires that confessions be voluntary under the totality of the circumstances (e.g., age, condition, education, and interrogation conditions).
cards.frontPrompt: How can a suspect terminate custodial interrogation by invoking Miranda rights, how can those rights be waived, and what independent due process limit applies to confessions?
cards.cloze: 1. Terminating custodial interrogation 1.1. An accused may terminate a {{c1::custodial interrogation}} at any time by invoking the {{c2::right to remain silent}} or the {{c3::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}}. 2. Waiver 2.1. Any waiver of Miranda rights must be {{c4::knowing}} and {{c5::voluntary}}, and may be {{c6::express or implied}}. 2.2. The {{c7::prosecution}} bears the burden of proving a valid waiver by a {{c8::preponderance of the evidence}}. 3. Due process voluntariness 3.1. Independently of Miranda, the {{c9::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that confessions be {{c10:voluntary}} under the {{c11::totality of the circumstances}}.
cards.easyContent: A suspect can stop custodial questioning by clearly invoking the right to remain silent or the Fifth Amendment right to counsel. Any later waiver of Miranda must be knowing and voluntary, and even apart from Miranda, due process requires that confessions be voluntary under the totality of the circumstances.
cards.mediumContent: A suspect can terminate custodial interrogation by clearly invoking either the right to remain silent or the Fifth Amendment right to counsel. Invoking silence limits when and how police may later resume; invoking counsel bars any further questioning unless the suspect reinitiates and validly waives. Any Miranda waiver must be knowing and voluntary, proven by the prosecution by a preponderance of the evidence, and may be express or implied. Separately, under the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause, confessions must be voluntary under a totality of the circumstances test.
cards.hardContent: Miranda gives a suspect in custodial interrogation the power to cut off questioning by invoking either the right to remain silent or the Fifth Amendment right to counsel. Invoking silence bars continued questioning subject to limited conditions on later resumption, while invoking counsel bars all questioning on any subject unless the suspect reinitiates communication and then validly waives Miranda. Any waiver must be knowing and voluntary, and may be express or implied; the prosecution must prove a valid waiver by a preponderance of the evidence. Independently, the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause requires that confessions be voluntary under the totality of the circumstances, considering factors such as the suspect’s age, mental and physical condition, education, and the duration, manner, and setting of the interrogation.
cards.mnemonic: S-C stops talking: Silence stops case; Counsel stops cops.

cards.clozeLite: A suspect can {{c1::terminate custodial interrogation}} by clearly invoking {{c2::silence or the Fifth Amendment right to counsel}}. Any Miranda {{c3::waiver must be knowing and voluntary}}, and the {{c4::prosecution must prove it by a preponderance}}. Separately, the {{c5::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires {{c6::voluntary confessions under the totality of the circumstances}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Double Jeopardy
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 022. Double Jeopardy
cards.front: Double Jeopardy – Overview
cards.backPlain: Double Jeopardy protects a defendant from being prosecuted more than once for the same offense after jeopardy has attached. Whether two prosecutions involve the "same offense" is determined under the same-elements (Blockburger) test, which asks whether each offense requires proof of an element the other does not. Lesser-included offenses merge into greater offenses once jeopardy attaches for the greater. There are limited exceptions that allow later prosecution for a greater offense when the greater offense was not complete or when new evidence arises (e.g., homicide after the victim later dies from an earlier battery). Jeopardy attaches at the start of trial proceedings: when the jury is impaneled and sworn in a jury trial, when the first witness is sworn in a bench trial, and when the court accepts a guilty plea; it does not attach merely from the filing of charges or grand jury proceedings.

cards.easyContent: Double Jeopardy bars a second prosecution for the same offense once jeopardy has attached, using the Blockburger same-elements test and recognizing merger of lesser-included offenses, limited exceptions for greater offenses (like homicide after later death), and specific attachment points (jury sworn, first witness sworn, plea accepted).
cards.mediumContent: Double Jeopardy prohibits reprosecution for the same offense once jeopardy attaches. The same-elements (Blockburger) test asks whether each offense requires proof of an element the other does not; lesser-included offenses merge into the greater once jeopardy attaches for the greater. Exceptions allow later prosecution for a greater offense when the greater was incomplete or when new evidence arises, such as homicide after a battery victim later dies. Jeopardy attaches when the jury is impaneled and sworn in a jury trial, when the first witness is sworn in a bench trial, and when a guilty plea is accepted, but not merely upon filing charges or grand jury proceedings.
cards.hardContent: Double Jeopardy bars a second prosecution for the same offense after jeopardy has attached. Under the same-elements (Blockburger) test, two offenses are different only if each requires proof of an element the other does not. Lesser-included offenses merge into the greater once jeopardy attaches for the greater offense, so later prosecution for the lesser is barred. Limited exceptions allow later prosecution for a greater offense when the greater was not complete at the time of the first trial or when new evidence arises—classic example: a defendant first tried for battery may later be tried for homicide if the victim subsequently dies from the battery. Jeopardy attaches at the start of trial proceedings: when the jury is impaneled and sworn in a jury trial, when the first witness is sworn in a bench trial, and when the court accepts a guilty plea. Jeopardy does not attach merely from the filing of charges or from grand jury proceedings.

cards.topic: Double Jeopardy
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 023. Double Jeopardy
cards.front: Double Jeopardy
cards.backPlain: 1. Exceptions permitting retrial after jeopardy attaches 1.1. Hung jury: If the jury cannot reach a verdict and is discharged, the defendant may be retried. 1.2. Mistrial due to manifest necessity: 1.2.1. The defendant may be retried if the trial is discontinued at the defendant's request on grounds not constituting an acquittal. 1.3. Retrial after a successful appeal by the defendant: 1.3.1. The defendant can be retried after a successful appeal unless the basis for reversal was insufficient evidence to support a guilty verdict. 1.4. Breach of a plea bargain agreement: If the defendant breaches a plea agreement, the prosecution may reinstate original charges and retry the defendant. 1.5. Separate sovereigns doctrine: 1.5.1. The defendant can be tried for the same conduct in different states. 1.5.2. The defendant can be tried for the same conduct in both federal and state court.

cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 024. Sixth Amendment Right to Counsel
cards.front: Sixth Amendment Right to Counsel
cards.backPlain: 1. Overview 1.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is a post-charge right that automatically attaches once formal charges have been filed and protects the defendant at all subsequent critical stages of the prosecution. 1.2. After attachment, police may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements about the charged offense outside the presence of counsel, and the right is offense-specific. 2. Relation to the Fifth Amendment and ineffective assistance 2.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel differs from the Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel, which must be invoked and is not offense-specific. 2.2. The Sixth Amendment also guarantees the right to effective assistance of counsel, which requires a showing of deficient performance and prejudice (a reasonable probability of a different outcome) to establish a violation on appeal.

cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel automatically attaches after formal charges, is offense-specific, and bars deliberate elicitation about the charged offense without counsel. It differs from the invoked, non–offense-specific Fifth Amendment Miranda right, and it includes a right to effective assistance requiring deficient performance plus prejudice.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel automatically attaches once formal charges are filed and applies at all subsequent critical stages; after attachment, police may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements about the charged offense without counsel, and the right is offense-specific. It contrasts with the Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel, which arises only if the suspect unambiguously invokes it during custodial interrogation and then bars questioning on any subject. The Sixth Amendment also guarantees effective assistance of counsel, requiring deficient performance and a reasonable probability of a different result but for that deficiency.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is a post-charge protection that automatically attaches upon the initiation of formal adversarial proceedings (e.g., indictment, information, or arraignment) and applies at all subsequent critical stages of the prosecution. Once attached, the government may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements about the charged offense outside the presence of counsel; the right is offense-specific and does not bar questioning about unrelated, uncharged crimes. In contrast, the Fifth Amendment right to counsel under Miranda arises only during custodial interrogation if the suspect unambiguously requests counsel; once invoked, it is not offense-specific and precludes questioning on any subject. Additionally, the Sixth Amendment guarantees effective assistance of counsel, and to show a violation on appeal the defendant must establish deficient performance and a reasonable probability that, but for that deficiency, the outcome of the proceeding would have been different.

cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 025. Pretrial Lineups and Showups
cards.front: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Overview
cards.backPlain: Pretrial lineups and showups raise two main constitutional issues: 1. Right to counsel - After formal charges, a suspect has a Sixth Amendment right to counsel at any post-charge, in-person lineup or showup. - This right does not apply to non-live identification procedures (e.g., photographic lineups, fingerprinting). 2. Due process - Regardless of charge status, a defendant can challenge any pretrial identification procedure on due process grounds if it is unnecessarily suggestive and creates a substantial likelihood of misidentification under the totality of the circumstances. - This is a demanding standard; the procedure must be extremely suggestive. 3. Remedy - If there is a violation of the right to counsel or due process in a pretrial identification, the defendant may seek to suppress the witness’s in-court identification. - Suppression is rare, because the government can often show an independent source for the in-court identification that overcomes the exclusionary rule.

cards.mediumContent: Pretrial lineups and showups involve: (1) a Sixth Amendment right to counsel at any post-charge, in-person lineup or showup (but not at non-live procedures like photo arrays), and (2) due process limits on unnecessarily suggestive procedures that create a substantial likelihood of misidentification under the totality of the circumstances. If a violation is found, the defendant can seek to suppress the witness’s in-court identification, although suppression is often avoided if the government proves an independent source.
cards.hardContent: Pretrial lineups and showups create two distinct issues. First, the Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches to any post-charge, in-person lineup or showup, but not to non-live procedures (such as photographic arrays or fingerprinting). Second, under due process, any pretrial identification—live or not—can be challenged if it is unnecessarily suggestive and creates a substantial likelihood of misidentification under the totality of the circumstances, a demanding standard requiring an extremely suggestive setup. The main remedy for a violation (right-to-counsel or due-process based) is a motion to suppress the witness’s in-court identification, but suppression is often avoided if the prosecution can establish an independent source for that identification.

cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 026. Grand Jury Proceedings and Indictments
cards.front: Grand Jury Proceedings and Indictments – Overview
cards.backPlain: In federal court, the Fifth Amendment generally requires a grand jury for felony prosecutions to determine whether there is sufficient probable cause to bring charges. The prosecutor presents evidence, and the grand jury votes on whether to issue an indictment. Grand jury proceedings are conducted in secret and operate under special procedural rules that sharply limit the suspect’s rights and modify the usual trial protections for witnesses. Within grand jury proceedings, witnesses still retain the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, may receive immunity in exchange for testimony, and the exclusionary rule does not apply—so an indictment can rest on evidence that would be inadmissible at trial. cards.easyContent: In federal felony cases, the Fifth Amendment generally requires a grand jury to decide whether there is probable cause to indict. Grand jury proceedings are secret, follow special procedural rules, and involve distinct Fifth Amendment principles about self-incrimination, immunity, and the inapplicability of the exclusionary rule.
cards.mediumContent: The Fifth Amendment generally requires a grand jury in federal felony prosecutions to determine whether there is probable cause to charge, based on evidence presented by the prosecutor, and to vote on an indictment. Grand jury proceedings occur in secret, with unique procedural rules that limit the suspect’s participation and modify witness protections. Within that framework, witnesses still retain the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, may receive immunity in exchange for testimony, and the exclusionary rule does not apply, allowing indictments based on evidence that would be inadmissible at trial.
cards.hardContent: In federal criminal procedure, the grand jury’s constitutional function is to serve as a buffer between the prosecutor and the accused by determining whether there is sufficient probable cause under the Fifth Amendment to justify an indictment in felony cases. The prosecutor presents evidence in secret proceedings, and the grand jury votes whether to indict. These proceedings operate under special rules: the suspect typically cannot attend or confront witnesses, and ordinary trial-based protections for witnesses are limited or altered. At the same time, witnesses retain the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination and may be compelled to testify through grants of immunity. The exclusionary rule does not apply at this stage, so even unlawfully obtained evidence can support an indictment. Together, these doctrines define the structure and constitutional boundaries of grand jury proceedings and indictments in federal court.

cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 027. Pretrial Hearings, Bail, and Right to a Speedy Trial
cards.front: Pretrial Hearings, Bail, and Right to a Speedy Trial
cards.backPlain: This card covers three related pretrial protections in criminal procedure: 1. Pretrial (preliminary) hearing for probable cause to detain: when a defendant is incarcerated or on bail without a prior probable cause determination, a preliminary hearing may be required and, if so, must be held promptly. 2. Bail: bail must not be excessive or arbitrary, denial of bail is subject to immediate review, and the government must justify denial by showing flight risk or danger to the community. 3. Right to a speedy trial: once a defendant is arrested or formally charged, the Sixth Amendment protects against unreasonable delay before trial, evaluated under a totality-of-circumstances test, with dismissal with prejudice as the remedy for a violation.

cards.easyContent: Three key pretrial protections: (1) a preliminary hearing may be required to determine probable cause to detain; (2) bail must not be excessive or arbitrarily denied, and denial must be justified; and (3) once arrested or charged, the defendant has a Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial, judged under a totality-of-circumstances test with dismissal as the remedy for violations.
cards.mediumContent: Pretrial protections include: (1) a preliminary hearing requirement when a defendant is in custody or on bail and there has been no prior finding of probable cause, which must occur promptly; (2) constitutional limits on bail, requiring that bail not exceed what is needed to secure appearance, forbidding arbitrary denial, allowing detention without bail but making refusals immediately appealable, and requiring proof of flight risk or danger to the community for denial; and (3) the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial, which attaches upon arrest or formal charge and is evaluated under a totality-of-circumstances standard, considering length and reason for delay, prejudice, and assertion of the right, with dismissal with prejudice as the remedy.
cards.hardContent: Three distinct pretrial protections operate together in criminal procedure: (1) A pretrial (preliminary) hearing can be required to determine whether there is probable cause to detain a defendant; it is required when the defendant is incarcerated or on bail and there has been no prior probable cause determination, and it must be held promptly. (2) Constitutional bail rules require that bail not be set higher than necessary to ensure the defendant’s appearance at trial. Detention without bail is permissible, but any refusal to grant bail is immediately appealable, and arbitrary denial of bail violates due process; to justify denial, the government must show either that the defendant poses a flight risk or that the defendant is a danger to the community. (3) The Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial protects a defendant from unreasonable delay between arrest or formal charging and trial. The right attaches upon arrest or formal charging, and whether it has been violated is evaluated under the totality of the circumstances, including the length and reason for delay, prejudice to the defendant, and whether the defendant asserted the right; the remedy for a violation is dismissal of the case with prejudice.

cards.topic: Plea Bargains
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 028. Plea Bargains
cards.front: Plea Bargains – Overview
cards.backPlain: Plea bargaining lets a defendant plead guilty in exchange for concessions, but doing so waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. A valid plea must be voluntary and intelligent and entered with an understanding of the charge, penalties, and rights being waived. Once a plea is validly accepted, it can be attacked on only narrow grounds (such as involuntariness, lack of jurisdiction, ineffective assistance of counsel, or prosecutorial breach). Plea agreements are treated under contract principles and are generally enforced against both parties, but the judge is not bound to accept or follow the bargain, and the prosecutor may threaten or file more serious charges supported by probable cause.

cards.mediumContent: In plea bargaining, the defendant pleads guilty in exchange for concessions and thereby waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. For the plea to be valid, the court must ensure it is voluntary and intelligent and that the defendant understands the nature and elements of the charge, the maximum and any mandatory penalty, the right to plead not guilty, and that a jury trial right is being waived. Once accepted as valid, the plea can be disturbed only for involuntariness, lack of jurisdiction, ineffective assistance, or prosecutorial breach. Plea agreements are interpreted under contract law, generally binding both sides, but the judge need not accept or follow them, and the prosecutor may threaten or bring more serious charges supported by probable cause.
cards.hardContent: Plea bargaining allows a defendant to plead guilty in exchange for concessions (e.g., reduced charges or sentencing recommendations), but this waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. The court must determine that the plea is voluntary and intelligently made and must ensure that the defendant understands: (1) the nature and critical elements of the charge, (2) the maximum authorized penalty and any mandatory sentence, (3) the right to plead not guilty, and (4) that entering the plea waives the right to a jury trial. Once a plea is validly accepted, appellate courts will disturb it only on limited grounds: if the plea was involuntary (e.g., due to misunderstanding), if the court lacked jurisdiction, if counsel was ineffective, or if the prosecutor failed to honor the bargain. Plea agreements are analyzed under contract principles and generally enforced against both parties, but the judge is not required to accept or follow the agreement. A prosecutor may threaten and, if necessary, follow through with more serious charges if the defendant refuses the plea, as long as there is probable cause for the enhanced charges.

cards.topic: Disclosure of Exculpatory Information
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 029. Disclosure of Exculpatory Information
cards.front: Disclosure of Exculpatory Information
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 The government has a duty to disclose material exculpatory evidence to the defendant. 1.2 Failure to disclose violates due process, whether intentional or not, and is grounds for reversing a conviction if the standard for materiality is met. 2. Establishing a violation 2.1 The defendant must show that the undisclosed evidence impeaches or is exculpatory. 2.2 The evidence is favorable to the defendant. 2.3 Prejudice has resulted: prejudice will be found if there is a reasonable probability that the result of the case would have been different if the undisclosed evidence had been presented at trial. 3. Applicability of duty to disclose 3.1 The duty applies to evidence relevant to the prosecution's case in chief and to evidence held by police and other investigators acting on the government's behalf. 3.2 The duty does not apply to post-conviction proceedings.

cards.mediumContent: The government has a due process duty to disclose material exculpatory and impeaching evidence favorable to the defendant. A Brady violation is established when the undisclosed evidence is favorable and there is a reasonable probability that, had it been disclosed, the outcome of the trial would have been different.
cards.hardContent: Due process requires the prosecution to disclose to the defense any material exculpatory or impeaching evidence in its possession or in the possession of police and other investigators acting on the government’s behalf. A violation occurs regardless of the prosecutor’s good or bad faith when the defendant shows that the suppressed evidence is favorable (either exculpatory or impeaching) and that prejudice resulted—meaning there is a reasonable probability that disclosure would have led to a different outcome at trial. This duty applies to evidence relevant to the prosecution’s case in chief but does not extend to post-conviction proceedings.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Right to a Jury Trial and Jury Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 030. Right to a Jury Trial and Jury Requirements
cards.front: Right to a Jury Trial and Jury Requirements
cards.backPlain: Sixth Amendment jury-trial rights in criminal cases: 1. Core Sixth Amendment jury right and presence: - The Sixth Amendment guarantees a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions. - The defendant has a right to be present at all critical stages (e.g., jury selection). 2. When a jury is required (serious offense): - A jury trial is required when the potential term of imprisonment exceeds 6 months. 3. Basic jury requirements: - The jury must have at least 6 jurors. - For serious offenses, the verdict must be unanimous. 4. Jury pool and impartiality: - The jury pool (venire) must be a representative cross-section of the community, but the seated jury need not be. - The defendant is entitled to an impartial jury and may question jurors about relevant biases and seek to strike biased jurors for cause. 5. Peremptory challenges and equal protection: - Parties may exercise peremptory challenges, but they may not be used to exclude jurors on the basis of race or gender, which violates equal protection. 6. Judge-directed verdicts: - The judge may direct a verdict of acquittal but may not direct a verdict of guilt, because that would deny the defendant a jury determination of guilt.

cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment guarantees a jury trial in criminal prosecutions for serious offenses—those with potential imprisonment over 6 months. The defendant has a right to be present at all critical stages, such as jury selection. The jury must have at least six jurors, and for serious offenses the verdict must be unanimous. The jury pool (venire) must be a representative cross-section of the community, though the seated jury need not be. Parties may exercise peremptory challenges but may not use them to exclude jurors based on race or gender, which violates equal protection. A judge may direct a verdict of acquittal but may not direct a verdict of guilt.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment provides a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions. The defendant has a right to be present for all critical stages, including jury selection. A jury trial is required for a serious offense, defined as one for which the potential punishment exceeds six months’ imprisonment. The jury must consist of at least six jurors, and for serious offenses the jury’s verdict must be unanimous. The jury pool (venire) must be drawn from a representative cross-section of the community, although the specific seated jury need not mirror the community. The defendant is entitled to an impartial jury and may question prospective jurors about relevant prejudices (such as racial bias or capital punishment views); jurors whose views would prevent or substantially impair performance of their duties may be struck for cause. Parties may exercise peremptory challenges for any reason, subject to the equal protection limitation that such challenges may not be used to exclude jurors on the basis of race or gender. Finally, the judge may not direct a verdict of guilt—because guilt must be determined by a jury—but may direct a verdict of acquittal.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Right to Confront Witnesses
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 031. Right to Confront Witnesses
cards.front: Right to Confront Witnesses – Overview
cards.backPlain: 1. Sixth Amendment confrontation right: 1.1 The Sixth Amendment gives the defendant the right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses. 2. Main components of the confrontation right: 2.1 Confrontation and in-person testimony: Adverse witnesses generally must testify in person and be subject to cross-examination, subject to limited public-policy exceptions and courtroom control (e.g., removal of a disruptive defendant). 2.2 Co-defendant confessions (Bruton rule): At a joint jury trial, a co-defendant’s confession implicating the defendant is generally inadmissible against the defendant, subject to specific exceptions (e.g., co-defendant testifies, severance, effective redaction, or rebuttal use). 2.3 Testimonial hearsay: Prior testimonial statements of an unavailable witness are admissible only if the defendant previously had an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Sixth Amendment right to confront witnesses protect, in terms of in-person testimony, co-defendant confessions (Bruton), and testimonial hearsay?
cards.cloze: 1. Sixth Amendment confrontation right: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} gives the defendant the right to {{c2::confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses}}. 2. Main components of the confrontation right: 2.1 {{c3::Confrontation and in-person testimony}}: Adverse witnesses generally must {{c4::testify in person}} and be subject to {{c5::cross-examination}}, subject to limited public-policy exceptions and courtroom control. 2.2 {{c6::Co-defendant confessions (Bruton rule)}}: At a {{c7::joint jury trial}}, a co-defendant’s confession implicating the defendant is generally inadmissible against the defendant, subject to specific exceptions. 2.3 {{c8::Testimonial hearsay}}: Prior testimonial statements of an {{c9::unavailable}} witness are admissible only if the defendant had a prior opportunity to {{c10::cross-examine}} the declarant.
cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause gives a defendant the right to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses. This includes rules about in-person testimony, limits on using co-defendant confessions at joint jury trials (Bruton), and limits on using prior testimonial statements of unavailable witnesses unless there was a prior chance to cross-examine.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment gives the defendant a confrontation right that has three main components: (1) a general right to have adverse witnesses testify in person and be subject to cross-examination, with limited exceptions when important public policy and reliability justify alternative procedures and with allowances for removing disruptive defendants; (2) the Bruton rule, which restricts the use of a co-defendant’s confession implicating the defendant at a joint jury trial, subject to exceptions such as co-defendant testimony with cross, severance, effective redaction, or rebuttal-only use; and (3) a restriction on using prior testimonial statements of unavailable witnesses unless the defendant previously had an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause entitles a criminal defendant to confront and cross-examine adverse witnesses. This right operates through three key doctrines: (1) confrontation and in-person testimony, which generally requires adverse witnesses to appear in court and be subject to cross-examination, though in-person confrontation can be dispensed with when necessary to advance an important public policy and the reliability of the testimony is otherwise assured, and a disruptive defendant may be removed from the courtroom; (2) the Bruton rule, under which a co-defendant’s confession implicating the defendant is inadmissible against the defendant at a joint jury trial, with specific exceptions where confrontation concerns are satisfied or mitigated; and (3) the testimonial-hearsay rule, which bars admission of prior testimonial statements by an unavailable witness unless the defendant had a prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant when the statement was made.
cards.mnemonic: Confrontation ABC: Adverse in-person, Bruton confessions, prior testimonial Cross needed.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) confrontation and in-person testimony; (2) Bruton rule and its exceptions; (3) testimonial hearsay and prior opportunity for cross-examination.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Eighth Amendment, Cruel and Unusual Punishment, and the Death Penal ty
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 032. Eighth Amendment, Cruel and Unusual Punishment, and the Death Penal ty
cards.front: Eighth Amendment, Cruel and Unusual Punishment, and the Death Penal ty
cards.backPlain: The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, including punishments that are grossly disproportionate to the offense. The death penalty is not per se unconstitutional, but its use is strictly limited. First, the Eighth Amendment requires that the death penalty be imposed only under procedures and statutes that meet certain safeguards: the victim must die as a result of the defendant’s crime, the statute cannot be unconstitutionally vague, the sentencer must be allowed to consider mitigating circumstances, and at least one statutory aggravating circumstance must support the death sentence. Second, the Eighth Amendment imposes categorical limitations on who may receive the death penalty: it cannot be imposed on defendants who were under 18 at the time of the offense, who are mentally disabled, or who are insane at the time of execution. In felony-murder cases, the death penalty is limited to major participants who acted with depraved indifference to human life. In addition, life without parole is impermissible for juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes.
cards.frontPrompt: Overall, how does the Eighth Amendment regulate cruel and unusual punishment and the use of the death penalty, including key requirements and categorical limits?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::Eighth Amendment}} prohibits {{c2::cruel and unusual punishment}}, including punishments that are {{c3::grossly disproportionate to the offense}}. The {{c4::death penalty}} is not per se unconstitutional, but its use is strictly limited by {{c5::procedural safeguards}} and {{c6::categorical exclusions}} (e.g., certain classes of defendants and certain offenses, such as non-homicide crimes by juveniles, for which life without parole is impermissible).
cards.easyContent: The Eighth Amendment bans cruel and unusual punishment, including grossly disproportionate sentences, and allows the death penalty only under strict procedural safeguards and categorical limits on who can receive it.
cards.mediumContent: The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, including disproportionate sentences. The death penalty is permitted but only when imposed under valid procedures (victim dies, statute is not vague, sentencer can consider mitigation, and at least one statutory aggravating factor supports death) and is categorically barred for certain offenders (juveniles under 18 at the time of the crime, the mentally disabled, and the insane at execution) and limited in felony-murder cases to major participants who acted with depraved indifference. Life without parole is also barred for juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes.
cards.hardContent: The Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment includes a proportionality principle and strict regulation of capital punishment. Punishment must not be grossly disproportionate to the offense, and life without parole may not be imposed on juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes. The death penalty itself is not per se unconstitutional, but it may only be imposed under valid statutes and procedures (including a non-vague statute, consideration of mitigating evidence, and at least one statutory aggravating factor) and is categorically unavailable for certain offenders and in certain circumstances, such as juveniles under 18 at the time of the crime, the mentally disabled, and the insane at the time of execution, as well as most minor participants in felony murder. These rules together define the modern Eighth Amendment framework for cruel and unusual punishment and capital sentencing.
cards.mnemonic: NO KIDS, NO CRAZY, NO IMPAIRED: death barred for juveniles, insane, mentally disabled.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) general Eighth Amendment and disproportionality; (2) procedural/statutory requirements for death penalty; (3) categorical exclusions and limitations on who can receive death and on LWOP for juveniles.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Eighth Amendment}} bars {{c2::cruel and unusual punishment}}, requires {{c3::non-vague death statutes with aggravators and mitigation}}, and categorically excludes {{c4::juveniles, mentally disabled, and insane at execution}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Burden of Proof and Sufficiency of Evidence
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 033. Burden of Proof and Sufficiency of Evidence
cards.front: Burden of Proof and Sufficiency of Evidence
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule and burden of proof: 1.1 The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause requires that the government prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt in all criminal cases. 1.2 The prosecution must prove all elements of every crime charged beyond a reasonable doubt. 1.3 The burden of proof on the elements is always on the prosecution and cannot be shifted to the defendant; a state law that shifts the burden to the defendant to prove he is not guilty is unconstitutional. 1.4 The defendant has the burden of proving any affirmative defenses he raises. 1.5 State laws may vary on what burden the defendant must satisfy for affirmative defenses; there is no single constitutional requirement. 1.6 A conviction is valid so long as a rational judge or jury, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, could find the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. 2. Jury instructions and mandatory presumptions: 2.1 A judge cannot give mandatory jury instructions that effectively direct a finding on an element of a charged crime. 2.2 Requiring the jury to apply a mandatory presumption regarding an element of the charged crime violates due process. 2.3 For example, in a murder trial where a body was never found, the court cannot instruct the jury to presume that a missing person is dead.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Due Process Clause, what is the prosecution’s burden of proof in criminal cases, how do affirmative defenses work, and why are mandatory presumptions in jury instructions unconstitutional?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule and burden of proof: 1.1 The {{c1::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that the government prove guilt {{c2::beyond a reasonable doubt}} in all criminal cases. 1.2 The prosecution must prove {{c3::all elements of every crime charged}} beyond a reasonable doubt. 1.3 The burden of proof on the elements is always on the {{c4::prosecution}} and cannot be shifted to the defendant; a state law that shifts the burden to the defendant to prove he is not guilty is {{c5::unconstitutional}}. 1.4 The defendant has the burden of proving any {{c6::affirmative defenses}} he raises. 1.5 State laws may vary on what {{c7::burden}} the defendant must satisfy for affirmative defenses; there is no single constitutional requirement. 1.6 A conviction is valid so long as a {{c8::rational judge or jury}}, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, could find the defendant {{c9::guilty beyond a reasonable doubt}}. 2. Jury instructions and mandatory presumptions: 2.1 A judge cannot give {{c10::mandatory jury instructions}} that effectively direct a finding on an {{c11::element}} of a charged crime. 2.2 Requiring the jury to apply a {{c12::mandatory presumption}} regarding an element of the charged crime violates {{c13::due process}}. 2.3 For example, in a murder trial where a body was never found, the court cannot instruct the jury to {{c14::presume that a missing person is dead}}.
cards.easyContent: Due process requires the prosecution to prove every element of a criminal offense beyond a reasonable doubt, while defendants bear the burden on affirmative defenses, and courts cannot use mandatory presumptions to direct findings on elements.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause, the government must prove the defendant’s guilt beyond a reasonable doubt in all criminal cases, and this standard applies to every element of every charged crime. The prosecution always bears this burden and it cannot be shifted to the defendant. The defendant, however, bears the burden of proving any affirmative defenses, with the specific burden level determined by state law. A conviction is upheld if a rational fact-finder, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, could find guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Judges may not give mandatory jury instructions or require mandatory presumptions that effectively direct the jury to find an element established, as this violates due process.
cards.hardContent: The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause requires that the prosecution prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt in all criminal cases. This standard applies to each and every element of the offense. The burden of proof on the elements rests exclusively with the prosecution and may not be shifted to the defendant; a statute that places on the defendant the burden to prove he is not guilty is unconstitutional. By contrast, the defendant bears the burden of proving any affirmative defenses, and the level of that burden (e.g., preponderance of the evidence, clear and convincing) is largely left to state law. Appellate review of sufficiency asks whether, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, any rational judge or jury could have found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. In instructing the jury, a judge may not give mandatory instructions or establish mandatory presumptions that effectively direct the jury to find a particular element established, because this violates due process—for example, instructing the jury in a murder case with no body that it must presume a missing person is dead.
cards.mnemonic: BRD on elements, D on defenses: State proves elements; Defendant proves defenses.
cards.clozeLite: Due process requires the {{c1::prosecution}} to prove {{c2::every element}} {{c3::beyond a reasonable doubt}}, while {{c4::defendants}} bear the burden on {{c5::affirmative defenses}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 004-1. Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct
cards.front: Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Fourth Amendment apply to a search or seizure in terms of government conduct, private conduct, and private actors working with the government?
cards.backPlain: Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct 1. Government Conduct Requirement 1.1 The Fourth Amendment applies only to government conduct. 1.2 Government conduct includes actions by: (a) Police officers and other law enforcement officials; (b) Other government agents acting in an investigative or enforcement capacity. 2. Purely Private Conduct 2.1 The Fourth Amendment does NOT protect against purely private conduct. 2.2 A search or seizure by a purely private individual, acting on their own initiative, is not subject to Fourth Amendment limits. 3. Authorized Private Conduct Treated as Government Conduct 3.1 Private persons acting at the direction of government agents are treated as government actors for Fourth Amendment purposes. 3.2 If the government instigates, encourages, or directs the private actor’s search or seizure, the conduct is attributable to the government and the Fourth Amendment applies.
cards.cloze: Fourth Amendment Applicability – Government vs. Private Conduct 1. {{c1::Government conduct requirement}} 1.1 The Fourth Amendment applies only to {{c2::government conduct}}. 1.2 Government conduct includes actions by {{c3::police and other law enforcement officials}} and by {{c4::other government agents}} acting in an investigative or enforcement capacity. 2. {{c5::Purely private conduct}} 2.1 The Fourth Amendment does {{c6::NOT}} protect against {{c7::purely private conduct}}. 2.2 A search or seizure by a private individual acting on their own initiative is {{c8::not subject to Fourth Amendment limits}}. 3. {{c9::Authorized private conduct as government action}} 3.1 {{c10::Private persons acting at the direction of government agents}} are treated as {{c11::government actors}}. 3.2 If the government {{c12::instigates, encourages, or directs}} the private actor’s search or seizure, the conduct is {{c13::attributable to the government}} and the Fourth Amendment applies.
cards.easyContent: The Fourth Amendment applies only to government conduct. It does not regulate purely private searches. But if private people act at the direction of the police or other government agents, their conduct counts as government action and triggers Fourth Amendment protections.
cards.mediumContent: To see if the Fourth Amendment applies, first ask whether the search or seizure involves government conduct, such as police or other government agents. The Amendment does not cover purely private conduct, where a private individual acts entirely on their own. However, if a private person acts at the direction or under the control of government agents—because the government instigated, encouraged, or directed the search—then that conduct is treated as government action.
cards.hardContent: The Fourth Amendment’s protections against unreasonable searches and seizures are triggered only by government conduct. This includes actions by police, other law enforcement officers, and government officials acting in an investigative or enforcement capacity. In contrast, purely private conduct—where an individual searches or seizes property on their own initiative, without governmental direction or involvement—falls outside the Fourth Amendment. However, when private individuals act at the direction of, or in coordination with, government agents (for example, at the request, encouragement, or specific direction of police), their conduct is attributed to the government, and the Fourth Amendment’s constraints apply.
cards.mnemonic: Fourth needs GAP: Government Action, not Private.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} applies only to {{c2::government conduct}}, not {{c3::purely private searches}}, unless {{c4::private actors act at government direction}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 004-2. Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy
cards.front: Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy
cards.frontPrompt: What is standing to challenge a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment, and how does the reasonable expectation of privacy requirement work?
cards.backPlain: Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy 1. Standing Requirement 1.1 A defendant may challenge a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment only if they have standing. 1.2 Standing in this context means the defendant’s own Fourth Amendment rights were violated. 2. Reasonable Expectation of Privacy (REP) 2.1 The core test for standing is whether the defendant had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place searched or the item seized. 2.2 The expectation must be: (a) Subjectively held by the defendant; and (b) One that society is prepared to recognize as objectively reasonable. 3. Application to Searches 3.1 If the defendant lacks a reasonable expectation of privacy in the thing or place searched, they cannot invoke the Fourth Amendment, even if the search was unreasonable as to someone else. 3.2 The validity of the search is evaluated only as to persons whose own reasonable expectation of privacy was infringed.
cards.cloze: Fourth Amendment Standing – Reasonable Expectation of Privacy 1. {{c1::Standing requirement}} 1.1 A defendant may challenge a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment only if {{c2::they have standing}}. 1.2 Standing means the {{c3::defendant’s own}} Fourth Amendment rights were violated. 2. {{c4::Reasonable Expectation of Privacy (REP)}} 2.1 The core test for standing is whether the defendant had a {{c5::reasonable expectation of privacy}} in the place searched or item seized. 2.2 The expectation must be both: (a) {{c6::Subjectively}} held by the defendant; and (b) {{c7::Objectively reasonable}}—one society is prepared to recognize. 3. {{c8::Application}} 3.1 If the defendant lacks a reasonable expectation of privacy in the thing or place searched, they {{c9::cannot invoke the Fourth Amendment}}, even if the search was unreasonable as to someone else. 3.2 The search is assessed only for {{c10::persons whose own REP was infringed}}.
cards.easyContent: To challenge a search under the Fourth Amendment, the defendant needs standing, which means their own reasonable expectation of privacy was violated. They must personally have a reasonable (subjective and objectively recognized) expectation of privacy in the place or item searched.
cards.mediumContent: A defendant cannot object to a search or seizure under the Fourth Amendment unless they have standing. Standing requires that their own Fourth Amendment rights were violated, which is shown by a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place or item searched. The expectation must be subjectively held by the defendant and objectively reasonable in society’s eyes. If the defendant lacks this reasonable expectation of privacy, they cannot challenge the search even if it was otherwise unlawful.
cards.hardContent: Standing in the Fourth Amendment context means that only someone whose own rights were infringed may challenge a search or seizure. The doctrinal test is whether the defendant had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the place searched or the item seized. This requires both a subjective expectation of privacy and one that society is prepared to recognize as objectively reasonable. If the defendant lacks such an expectation in the area or object searched, they cannot invoke the exclusionary rule, regardless of whether the search might have been unreasonable as to another person. Courts therefore focus on whose reasonable expectation of privacy was actually invaded.
cards.mnemonic: REP or RIP: without a Reasonable Expectation of Privacy, your challenge dies.
cards.clozeLite: Fourth Amendment {{c1::standing}} requires that the {{c2::defendant's own}} {{c3::reasonable expectation of privacy}} was violated—both {{c4::subjective}} and {{c5::objectively reasonable}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 004-3. Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions
cards.front: Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general Fourth Amendment warrant requirement for searches and seizures, and what are the main exceptions you should analyze if no valid warrant exists?
cards.backPlain: Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions 1. General Reasonableness Rule 1.1 Government searches and seizures of evidence must be reasonable under the Fourth Amendment. 1.2 Reasonableness generally requires a valid search warrant supported by probable cause and issued by a neutral and detached magistrate (details covered elsewhere in the outline). 2. Warrant vs. Exceptions Framework 2.1 First ask: Was there a valid search warrant? 2.2 If there was a valid warrant, the search is generally reasonable (subject to scope and execution requirements). 2.3 If there was no valid warrant, the search is presumed unreasonable unless it falls within a recognized exception to the warrant requirement. 3. Main Warrant Exceptions to Analyze 3.1 Search incident to arrest. 3.2 Plain view search. 3.3 Automobile search. 3.4 Valid consent to search. 3.5 Exigent circumstances. 3.6 Stop and frisk. 4. Mnemonic 4.1 Use "SPACE-S" to remember the main exceptions: Search incident to arrest, Plain view, Automobile, Consent, Exigent circumstances, Stop and frisk.
cards.cloze: Fourth Amendment – Warrant Requirement and Main Exceptions 1. {{c1::General reasonableness rule}} 1.1 Government searches and seizures must be {{c2::reasonable}} under the {{c3::Fourth Amendment}}. 1.2 Reasonableness generally requires a valid {{c4::search warrant}}. 2. {{c5::Warrant vs. exceptions framework}} 2.1 First ask: Was there a {{c6::valid search warrant}}? 2.2 If yes, the search is generally {{c7::reasonable}}, subject to scope and execution. 2.3 If there is no valid warrant, the search is presumed {{c8::unreasonable}} unless it falls within a recognized {{c9::exception to the warrant requirement}}. 3. {{c10::Main warrant exceptions}} ("SPACE-S") 3.1 {{c11::Search incident to arrest}}. 3.2 {{c12::Plain view}} search. 3.3 {{c13::Automobile}} search. 3.4 Valid {{c14::consent}} to search. 3.5 {{c15::Exigent circumstances}}. 3.6 {{c16::Stop and frisk}}.
cards.easyContent: Fourth Amendment searches and seizures must be reasonable. That usually means a valid warrant. If there is no valid warrant, the search is presumed unreasonable unless a main exception applies: Search incident to arrest, Plain view, Automobile, Consent, Exigent circumstances, or Stop and frisk ("SPACE-S").
cards.mediumContent: Under the Fourth Amendment, government searches and seizures must be reasonable. Reasonableness generally requires a valid search warrant. In analyzing a search, first ask whether there was a valid warrant; if so, the search is usually reasonable, subject to scope and execution limits. If there is no valid warrant, the search is presumed unreasonable unless it fits within an established exception: search incident to arrest, plain view, automobile search, valid consent, exigent circumstances, or stop and frisk, remembered by the mnemonic "SPACE-S."
cards.hardContent: The Fourth Amendment’s reasonableness requirement ordinarily demands a valid search warrant, supported by probable cause and issued by a neutral and detached magistrate, with proper description of the place to be searched and items to be seized. In practice, the analysis is a two-step inquiry: (1) Was there a valid search warrant? If yes, the search will typically be upheld, provided officers remained within the scope of the warrant and executed it properly. (2) If there was no valid warrant, the search is presumptively unreasonable. The government can overcome this presumption only by establishing that the search falls within a recognized exception to the warrant requirement. The primary exceptions to keep in mind at the framework level are: search incident to arrest, plain view, automobile search, valid consent, exigent circumstances (such as hot pursuit or risk of destruction of evidence), and stop and frisk. These are captured by the mnemonic "SPACE-S."
cards.mnemonic: SPACE-S: Search incident, Plain view, Auto, Consent, Exigent, Stop-frisk.
cards.clozeLite: If there is {{c1::no valid warrant}}, a Fourth Amendment search is {{c2::presumed unreasonable}} unless it fits {{c3::SPACE-S}}: {{c4::search incident}}, {{c5::plain view}}, {{c6::automobile/consent/exigent/stop-frisk}}.

cards.front: Reasonable Expectation of Privacy – Definition and Standing

Standing to challenge a government search or seizure requires that the defendant personally had a REOP, determined by the totality of the circumstances. 2.1. The question is whether the defendant’s expectation of privacy is one that society is prepared to recognize as reasonable under all the circumstances.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) under the Fourth Amendment, and how does it relate to standing to challenge a search?

The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} only applies if a person has a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} regarding the place or thing searched and/or the items seized. 2. {{c3::Standing}} to challenge a government search or seizure requires that the {{c4::defendant personally}} had a REOP, determined by the {{c5::totality of the circumstances}}. 2.1. cards.easyContent: The Fourth Amendment only applies if the person has a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in the place or thing searched, and the defendant has standing to object to the search only if they personally had that reasonable expectation, based on the totality of the circumstances.
cards.mediumContent: A reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) exists when the defendant both subjectively expects privacy and society is prepared to recognize that expectation as reasonable. The Fourth Amendment applies—and the defendant has standing to challenge the search—only if the defendant personally had such a REOP in the place or thing searched or the items seized, as determined under the totality of the circumstances.
cards.hardContent: The Fourth Amendment governs only when government conduct intrudes on a person’s reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in a place or thing or in the items seized. REOP is assessed under the totality of the circumstances and generally requires both a subjective expectation of privacy and one that society is prepared to recognize as objectively reasonable. A criminal defendant has standing to challenge the legality of a search or seizure only if they personally had such a REOP in the specific area or items affected.
cards.mnemonic: REOP: Reasonable Expectation Of Privacy = standing.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: REOP – No Expectation of Privacy Situations
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 005-2. REOP – No Expectation of Privacy Situations
cards.front: Reasonable Expectation of Privacy – When There Is No REOP
cards.backPlain: 1. There is no reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in inherently public or exposed things, so the Fourth Amendment does not apply to their observation or seizure. 2. Common examples where there is no REOP: 2.1. Handwriting. 2.2. Voice. 2.3. Physical location or movements in public. 2.4. Odors emanating from a person or property. 2.5. Public records. 2.6. Items viewable from a public space (plain view from a lawful vantage point). 2.7. Bank account records held by the bank. 2.8. The smell of luggage. 3. Areas outside the home’s curtilage are not protected by the Fourth Amendment: 3.1. Open fields and other areas beyond the curtilage are unprotected. 3.2. Garbage or trash placed outside the curtilage (e.g., on the street for collection) may be searched or seized by police without implicating the Fourth Amendment.
cards.frontPrompt: In what kinds of information, items, or locations does a person have no reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) under the Fourth Amendment?
cards.cloze: 1. There is {{c1::no reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in inherently public or exposed things, so the {{c2::Fourth Amendment}} does not apply to their observation or seizure. 2. Examples where there is no REOP: 2.1. {{c3::Handwriting}}. 2.2. {{c4::Voice}}. 2.3. {{c5::Physical location or movements}} in public. 2.4. {{c6::Odors}} emanating from a person or property. 2.5. {{c7::Public records}}. 2.6. Items {{c8::viewable from a public space}} (plain view from a lawful vantage point). 2.7. {{c9::Bank account records}} held by the bank. 2.8. The {{c10::smell of luggage}}. 3. Areas outside the home’s {{c11::curtilage}} are not protected by the Fourth Amendment, including: 3.1. {{c12::Open fields}} and other areas beyond the curtilage. 3.2. {{c13::Garbage or trash placed outside the curtilage}} (e.g., on the street for collection).
cards.easyContent: There is no reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in inherently public or exposed things, like handwriting, voice, public movements, odors, public records, bank records, things plainly visible from public spaces, or the smell of luggage. There is also no REOP in areas outside a home’s curtilage, including garbage set out on the street.
cards.mediumContent: The Fourth Amendment does not protect information or items for which society recognizes no reasonable expectation of privacy. This includes handwriting, voice, a person’s public location or movements, odors, public records, items plainly visible from lawful public vantage points, bank account records held by the bank, and the smell of luggage. Likewise, areas outside the home’s curtilage—such as open fields and trash or garbage placed on the street for collection—are unprotected and may be searched or seized without triggering the Fourth Amendment.
cards.hardContent: No reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) exists in inherently public or exposed information and areas, so observation or acquisition of such information does not constitute a Fourth Amendment search. Classic examples include handwriting, voice, a person’s physical location and movements in public, odors from a person or property, public records, items plainly visible from public vantage points, bank account records in a bank’s possession, and the smell of luggage. Similarly, the Fourth Amendment does not extend to areas beyond the home’s curtilage, such as open fields, or to garbage or trash placed outside the curtilage—like bags left on the curb for collection—which can be examined by police without a warrant or probable cause.
cards.mnemonic: EXPOSED: Exhibited Xtras—Public, Open, Smelly, External, Documented—no REOP.
cards.clozeLite: No {{c1::Fourth Amendment search}} occurs for {{c2::handwriting, voice, public movements, odors, public records, bank records}} or {{c3::open fields and curbside trash}} because there is {{c4::no reasonable expectation of privacy}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: REOP – Automatic Standing (Home and Overnight Guest)
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 005-3. REOP – Automatic Standing (Home and Overnight Guest)
cards.front: Reasonable Expectation of Privacy – Automatic Standing
cards.backPlain: 1. Automatic standing: certain home-related relationships create a presumed reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) in the premises to be searched. 2. A defendant has automatic standing (REOP is always recognized) if the defendant: 2.1. Owns the premises to be searched; or 2.2. Has a right to possess the premises to be searched; or 2.3. Lives in the premises to be searched; or 2.4. Is an overnight guest in the premises to be searched.
cards.frontPrompt: In what home-related situations is a defendant presumed to have a reasonable expectation of privacy (automatic standing) to challenge a search?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Automatic standing}} refers to situations where a defendant is presumed to have a {{c2::reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP)}} in premises to be searched. 2. A defendant has automatic standing if the defendant: 2.1. {{c3::Owns}} the premises to be searched; or 2.2. Has a {{c4::right to possess}} the premises to be searched; or 2.3. {{c5::Lives in}} the premises to be searched; or 2.4. Is an {{c6::overnight guest}} in the premises to be searched.
cards.easyContent: A defendant is presumed to have a reasonable expectation of privacy, and thus standing, in premises they own, have a right to possess, live in, or use as an overnight guest.
cards.mediumContent: In some home-related situations, courts presume a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) and thus standing. A defendant has automatic standing to challenge a search of premises they own, have a right to possess, reside in, or use as an overnight guest.
cards.hardContent: Certain strong connections to a dwelling automatically establish a reasonable expectation of privacy (REOP) sufficient for Fourth Amendment standing. A defendant has automatic standing to contest a search of premises that the defendant owns, has a right to possess, or actually lives in, as well as premises where the defendant is staying as an overnight guest. These home-centered relationships create a robust and presumptively reasonable privacy interest in the premises.
cards.mnemonic: HOME: Have right, Own, Move in, Evening guest.
cards.clozeLite: Automatic {{c1::Fourth Amendment standing}} exists to challenge a home search if D {{c2::owns}}, {{c3::has a right to possess}}, {{c4::resides in}}, or is an {{c5::overnight guest}} there.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Valid Search Warrant – General Requirement
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 006-1. Valid Search Warrant – General Requirement
cards.front: Valid Search Warrant – General Requirement
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general Fourth Amendment rule regarding when the government must obtain a search warrant?
cards.backPlain: General rule: Under the Fourth Amendment, a search is ordinarily valid only if conducted pursuant to a properly executed search warrant. Unless a recognized exception to the warrant requirement applies (e.g., exigent circumstances, consent, search incident to arrest, automobile exception, etc.), the government must obtain a valid warrant before conducting a search.
cards.cloze: General rule: Under the {{c1::Fourth Amendment}}, a search is ordinarily valid only if conducted pursuant to a properly executed {{c2::search warrant}}. Unless a recognized {{c3::exception to the warrant requirement}} applies (e.g., exigent circumstances, consent, search incident to arrest, automobile exception), the government must obtain a valid warrant before conducting a search.
cards.easyContent: The Fourth Amendment generally requires the government to get a valid search warrant before conducting a search, unless a specific warrant exception applies.
cards.mediumContent: As a baseline, the Fourth Amendment requires that searches be conducted pursuant to a properly executed warrant. Only if a recognized exception to the warrant requirement applies may the government conduct a warrantless search.
cards.hardContent: The default rule under the Fourth Amendment is that a search is reasonable only if conducted pursuant to a valid search warrant. The government must obtain such a warrant unless a specific, judicially recognized exception to the warrant requirement applies (such as consent, exigent circumstances, search incident to a lawful arrest, automobile exception, or other limited doctrines). If no exception applies and no valid warrant is obtained, the search is presumptively unreasonable.
cards.mnemonic: Start with W: Without a warrant, a search is presumptively wrong—unless an exception applies.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Fourth Amendment}} default is that a {{c2::search is reasonable only with a valid warrant}}, unless a {{c3::recognized warrant exception}} applies.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Valid Search Warrant – Probable Cause and Affidavit / False Statement
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 006-2. Valid Search Warrant – Probable Cause and Affidavit / False Statement
cards.front: Valid Search Warrant – Probable Cause and Affidavit / False Statement
cards.frontPrompt: What is required to show probable cause for a search warrant, and when will a false statement in the supporting affidavit invalidate the warrant?
cards.backPlain: 1. Probable cause requirement: - A valid search warrant must be based on probable cause that evidence, contraband, or fruits or instrumentalities of crime will be found in the place to be searched. - Probable cause is usually demonstrated by a police affidavit submitted to the magistrate. - The affidavit must set out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found; it may incorporate information from anonymous sources. 2. False statements in the affidavit (Franks-type challenge): - A defendant can attack a warrant by showing that: (1) The affidavit contained a false statement; (2) The affiant (the officer) included the false statement intentionally or with reckless disregard for the truth; and (3) The false statement was material to the finding of probable cause. - If these elements are met, the false material is excised from the affidavit; if the remaining content does not establish probable cause, the warrant is invalid.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Probable cause}} requirement: - A valid search warrant must be based on probable cause that {{c2::evidence, contraband, or fruits or instrumentalities of crime}} will be found in the place to be searched. - Probable cause is usually demonstrated by a police {{c3::affidavit}} submitted to the magistrate. - The affidavit must set out {{c4::facts}} showing a {{c5::fair probability}} that evidence will be found; it may incorporate information from {{c6::anonymous sources}}. 2. False statements in the affidavit ({{c7::Franks}}-type challenge): - A defendant can attack a warrant by showing that: (1) The affidavit contained a {{c8::false statement}}; (2) The affiant included the false statement {{c9::intentionally or with reckless disregard for the truth}}; and (3) The false statement was {{c10::material to the finding of probable cause}}. - If these elements are met, the false material is {{c11::excised}}; if the remaining content does not establish probable cause, the {{c12::warrant is invalid}}.
cards.easyContent: A warrant must be supported by probable cause, normally shown in a police affidavit that sets out facts showing a fair probability that evidence will be found. If the officer intentionally or recklessly includes a material false statement in the affidavit, and without that statement there’s no probable cause, the warrant is invalid.
cards.mediumContent: Probable cause for a search warrant is generally shown through a sworn police affidavit that recites facts (including, if appropriate, anonymous tips) indicating a fair probability that evidence of a crime will be found at a particular place. A defendant can challenge the warrant by proving that the affiant intentionally or recklessly included a false statement that was material to probable cause; if so, the false material is excised and the warrant fails if the remaining affidavit does not support probable cause.
cards.hardContent: To be valid, a search warrant must be supported by probable cause that evidence, contraband, or the fruits or instrumentalities of crime are likely to be found at the specified location. Probable cause is typically established via a sworn law-enforcement affidavit submitted to a magistrate, which must lay out concrete facts indicating a fair probability that the search will uncover evidence; the affidavit may rely on informants, including anonymous sources, as part of the totality of the circumstances. Under a Franks-type challenge, a defendant may invalidate the warrant by showing (1) that the affidavit contained a false statement; (2) that the affiant included the false statement intentionally or with reckless disregard for the truth; and (3) that the false statement was material to the probable cause finding. If these elements are met and, after excising the false material, the remaining affidavit does not establish probable cause, the warrant is invalid and evidence may be suppressed (subject to any applicable good-faith exception).
cards.mnemonic: Franks PC test: False, Fault, Fundamental to PC.
