cards.clozeLite: Probable cause for a search warrant is shown by a {{c1::sworn police affidavit}} reciting facts showing a {{c2::fair probability}} evidence is at a place. A defendant can attack it by proving the {{c3::affiant intentionally or recklessly included a false statement}} that was {{c4::material to probable cause}}; if the remaining affidavit {{c5::does not support probable cause}}, the warrant is invalid.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Valid Search Warrant – Particularity Requirement
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 006-3. Valid Search Warrant – Particularity Requirement
cards.front: Valid Search Warrant – Particularity Requirement
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Fourth Amendment particularity requirement demand in a valid search warrant?
cards.backPlain: Particularity requirement: - A valid search warrant must be precise on its face. It must describe, with reasonable precision, the place to be searched and the items or persons to be seized. - The description must be specific enough that the executing officers can reasonably identify the correct premises and limit the search to evidence described in the warrant, avoiding general exploratory searches. - Overly broad or vague warrants that fail to reasonably particularize the place or items (i.e., "general warrants") are constitutionally defective.
cards.cloze: Particularity requirement: - A valid search warrant must be {{c1::precise on its face}}. It must describe, with {{c2::reasonable precision}}, the {{c3::place to be searched}} and the {{c4::items or persons to be seized}}. - The description must be specific enough that officers can reliably {{c5::identify the correct premises}} and {{c6::limit the search}} to evidence described in the warrant, avoiding {{c7::general exploratory searches}}. - Overly broad or vague warrants that fail to reasonably particularize the place or items (i.e., {{c8::general warrants}}) are {{c9::constitutionally defective}}.
cards.easyContent: A warrant must describe with reasonable precision the place to be searched and the items or persons to be seized. General, overly broad descriptions violate the Fourth Amendment particularity requirement.
cards.mediumContent: To satisfy the Fourth Amendment, a search warrant must be sufficiently particular on its face: it must describe the place to be searched and the items or persons to be seized with enough specificity that executing officers can reasonably identify the correct location and limit their search accordingly. Warrants that allow broad, exploratory rummaging—"general warrants"—are invalid.
cards.hardContent: The Fourth Amendment's particularity requirement prohibits general warrants. A valid search warrant must be precise on its face and must describe, with reasonable precision under the circumstances, both the place to be searched and the items or persons to be seized. The description must be clear enough to guide executing officers to the proper premises and to confine the scope of the search to the evidence specified, thereby preventing general exploratory searches. If the warrant is overly broad, vague, or fails to meaningfully limit the place or items, it is facially defective and may be invalid for lack of particularity.
cards.mnemonic: P in PNP: Particularity = Precise place and Property.
cards.clozeLite: A valid warrant must {{c1::describe the place to be searched}} and {{c2::items or persons to be seized}} with {{c3::reasonable precision}}, avoiding {{c4::general warrants}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Valid Search Warrant – Neutral Magistrate and Good-Faith Exception
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 006-4. Valid Search Warrant – Neutral Magistrate and Good-Faith Exception
cards.front: Valid Search Warrant – Neutral Magistrate and Good-Faith Exception
cards.frontPrompt: What is required regarding the issuing magistrate for a valid search warrant, and when does the good-faith exception to the exclusionary rule apply or not apply?
cards.backPlain: 1. Neutral and detached magistrate: - A valid search warrant must be issued by a neutral and detached magistrate—someone not aligned with the prosecution or police and who is capable of making an independent determination of probable cause. - A magistrate who participates in law enforcement activities or otherwise abandons the judicial role is not neutral and detached. 2. Good-faith exception to the exclusionary rule: - General rule: Even if a warrant is later found invalid, the exclusionary rule does not apply if police acted in objective good-faith reliance on the warrant. 3. Exceptions to good-faith reliance (when police cannot rely on the warrant): Officers cannot invoke the good-faith exception if: (1) The supporting affidavit completely lacks probable cause—no reasonable officer would have relied on it. (2) The warrant is defective on its face (e.g., fails to particularize place or items). (3) The police or government official lied to or misled the magistrate. (4) The magistrate has wholly abandoned the judicial role and is not neutral and detached.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Neutral and detached magistrate}}: - A valid search warrant must be issued by a magistrate who is not aligned with law enforcement and who can make an {{c2::independent probable cause}} determination. 2. {{c3::Good-faith exception}} to the {{c4::exclusionary rule}}: - Even if a warrant is later found invalid, evidence is generally not excluded if police acted in {{c5::objective good-faith reliance}} on the warrant. 3. Exceptions to good-faith reliance (when the exception does NOT apply): Officers cannot rely on the good-faith exception if: (1) The affidavit {{c6::completely lacks probable cause}}—no reasonable officer would have relied on it. (2) The warrant is {{c7::defective on its face}} (e.g., fails to particularize place or items). (3) The police or government officials {{c8::lied to or misled the magistrate}}. (4) The magistrate has {{c9::wholly abandoned the judicial role}} and is not truly neutral and detached.
cards.easyContent: A search warrant must be issued by a neutral and detached magistrate. Even if the warrant later turns out to be invalid, evidence is usually not excluded if officers relied on it in objective good faith. But the good-faith exception does not apply if the affidavit is wholly lacking in probable cause, the warrant is facially defective, the officers misled the magistrate, or the magistrate abandoned the judicial role.
cards.mediumContent: For a valid search warrant, the issuing authority must be a neutral and detached magistrate capable of independently assessing probable cause. Under the good-faith exception, evidence obtained under a warrant later found invalid is not excluded if officers reasonably relied on the warrant. However, good faith does not save the evidence when the affidavit is so lacking in probable cause that no reasonable officer would rely on it, when the warrant is facially defective, when police misled the magistrate, or when the magistrate has essentially ceased to function as a neutral judicial officer.
cards.hardContent: A valid search warrant must be issued by a neutral and detached magistrate—one who is independent of law enforcement and who exercises a genuine judicial function in determining probable cause. If a warrant is later held invalid, the exclusionary rule ordinarily does not require suppression of evidence obtained under it if officers acted in objective good-faith reliance on the warrant. This good-faith exception is limited: it does not apply when (1) the supporting affidavit is so lacking in indicia of probable cause that no reasonable officer would rely on it; (2) the warrant is facially defective, such as by failing to meet the particularity requirement; (3) law enforcement officers or government officials lied to or misled the magistrate; or (4) the magistrate has wholly abandoned the judicial role and is not truly neutral and detached.
cards.mnemonic: No PC, Bad Face, Cops Lie, Judge’s a Cop.
cards.clozeLite: A valid warrant needs a {{c1::neutral and detached magistrate}} and allows {{c2::good-faith reliance}} unless {{c3::no probable cause}}, {{c4::facial defect}}, {{c5::police mislead}}, or {{c6::magistrate abandons neutrality}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Core Rule and Scope
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 008-1. Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Core Rule and Scope
cards.front: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Core Rule and Scope
cards.frontPrompt: What is the core rule governing a search incident to a lawful arrest, and what are the key requirements for timing and scope (person and area searched)?
cards.backPlain: 1. Core SILA rule: Police may, without a warrant, search a lawfully arrested person and the area within his immediate control. 1.1. The arrest must be lawful (i.e., supported by probable cause and otherwise valid). 1.2. The search must be contemporaneous with the arrest (occurring at roughly the same time and place). 1.3. Scope of area: The search is limited to the area within the arrestee’s immediate reach or movement (his "wingspan")—places where he could obtain weapons or destroy evidence. 1.4. Purpose: Officer safety (to find weapons) and preservation of evidence (to prevent destruction).
cards.cloze: 1. Core SILA rule: Police may, without a warrant, {{c1::search a lawfully arrested person and the area within his immediate control}}. 1.1. The {{c2::arrest must be lawful}} (supported by probable cause and otherwise valid). 1.2. The search must be {{c3::contemporaneous with the arrest}} (roughly same time and place). 1.3. Scope of area: The search is limited to the area within the arrestee’s {{c4::immediate reach or movement}} (his "{{c5::wingspan}}")—places where he could obtain weapons or destroy evidence. 1.4. Purpose: {{c6::officer safety}} (to find weapons) and {{c7::preservation of evidence}} (to prevent destruction).
cards.easyContent: A search incident to a lawful arrest (SILA) lets officers, without a warrant, search the arrestee and his immediate reach at the time of arrest, as long as the arrest is lawful, the search is contemporaneous, and the search stays within the arrestee’s wingspan for weapons and evidence.
cards.mediumContent: Under the core SILA rule, officers may, without a warrant, search a lawfully arrested person and the area within his immediate control. The arrest must itself be lawful, the search must be contemporaneous with the arrest, and the search must be confined to the arrestee’s wingspan—places he could access to grab a weapon or destroy evidence. The justification is officer safety and evidence preservation.
cards.hardContent: The core search-incident-to-lawful-arrest (SILA) doctrine authorizes officers, without a warrant, to search (1) the person of an arrestee and (2) the area within his immediate control. This authority attaches only if the underlying arrest is lawful (e.g., supported by probable cause) and the search is conducted contemporaneously with the arrest in both time and place. The spatial scope is limited to the arrestee’s wingspan—areas he could reach during the arrest to obtain weapons or destroy evidence. The twin rationales are officer safety and preservation of evidence, and these rationales also limit how broadly officers may interpret the arrestee’s “immediate control.”
cards.mnemonic: SILA: Safe Immediate Lawful Arrest—person plus wingspan.
cards.clozeLite: SILA allows officers to {{c1::search a lawfully arrested person}} and {{c2::the area within his immediate control}} if {{c3::the arrest is lawful}} and {{c4::the search is contemporaneous}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Protective Sweeps and Inventory Searches
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 008-2. Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Protective Sweeps and Inventory Searches
cards.front: SILA – Protective Sweeps and Inventory Searches
cards.frontPrompt: Following a lawful arrest, when may police conduct a protective sweep of nearby areas and when may they perform an inventory search of the arrestee’s belongings or property?
cards.backPlain: 1. Protective sweeps: 1.1. Following an arrest in a home or building, police may conduct a limited protective sweep of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest area. 1.2. Standard: Officers must have a reasonable belief (based on specific facts) that accomplices may be present or that there is danger. 1.3. Scope: A cursory inspection for persons (not a full evidentiary search), generally limited to spaces where a person could be hiding; expansion beyond adjoining areas requires articulable facts suggesting danger. 2. Inventory searches: 2.1. When jailing an arrested suspect or impounding property, police may conduct an inventory search of the arrestee’s belongings or seized property. 2.2. Purpose: To protect the owner’s property, prevent claims of theft, and maintain jail/impound security, not to search for evidence. 2.3. Requirement: The inventory must be conducted pursuant to standardized, good-faith procedures and may not be a pretext for an investigatory search.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Protective sweeps}}: 1.1. Following an arrest in a home or building, police may conduct a {{c2::limited protective sweep}} of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest area. 1.2. Standard: Officers must have a {{c3::reasonable belief}} (based on specific facts) that {{c4::accomplices may be present}} or that there is {{c5::danger}}. 1.3. Scope: A {{c6::cursory inspection for persons}} (not a full evidentiary search), generally limited to spaces where a person could be hiding; expansion beyond adjoining areas requires {{c7::articulable facts suggesting danger}}. 2. {{c8::Inventory searches}}: 2.1. When jailing an arrested suspect or impounding property, police may conduct an inventory search of the {{c9::arrestee’s belongings or seized property}}. 2.2. Purpose: To {{c10::protect the owner’s property}}, {{c11::prevent claims of theft}}, and {{c12::maintain jail/impound security}}, not to search primarily for evidence. 2.3. Requirement: The inventory must be conducted pursuant to {{c13::standardized, good-faith procedures}} and may not be a {{c14::pretext for an investigatory search}}.
cards.easyContent: After an arrest in a home, officers can do a brief protective sweep of nearby spaces if they reasonably believe there is danger or accomplices. Separately, when jailing an arrestee or impounding property, officers may inventory his belongings or property under standardized procedures for security and property protection, not as a pretext to look for evidence.
cards.mediumContent: A protective sweep is a limited, cursory inspection of areas immediately adjoining the place of arrest in a home or building, justified by a reasonable belief that there might be accomplices or danger. It is confined to places where people might hide and may be extended only if articulable facts suggest a continuing threat. Inventory searches occur when an arrestee is taken to jail or property is impounded; officers may catalog the arrestee’s belongings or seized property under standardized, good-faith procedures, primarily to protect property, avoid theft claims, and maintain security—not to conduct an evidentiary search.
cards.hardContent: Incident to an in-home or building arrest, officers may undertake a protective sweep—a quick, limited check of spaces immediately adjoining the arrest site—when they have a reasonable belief, grounded in specific and articulable facts, that an accomplice may be present or that there is danger. The sweep is confined to a cursory inspection of areas where a person could hide and is not a full-blown search for evidence; any extension beyond immediately adjoining spaces requires additional articulable facts indicating a threat. Separately, when an arrestee is booked into jail or property is impounded, officers may conduct an inventory search of the arrestee’s belongings or other seized property. Such inventories must be performed pursuant to standardized, non-investigatory procedures, aimed at protecting the owner’s property, avoiding false-theft claims, and maintaining security, and may not be used as a mere pretext to look for evidence.
cards.mnemonic: After arrest: SWEEP for people, INVENTORY for property.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::protective sweep}} is a {{c2::limited, cursory inspection}} of areas {{c3::immediately adjoining the arrest site}} where people might hide, while an {{c4::inventory search}} catalogs {{c5::arrestee’s belongings or impounded property}} under {{c6::standardized, good-faith procedures}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Vehicle Searches
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 008-3. Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Vehicle Searches
cards.front: SILA – Vehicle Searches Incident to Arrest
cards.frontPrompt: After arresting a recent occupant of a vehicle, what are the rules governing a search of the vehicle incident to arrest, including the permissible scope and trunk limitation?
cards.backPlain: 1. General SILA rule for vehicles: 1.1. After arresting a recent occupant of a vehicle, police may search the vehicle’s passenger compartment, including containers and the glove box, incident to arrest only if, at the time of the search: 1.1.1. The arrestee is unsecured and may access the vehicle interior; or 1.1.2. Police reasonably believe the vehicle contains evidence of the offense for which the arrest was made. 2. Trunk limitation: 2.1. Police may not search the trunk of the vehicle solely as a search incident to arrest. 2.2. To search the trunk, officers need an independent justification, such as probable cause (supporting a search under the automobile exception) or valid consent.
cards.cloze: 1. General SILA rule for vehicles: 1.1. After arresting a recent occupant of a vehicle, police may search the vehicle’s {{c1::passenger compartment}}, including containers and the {{c2::glove box}}, incident to arrest only if, at the time of the search: 1.1.1. The arrestee is {{c3::unsecured}} and may {{c4::access the vehicle interior}}; or 1.1.2. Police {{c5::reasonably believe}} the vehicle contains {{c6::evidence of the offense for which the arrest was made}}. 2. Trunk limitation: 2.1. Police may not search the {{c7::trunk}} of the vehicle solely as a search incident to arrest. 2.2. To search the trunk, officers need {{c8::probable cause}} (e.g., to use the automobile exception) or {{c9::valid consent}}.
cards.easyContent: When an occupant of a car is arrested, officers can search the passenger compartment (including the glove box and containers) incident to arrest only if the arrestee is still unsecured and can reach the interior, or if officers reasonably believe the car holds evidence of the offense of arrest. They cannot search the trunk incident to arrest without separate probable cause or consent.
cards.mediumContent: Vehicle searches incident to arrest are limited. After arresting a recent occupant, officers may search the passenger compartment, including containers and the glove box, if at the time of the search the arrestee is unsecured and could access the interior, or if it is reasonable to believe the vehicle contains evidence of the offense of arrest. SILA does not by itself authorize a trunk search; officers need an independent basis, such as probable cause to search under the automobile exception or valid consent from someone with authority.
cards.hardContent: Under the search-incident-to-lawful-arrest doctrine as applied to vehicles, officers who arrest a recent occupant may search the vehicle’s passenger compartment, including closed containers and the glove box, only when one of two conditions is satisfied at the time of the search: (1) the arrestee remains unsecured and within reaching distance of the passenger compartment, or (2) it is reasonable to believe that the vehicle contains evidence of the offense of arrest. This SILA authority does not extend to the trunk; a trunk search requires an independent justification such as probable cause supporting an automobile-exception search or valid voluntary consent by a person with authority over the vehicle.
cards.mnemonic: Car SILA: CABIN if Reachable or Relevant; trunk needs more.
cards.clozeLite: After arresting a recent vehicle occupant, SILA allows a search of the {{c1::passenger compartment (including containers)}} only if the arrestee is {{c2::unsecured and within reach}} or if it’s {{c3::reasonable to believe the car holds evidence of the offense of arrest}}; {{c4::SILA does not by itself allow a trunk search}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Breath Tests and Cell Phones
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 008-4. Search Incident to Lawful Arrest – Breath Tests and Cell Phones
cards.front: SILA – Breath Tests and Cell-Phone Limitation
cards.frontPrompt: In the context of a search incident to a lawful arrest, what are the rules for warrantless breathalyzer tests and for searching digital information on seized cell phones?
cards.backPlain: 1. Breathalyzer tests (DUI arrests): 1.1. Following a lawful arrest based on probable cause for drunk driving, police may require a warrantless breathalyzer test incident to the arrest. 1.2. Rationale: Breath tests are considered minimally intrusive and fall within the search-incident-to-arrest exception. 2. Cell phones (digital information limitation): 2.1. Police may seize a cell phone incident to arrest (e.g., to prevent destruction or for officer safety) but may not search the digital contents of the phone incident to arrest without a warrant. 2.2. Officers generally must obtain a warrant to search text messages, emails, photos, or other digital data stored on a phone seized during an arrest, absent an independent exception (e.g., exigent circumstances).
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Breathalyzer tests}} (DUI arrests): 1.1. Following a {{c2::lawful arrest}} based on {{c3::probable cause for drunk driving}}, police may require a {{c4::warrantless breathalyzer test}} incident to the arrest. 1.2. Rationale: Breath tests are considered {{c5::minimally intrusive}} and fall within the {{c6::search-incident-to-arrest}} exception. 2. {{c7::Cell phones}} (digital information limitation): 2.1. Police may {{c8::seize}} a cell phone incident to arrest but may not {{c9::search the digital contents}} of the phone incident to arrest without a {{c10::warrant}}. 2.2. Officers generally must obtain a warrant to search {{c11::text messages, emails, photos, or other digital data}} stored on a phone seized during an arrest, absent an independent exception such as {{c12::exigent circumstances}}.
cards.easyContent: After a lawful DUI arrest based on probable cause, officers can require a warrantless breath test as a valid search incident to arrest. By contrast, even if they seize a cell phone during an arrest, they usually need a warrant to search its digital contents, unless another exception like exigent circumstances applies.
cards.mediumContent: Incident to a lawful drunk-driving arrest supported by probable cause, a warrantless breathalyzer test is permitted as part of the search-incident-to-arrest exception because it is considered minimally intrusive. However, officers may not rely on SILA to search the digital contents of a seized cell phone. While they may physically seize the phone incident to arrest, they must generally obtain a warrant before examining its stored data—texts, emails, photos, and other digital information—unless some separate exception (such as exigent circumstances) justifies a warrantless digital search.
cards.hardContent: Within the search-incident-to-lawful-arrest framework, courts treat warrantless breathalyzer tests and digital cell-phone searches differently. A warrantless breath test following a lawful, probable-cause arrest for drunk driving is generally permissible as a search incident to arrest, on the theory that it is only minimally intrusive and closely tied to the justification for the drunk-driving arrest. In contrast, although officers may seize a cell phone incident to arrest to secure it and prevent destruction, they may not search its digital contents—such as text messages, emails, photos, and app data—based solely on SILA. Absent an independent exception like exigent circumstances, officers must first obtain a warrant before accessing the digital information stored on the phone.
cards.mnemonic: Breath is fair game under SILA; bytes on phones need a warrant.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::SILA}}, a {{c2::warrantless breath test}} after a lawful DUI arrest is allowed, but {{c3::searching cell-phone digital data}} generally {{c4::requires a warrant}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Miranda Rights – When Miranda Applies (Custodial Interrogation)
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 020-1. Miranda Rights – When Miranda Applies (Custodial Interrogation)
cards.front: Miranda – When Do Warnings Apply?
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1. A suspect who is in custody must be informed of Miranda rights before interrogation. 1.2. If Miranda warnings are required but not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s subsequent statements are generally inadmissible in the prosecution’s case-in-chief. 1.3. Miranda applies only when the accused is both in custody and subjected to interrogation ("custodial interrogation").
cards.frontPrompt: Under what circumstances are Miranda warnings required, and what is the general consequence of failing to give them?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule 1.1. A suspect who is in {{c1::custody}} must be informed of {{c2::Miranda rights}} before {{c3:interrogation}}. 1.2. If Miranda warnings are required but not given before custodial interrogation, the suspect’s subsequent statements are generally {{c4::inadmissible}} in the {{c5::prosecution’s case-in-chief}}. 1.3. Miranda applies only when the accused is both in {{c1::custody}} and subjected to {{c3::interrogation}} ("{{c6::custodial interrogation}}".).
cards.easyContent: Miranda warnings are required only during custodial interrogation; without them, statements are generally inadmissible in the prosecution’s case-in-chief.
cards.mediumContent: Miranda applies to custodial interrogation: when a suspect is both in custody and subjected to police questioning or its functional equivalent. If warnings are required but omitted, the suspect’s statements are typically inadmissible in the prosecution’s case-in-chief.
cards.hardContent: Miranda’s protections are triggered only during custodial interrogation. Custody means the suspect is in a situation where a reasonable person would not feel free to leave, and interrogation means police questions or their functional equivalent. Before such questioning, officers must give Miranda warnings; if they do not, any resulting statements are generally excluded from the prosecution’s case-in-chief, though other doctrines may govern derivative evidence or impeachment use.
cards.mnemonic: Think "CI → W": Custodial Interrogation requires Warnings.
cards.clozeLite: Miranda applies only to {{c1::custodial interrogation}}—when a suspect is {{c2::in custody}} and {{c3::subjected to police questioning or its functional equivalent}}; without warnings, {{c4::statements are generally inadmissible in the prosecution’s case-in-chief}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Miranda Rights – Custody, Interrogation, and Exceptions
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 020-2. Miranda Rights – Custody, Interrogation, and Exceptions
cards.front: Miranda – Custody, Interrogation, and Key Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 2. Custody 2.1. The accused is in custody when a reasonable person would not feel free to leave. 3. Interrogation 3.1. Interrogation consists of statements or actions by police that are reasonably likely to elicit incriminating responses. 3.2. Unsolicited or volunteered statements by the accused are not protected by Miranda (because they are not the product of interrogation). 3.3. Routine questioning, such as during booking or a probation interview, is not considered interrogation. 3.4. Public-safety exception: police may interrogate a suspect without giving Miranda warnings when reasonably necessary to protect public safety (for example, where the defendant has information about a bomb that could explode in public).
cards.frontPrompt: How do you define custody and interrogation for Miranda purposes, and what are the main situations that fall outside interrogation, including the public-safety exception?
cards.cloze: 2. Custody 2.1. The accused is in {{c1::custody}} when a {{c2::reasonable person}} would not feel {{c3::free to leave}}. 3. Interrogation 3.1. {{c4::Interrogation}} consists of statements or actions by police that are reasonably likely to elicit {{c5::incriminating responses}}. 3.2. {{c6::Unsolicited or volunteered statements}} by the accused are not protected by Miranda because they are not the product of {{c4::interrogation}}. 3.3. {{c7::Routine questioning}}, such as during {{c8::booking}} or a {{c9::probation interview}}, is not considered interrogation. 3.4. {{c10::Public-safety exception}}: police may interrogate a suspect without giving Miranda warnings when reasonably necessary to protect {{c11::public safety}} (for example, where the defendant has information about a {{c12::bomb}} that could explode in public).
cards.easyContent: Custody exists when a reasonable person wouldn’t feel free to leave. Interrogation is police conduct likely to elicit incriminating responses. Volunteered statements, routine booking questions, and some emergency public-safety questions fall outside Miranda’s interrogation requirement.
cards.mediumContent: For Miranda, custody is an objective test: whether a reasonable person in the suspect’s position would feel free to leave. Interrogation covers police statements or actions reasonably likely to elicit incriminating responses. Volunteered statements and routine booking or probation questions are not interrogation. There is also a narrow public-safety exception allowing unwarned questioning when reasonably necessary to protect the public, such as asking about the location of a bomb.
cards.hardContent: Miranda’s custody requirement is satisfied when, under an objective standard, a reasonable person in the suspect’s situation would not feel free to terminate the encounter and leave. Interrogation encompasses not only direct questioning but also its functional equivalent: any words or actions by police that they should know are reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response. Statements that are volunteered by the suspect, without prompting, are outside Miranda. Likewise, routine administrative inquiries—such as standard booking questions or some probation interviews—are not treated as interrogation. Finally, under the public-safety exception, officers may ask questions without first giving Miranda warnings when reasonably necessary to secure their own safety or the safety of the public, such as determining the location of a weapon or explosive that poses an imminent threat.
cards.mnemonic: CIP: Custody, Interrogation, Plus exceptions (volunteered, booking, public safety).
cards.clozeLite: For {{c1::Miranda}}, {{c2::custody}} means a reasonable person wouldn’t feel free to leave; {{c3::interrogation}} is conduct likely to elicit incriminating responses, excluding {{c4::volunteered statements}}, {{c5::booking questions}}, and the {{c6::public-safety exception}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Miranda Rights – Content of Warnings and Constitutional Basis
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 020-3. Miranda Rights – Content of Warnings and Constitutional Basis
cards.front: Miranda – Required Warnings and Constitutional Basis
cards.backPlain: 4. Miranda warnings 4.1. Police must inform the accused that: 4.1.1. He has the right to remain silent. 4.1.2. Anything he says can be used against him in court. 4.1.3. He has the right to the presence of an attorney. 4.1.4. An attorney will be appointed if he cannot afford one. 4.2. Substantial compliance in reading the warnings is sufficient; the warnings need not be perfectly worded. 4.3. Failure to give Miranda warnings implicates the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, not the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
cards.frontPrompt: What specific warnings must police give under Miranda, how exact must the wording be, and which constitutional right is implicated by a failure to warn?
cards.cloze: 4. Miranda warnings 4.1. Police must inform the accused that: 4.1.1. He has the {{c1::right to remain silent}}. 4.1.2. {{c2::Anything he says can be used against him in court}}. 4.1.3. He has the {{c3::right to the presence of an attorney}}. 4.1.4. An attorney will be {{c4::appointed if he cannot afford one}}. 4.2. {{c5::Substantial compliance}} in reading the warnings is sufficient; the warnings need not be perfectly worded. 4.3. Failure to give Miranda warnings implicates the {{c6::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}}, not the {{c7::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}.
cards.easyContent: Miranda requires warnings about the right to remain silent, the use of statements in court, the right to counsel, and appointed counsel if indigent. The wording need only substantially comply, and failures are treated as Fifth Amendment self-incrimination problems, not Sixth Amendment counsel violations.
cards.mediumContent: Before custodial interrogation, police must advise the suspect that he has the right to remain silent, that anything he says can be used against him in court, that he has the right to an attorney, and that one will be appointed if he cannot afford one. Courts require only substantial compliance with this content; the exact phrasing need not be perfect. A failure to give these warnings is analyzed under the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, not under the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
cards.hardContent: Miranda mandates that officers, before custodial interrogation, give four core warnings: (1) the suspect has the right to remain silent; (2) any statement can and will be used against him in court; (3) he has the right to consult with a lawyer and to have the lawyer present during questioning; and (4) if he cannot afford a lawyer, one will be appointed before any questioning if he so desires. Courts look for substantial compliance with these requirements rather than rigid incantation of specific words. A failure to administer these warnings, when required, leads to exclusion of the resulting statements on the ground that they were obtained in violation of the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, not the Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
cards.mnemonic: Miranda = S-U-C-C: Silence, Used, Counsel, Court-appointed.
cards.clozeLite: Before {{c1::custodial interrogation}}, police must give {{c2::four Miranda warnings}} and need only {{c3::substantial compliance}}; failure is a {{c4::Fifth, not Sixth, Amendment}} issue.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Invoking Miranda – Right to Remain Silent
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 021-1. Invoking Miranda – Right to Remain Silent
cards.front: Invoking Miranda – Right to Remain Silent
cards.backPlain: Invoking the Right to Remain Silent (Fifth Amendment) 1. General rule 1.1. An accused may terminate a custodial interrogation at any time by invoking the right to remain silent. 2. Effect of invocation 2.1. Once the accused invokes the right to remain silent, police must immediately cease all questioning. 2.2. Only the accused can reinitiate dialogue about the investigation. 3. When police may resume 3.1. Police may resume questioning only after a significant period of time has passed. 3.2. Any resumed questioning must generally concern unrelated crimes. 3.3. Before resuming, the accused must be given a fresh set of Miranda warnings.
cards.frontPrompt: How does a suspect invoke the Miranda right to remain silent, and what limits does that place on further police questioning?
cards.cloze: Invoking the Right to Remain Silent (Fifth Amendment) 1. An accused may terminate a {{c1::custodial interrogation}} at any time by invoking the {{c2::right to remain silent}}. 2. Once this right is invoked, police must {{c3::immediately cease all questioning}}. 3. Only the {{c4::accused}} may {{c5::reinitiate dialogue}} about the investigation. 4. Police may resume questioning only after a {{c6::significant period of time}} has passed, and generally only about {{c7::unrelated crimes}}, and only after giving {{c8::fresh Miranda warnings}}.
cards.easyContent: If a suspect clearly invokes the right to remain silent during custodial interrogation, police must stop questioning. Only the suspect can restart it, and police can only later resume after a significant break, with new warnings, and usually only about unrelated crimes.
cards.mediumContent: During custodial interrogation, a suspect can invoke the Fifth Amendment right to remain silent to cut off questioning. Once invoked, police must immediately stop questioning, and only the suspect may reinitiate discussion about the investigation. Police may resume only after a significant period of time has passed, with a fresh set of Miranda warnings, and generally only to question about unrelated offenses.
cards.hardContent: The Fifth Amendment right to remain silent, as implemented by Miranda, allows an accused to terminate custodial interrogation at any time by clearly invoking that right. Upon invocation, the police must immediately cease all questioning. Only the accused may reinitiate dialogue about the investigation. Police may resume questioning only after a significant period of time has elapsed, and generally only about unrelated crimes, and they must first administer a fresh set of Miranda warnings before any renewed questioning.
cards.mnemonic: Silence stops THIS session: S = Silence; S = Stop; S = Significant break before restart.
cards.clozeLite: During {{c1::custodial interrogation}}, a suspect can {{c2::clearly invoke the right to remain silent}}; police must {{c3::immediately stop questioning}} and may resume only after a {{c4::significant break with fresh Miranda warnings}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Invoking Miranda – Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 021-2. Invoking Miranda – Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel
cards.front: Invoking Miranda – Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel
cards.backPlain: Invoking the Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel (Miranda) 1. General rule 1.1. An accused may terminate a custodial interrogation at any time by invoking the Fifth Amendment right to counsel. 2. Effect of invocation 2.1. Once the accused unambiguously requests counsel, police must cease all questioning on any topic. 3. Distinction from Sixth Amendment right to counsel 3.1. The Fifth Amendment right to counsel under Miranda is not offense-specific and applies during custodial interrogation. 3.2. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is offense-specific and attaches only once formal charges are filed. 4. Reinitiation 4.1. If the accused initiates communication after invoking counsel, interrogation may resume. 4.2. Any resumed interrogation is subject to a valid Miranda waiver.
cards.frontPrompt: What happens when a suspect clearly invokes the Fifth Amendment right to counsel under Miranda, and how does this differ from the Sixth Amendment right to counsel?
cards.cloze: Invoking the Fifth Amendment Right to Counsel (Miranda) 1. An accused may terminate custodial interrogation by invoking the {{c1::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}}. 2. Once the accused {{c2::unambiguously requests counsel}}, police must cease all questioning on {{c3::any topic}}. 3. This {{c4::Fifth Amendment right to counsel}} is different from the {{c5::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}}, which is {{c6::offense-specific}} and attaches only once {{c7::formal charges are filed}}. 4. If the accused {{c8::initiates communication}} after invoking counsel, interrogation may resume, but only with a {{c9::valid Miranda waiver}}.
cards.easyContent: If a suspect clearly asks for a lawyer during custodial interrogation, police must stop all questioning on any topic. Questioning can only resume if the suspect reinitiates and validly waives Miranda. This Fifth Amendment counsel right is broader than the offense-specific Sixth Amendment right that attaches only after formal charges.
cards.mediumContent: A suspect in custody can invoke the Fifth Amendment right to counsel by clearly requesting a lawyer. Once invoked, all police questioning on any subject must stop. The Miranda counsel right is not offense-specific, unlike the Sixth Amendment right, which applies only after formal charges and only to the charged offense. If, after invoking counsel, the suspect initiates further communication with police, interrogation may resume, but only if the suspect then validly waives Miranda rights.
cards.hardContent: During custodial interrogation, an accused may terminate questioning by unambiguously requesting counsel, thereby invoking the Fifth Amendment right to counsel under Miranda. Once this right is invoked, police must cease all questioning on any topic; the protection is not offense-specific. This contrasts with the Sixth Amendment right to counsel, which is offense-specific and attaches only once formal adversarial judicial proceedings—such as indictment, arraignment, or formal charging—have begun. If, after invoking counsel, the accused initiates communication with the police, interrogation may resume, but only if the accused validly waives Miranda rights under the knowing and voluntary standard.
cards.mnemonic: Counsel call cuts ALL: Fifth = all topics; Sixth = specific charges only.
cards.clozeLite: If a suspect in {{c1::custody}} clearly asks for a {{c2::lawyer}}, police must stop {{c3::all questioning on any subject}}. This Fifth Amendment counsel right is {{c4::not offense-specific}}, unlike the {{c5::Sixth Amendment}} right.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Miranda Waiver – Knowing, Voluntary, and Burden of Proof
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 021-3. Miranda Waiver – Knowing, Voluntary, and Burden of Proof
cards.front: Miranda Waiver – Knowing, Voluntary, and Burden of Proof
cards.backPlain: Waiving Miranda Rights 1. Requirements for a valid waiver 1.1. A valid Miranda waiver must be: 1.1.1. Knowingly made; and 1.1.2. Voluntarily made. 2. Form of waiver 2.1. The waiver may be express (e.g., explicit written or oral statement) or implied from the suspect’s conduct (e.g., answering questions after receiving warnings). 2.2. In any form, the waiver must still satisfy the knowing and voluntary standard. 3. Burden of proof 3.1. The burden is on the prosecution to prove a valid Miranda waiver. 3.2. The standard of proof is a preponderance of the evidence.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for a valid Miranda waiver, and who bears the burden of proving it?
cards.cloze: Waiving Miranda Rights 1. A valid Miranda waiver must be {{c1::knowing}} and {{c2::voluntary}}. 2. The waiver may be {{c3::express}} or {{c4::implied}} from the suspect’s conduct, but in either case must satisfy the {{c5::knowing and voluntary}} standard. 3. The burden is on the {{c6::prosecution}} to prove a valid waiver by a {{c7::preponderance of the evidence}}.
cards.easyContent: A Miranda waiver must be knowing and voluntary, can be express or implied, and the prosecution must prove its validity by a preponderance of the evidence.
cards.mediumContent: To be valid, a Miranda waiver must be both knowing and voluntary. It can be given expressly—such as a written or oral statement—or implied from the suspect’s conduct, such as answering questions after warnings. Regardless of form, it must meet the knowing and voluntary standard, and the prosecution bears the burden of proving a valid waiver by a preponderance of the evidence.
cards.hardContent: A Miranda waiver is valid only if made knowingly and voluntarily. A knowing waiver requires that the suspect understand the rights and the consequences of abandoning them; a voluntary waiver requires that the decision to waive be the product of a free and deliberate choice, not coercion or improper pressure. The waiver may be express, such as a written waiver form, or implied, as when a suspect who has received and understood Miranda warnings proceeds to answer questions. In either case, the waiver must satisfy the knowing and voluntary criteria. The prosecution bears the burden of establishing a valid waiver by a preponderance of the evidence.
cards.mnemonic: Waiver = K + V; P by >50% (preponderance).
cards.clozeLite: A valid {{c1::Miranda waiver}} must be {{c2::knowing}} and {{c3::voluntary}}, may be {{c4::express or implied}}, and {{c5::prosecution}} must prove it by {{c6::preponderance of the evidence}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fourteenth Amendment Due Process – Voluntariness of Confessions
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 021-4. Fourteenth Amendment Due Process – Voluntariness of Confessions
cards.front: Fourteenth Amendment Due Process – Voluntariness of Confessions
cards.backPlain: Fourteenth Amendment and Confessions 1. Independent due process requirement 1.1. Independently of Miranda, the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause requires that confessions be voluntary to be admissible. 2. Voluntariness standard 2.1. Voluntariness is assessed under the totality of the circumstances. 2.2. Relevant factors include, among others: 2.2.1. The suspect's age; 2.2.2. The suspect's mental and physical condition; 2.2.3. The suspect's education; and 2.2.4. The duration, manner, and setting of the interrogation.
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause require for a confession to be admissible, and how is voluntariness evaluated?
cards.cloze: Fourteenth Amendment and Confessions 1. Independently of Miranda, the {{c1::Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause}} requires that confessions be {{c2::voluntary}} to be admissible. 2. Voluntariness is assessed under the {{c3::totality of the circumstances}}, considering factors such as the suspect's {{c4::age}}, {{c5::mental and physical condition}}, {{c6::education}}, and the {{c7::duration, manner, and setting}} of the interrogation.
cards.easyContent: Even if Miranda is satisfied, due process still requires that a confession be voluntary under the totality of the circumstances to be admissible.
cards.mediumContent: The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause independently bars involuntary confessions, regardless of Miranda compliance. Courts look to the totality of the circumstances, including the suspect’s age, mental and physical condition, education, and the duration, manner, and setting of the interrogation, to determine whether the confession was the product of free will or coercion.
cards.hardContent: Apart from Miranda, the Fourteenth Amendment’s Due Process Clause requires that confessions admitted at trial be voluntary. Voluntariness is evaluated under a totality of the circumstances test that examines whether the suspect’s will was overborne by police conduct. Relevant considerations include the suspect’s age, mental and physical condition, level of education and intelligence, and the duration, manner, and setting of the interrogation, including any threats, promises, or psychological pressures. A confession found involuntary under this standard is inadmissible, even if Miranda warnings were properly given and waived.
cards.mnemonic: VOL: Voluntary under Overall Look (totality) at circumstances.
cards.clozeLite: Due process {{c1::independently bars involuntary confessions}}, applying a {{c2::totality of the circumstances}} test to see if {{c3::police overbore the suspect’s will}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Double Jeopardy – Core Rule and Same-Elements Test
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 022-1. Double Jeopardy – Core Rule and Same-Elements Test
cards.front: Double Jeopardy – Core Rule & Same-Elements Test
cards.backPlain: 1. General Double Jeopardy rule 1.1. A defendant cannot be retried for the same offense once jeopardy has attached. 1.2. Double jeopardy issues arise when a defendant is prosecuted for one crime and tried, then later charged again based on the same offense. 2. Same offense (Blockburger) test 2.1. Two offenses are different if conviction for one offense requires proof of an element not included in the other offense. 2.2. This is the same-elements (Blockburger) test: if each offense contains an element the other does not, they are different offenses; if not, they are the same offense for Double Jeopardy purposes.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the core Double Jeopardy rule, and how does the same-elements (Blockburger) test define when two offenses are the "same offense"?
cards.cloze: 1. General Double Jeopardy rule 1.1. A defendant cannot be retried for the {{c1::same offense}} once {{c2::jeopardy has attached}}. 1.2. Double jeopardy issues arise when a defendant is prosecuted for one crime and tried, then later charged again based on the {{c1::same offense}}. 2. Same offense (Blockburger) test 2.1. Two offenses are different if conviction for one offense requires proof of an {{c3::element not included}} in the other offense. 2.2. This is the {{c4::same-elements (Blockburger) test}}: if each offense contains an {{c5::element the other does not}}, they are {{c6::different offenses}}; if not, they are the {{c7::same offense}} for Double Jeopardy purposes.
cards.easyContent: Double Jeopardy bars a second trial for the same offense once jeopardy attaches. Under the Blockburger same-elements test, two crimes are different only if each has an element the other does not.
cards.mediumContent: Double Jeopardy prohibits reprosecution for the same offense after jeopardy attaches. Whether two charges are the same offense is determined by the same-elements (Blockburger) test: the offenses are different only if each requires proof of an element the other does not; otherwise, they are the same offense and a second prosecution is barred.
cards.hardContent: Double Jeopardy prevents a defendant from being tried again for the same offense once jeopardy has attached. When a defendant is tried for one crime and the state later seeks to bring a new charge based on the same conduct, courts apply the same-elements (Blockburger) test. Under this test, two offenses are considered different only if each requires proof of an element that the other does not. If one offense does not contain any element that the other lacks, they are treated as the same offense for Double Jeopardy purposes and a later prosecution is barred.
cards.mnemonic: Blockburger: each crime needs its own "block" element.
cards.clozeLite: Double Jeopardy {{c1::bars reprosecution}} for the {{c2::same offense}} once {{c3::jeopardy attaches}}. Under {{c4::Blockburger}}, offenses differ only if {{c5::each requires a unique element}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Double Jeopardy – Lesser-Included Offenses and Offense Comparisons
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 022-2. Double Jeopardy – Lesser-Included Offenses and Offense Comparisons
cards.front: Double Jeopardy – Lesser-Included Offenses & Examples
cards.backPlain: 1. Lesser-included offenses and merger 1.1. Lesser-included offenses: once jeopardy attaches for the greater offense, the defendant cannot later be prosecuted for a lesser-included offense based on the same conduct. 2. Examples of same vs. different offense 2.1. Same offense example: First offense requires proof of A, B, and C; second offense requires proof of A and B only. The second offense is a lesser-included offense and is barred as the same offense. 2.2. Different offense example: First offense requires proof of A and B; second offense requires proof of A, C, and D. Each offense contains an element the other does not, so they are different offenses and Double Jeopardy does not bar the second prosecution.
cards.frontPrompt: How does Double Jeopardy treat lesser-included offenses, and what examples illustrate when two offenses are the same or different?
cards.cloze: 1. Lesser-included offenses and merger 1.1. {{c1::Lesser-included offenses}}: once jeopardy attaches for the {{c2::greater offense}}, the defendant cannot later be prosecuted for a {{c1::lesser-included offense}} based on the same conduct. 2. Examples of same vs. different offense 2.1. {{c3::Same offense}} example: First offense requires proof of {{c4::A, B, and C}}; second offense requires proof of {{c5::A and B}} only. The second offense is a {{c6::lesser-included offense}} and is barred as the same offense. 2.2. {{c7::Different offense}} example: First offense requires proof of {{c8::A and B}}; second offense requires proof of {{c9::A, C, and D}}. Each offense contains an {{c10::element the other does not}}, so they are {{c11::different offenses}} and Double Jeopardy does not bar the second prosecution.
cards.easyContent: If a defendant has been tried for a greater offense, the state cannot later prosecute a lesser-included offense from the same conduct. If one crime’s elements are fully contained in another, it’s the same offense; if each crime has an element the other doesn’t, they are different offenses.
cards.mediumContent: Under Double Jeopardy, lesser-included offenses merge into the greater: once jeopardy attaches for the greater offense, later prosecution for the lesser is barred. If crime 1 requires A, B, C and crime 2 requires only A and B, crime 2 is a lesser-included offense and barred. If crime 1 requires A, B and crime 2 requires A, C, D, each offense has at least one element the other lacks, so they are different offenses and a later prosecution is allowed.
cards.hardContent: Double Jeopardy prevents later prosecution for lesser-included offenses once jeopardy has attached for the greater offense on the same conduct. A lesser-included offense is one whose elements are entirely subsumed within the greater. For example, if the first offense requires proof of A, B, and C and the second offense requires proof of only A and B, the second offense is a lesser-included offense and constitutes the same offense, so a later prosecution is barred. By contrast, if the first offense requires A and B and the second requires A, C, and D, each contains an element the other does not, so they are different offenses and Double Jeopardy does not prevent a second prosecution.
cards.mnemonic: If #2 fits inside #1, #2 merges and is barred.
cards.clozeLite: Under Double Jeopardy, {{c1::lesser-included offenses merge into the greater}}: once {{c2::jeopardy attaches for the greater offense}}, {{c3::later prosecution for the lesser}} is barred.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Double Jeopardy – Attachment and Exceptions for Greater Offenses
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 022-3. Double Jeopardy – Attachment and Exceptions for Greater Offenses
cards.front: Double Jeopardy – When Jeopardy Attaches & Greater-Offense Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 1. When jeopardy attaches 1.1. Jeopardy generally attaches at the start of trial proceedings. 1.2. Jeopardy does not attach merely from the filing of charges or from grand jury proceedings alone. 1.3. In a jury trial, jeopardy attaches once the jury is impaneled and sworn. 1.4. In a bench trial, jeopardy attaches once the first witness is sworn. 1.5. In plea proceedings, jeopardy attaches once the court accepts a guilty plea. 2. Exceptions allowing later prosecution for a greater offense 2.1. New evidence for a greater offense becomes available after the first trial. 2.2. The defendant may be tried for battery and later tried for homicide if the victim subsequently dies from the battery, because the greater offense (homicide) was not complete at the time of the first prosecution for battery.
cards.frontPrompt: When does jeopardy attach in jury trials, bench trials, and plea proceedings, and what exceptions allow a later prosecution for a greater offense like homicide after battery?
cards.cloze: 1. When jeopardy attaches 1.1. Jeopardy generally attaches at the {{c1::start of trial proceedings}}. 1.2. Jeopardy does {{c2::not}} attach merely from the {{c3::filing of charges}} or from {{c4::grand jury proceedings}} alone. 1.3. In a {{c5::jury trial}}, jeopardy attaches once the jury is {{c6::impaneled and sworn}}. 1.4. In a {{c7::bench trial}}, jeopardy attaches once the {{c8::first witness is sworn}}. 1.5. In {{c9::plea proceedings}}, jeopardy attaches once the court {{c10::accepts a guilty plea}}. 2. Exceptions allowing later prosecution for a greater offense 2.1. {{c11::New evidence}} for a greater offense becomes available after the first trial. 2.2. The defendant may be tried for {{c12::battery}} and later tried for {{c13::homicide}} if the victim subsequently {{c14::dies}} from the battery, because the greater offense was {{c15::not complete}} at the time of the first prosecution.
cards.easyContent: Jeopardy attaches at the start of the case: when the jury is sworn in a jury trial, when the first witness is sworn in a bench trial, or when a guilty plea is accepted; it does not attach just from charging or a grand jury. Later prosecution for a greater offense is allowed if new evidence appears or the greater offense wasn’t complete yet, like homicide after the victim later dies from a battery.
cards.mediumContent: Jeopardy attaches at the commencement of the adjudicative phase: when the jury is impaneled and sworn in a jury trial, when the first witness is sworn in a bench trial, and when the court accepts a guilty plea. Merely filing charges or obtaining an indictment is not enough. Despite attachment, Double Jeopardy permits later prosecution for a greater offense when new evidence arises or when the greater offense was not complete at the time of the earlier case, such as allowing a homicide prosecution after a prior battery case if the victim later dies from the same conduct.
cards.hardContent: Jeopardy attaches at the start of trial proceedings—not at charging or indictment. In a jury trial, attachment occurs when the jury is impaneled and sworn. In a bench trial, attachment occurs when the first witness is sworn. In plea proceedings, attachment occurs when the court formally accepts a guilty plea. These attachment points trigger Double Jeopardy protection, but do not absolutely bar all later prosecutions. Exceptions allow later prosecution for a greater offense when the greater offense was not yet complete or when new evidence emerges. A classic example is where the defendant is tried for battery, and only later does the victim die from that battery: the state may then prosecute for homicide because the homicide offense was not complete at the time of the original battery prosecution.
cards.mnemonic: Attachment JBP: Jury sworn, Bench first witness, Plea accepted; then battery-to-body allows homicide.
cards.clozeLite: Jeopardy attaches in {{c1::jury trials when the jury is impaneled and sworn}}, in {{c2::bench trials when the first witness is sworn}}, and in {{c3::pleas when the guilty plea is accepted}}; a later {{c4::homicide}} case is allowed if the victim {{c5::later dies from the same battery}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Sixth Amendment Right to Counsel – Attachment, Critical Stages, and Scope
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 024-1. Sixth Amendment Right to Counsel – Attachment, Critical Stages, and Scope
cards.front: Sixth Amendment Right to Counsel – Attachment, Critical Stages, and Scope
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Sixth Amendment right to counsel attach, what stages does it cover, and what does it bar police from doing regarding the charged offense?
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1. Once the Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches, police may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements from the defendant about the charged offense outside the presence of counsel. 2. Attachment and application 2.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches once formal charges have been filed (such as indictment, information, or arraignment). 2.2. It applies to all subsequent critical stages of the judicial proceedings. 3. Scope of the Sixth Amendment right 3.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is offense-specific. 3.2. Police may question the defendant about any other uncharged crimes without violating the defendant's Sixth Amendment rights.
cards.cloze: 1. General rule 1.1. Once the {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} attaches, police may not {{c2::deliberately elicit incriminating statements}} from the defendant about the {{c3::charged offense}} outside the presence of counsel. 2. Attachment and application 2.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches once {{c4::formal charges have been filed}} (such as {{c5::indictment, information, or arraignment}}). 2.2. It applies to all subsequent {{c6::critical stages}} of the judicial proceedings. 3. Scope of the Sixth Amendment right 3.1. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is {{c7::offense-specific}}. 3.2. Police may question the defendant about any other {{c8::uncharged crimes}} without violating the defendant's Sixth Amendment rights.
cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel automatically attaches when formal charges are filed, applies at all later critical stages, and bars deliberate police elicitation about the charged offense without counsel. It is offense-specific, so it does not bar questioning about unrelated uncharged crimes.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel attaches when formal adversarial proceedings begin—by indictment, information, arraignment, or similar charging event—and then applies at all subsequent critical stages of the prosecution. After attachment, police may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements about the charged offense outside the presence of counsel. The right is offense-specific, so it restricts questioning only as to the charged crime; officers may still ask about unrelated, uncharged offenses without violating the Sixth Amendment.
cards.hardContent: Once formal criminal charges are filed—through indictment, information, arraignment, or a similar event—the Sixth Amendment right to counsel automatically attaches. From that point forward, it protects the defendant at all subsequent critical stages of the prosecution, including proceedings where substantial rights may be affected. After attachment, the government may not deliberately elicit incriminating statements about the charged offense from the defendant in the absence of counsel. The protection is offense-specific: it applies only to the crime with which the defendant has been formally charged. Accordingly, police remain free under the Sixth Amendment (though other doctrines may apply) to question the defendant about separate, uncharged crimes, even after the right has attached for the charged offense.
cards.mnemonic: SIXTH: Starts at Indictment, eXcludes Talk re Here-charged crime.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} attaches at {{c2::formal adversarial proceedings}} and applies at all later {{c3::critical stages}}. It bars {{c4::deliberate elicitation about the charged offense}} and is {{c5::offense-specific}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Fifth vs. Sixth Amendment Rights to Counsel – Comparison
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 024-2. Fifth vs. Sixth Amendment Rights to Counsel – Comparison
cards.front: Fifth vs. Sixth Amendment Rights to Counsel – Comparison
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel differ from the Sixth Amendment right to counsel in terms of how they arise and their offense-specific nature?
cards.backPlain: 1. Fifth Amendment right to counsel (Miranda) 1.1. Not automatic: the accused must invoke this right by unambiguously requesting the presence of counsel during custodial interrogation. 1.2. Not offense-specific: once invoked, police must stop questioning on all subjects. 2. Sixth Amendment right to counsel 2.1. Automatic: attaches once formal charges have been filed and applies at all subsequent critical stages. 2.2. Offense-specific: police may still question the defendant about other, uncharged crimes.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Fifth Amendment}} right to counsel ({{c2::Miranda}}) 1.1. {{c3::Not automatic}}: the accused must invoke this right by {{c4::unambiguously requesting}} the presence of counsel during {{c5::custodial interrogation}}. 1.2. {{c6::Not offense-specific}}: once invoked, police must stop questioning on {{c7::all subjects}}. 2. {{c8::Sixth Amendment}} right to counsel 2.1. {{c9::Automatic}}: attaches once {{c10::formal charges have been filed}} and applies at all subsequent {{c11::critical stages}}. 2.2. {{c12::Offense-specific}}: police may still question the defendant about {{c13::other, uncharged crimes}}.
cards.easyContent: The Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel is not automatic; it must be clearly invoked during custodial interrogation and then bars questioning on any topic. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel is automatic after formal charges, applies at critical stages, and is offense-specific.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Fifth Amendment, the Miranda right to counsel arises only during custodial interrogation and only if the suspect unambiguously requests a lawyer; once invoked, it is not offense-specific and forbids police questioning on any subject. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel, by contrast, automatically attaches when formal charges are filed and applies at all subsequent critical stages, but it is offense-specific, limiting questioning about the charged offense while still allowing questioning on unrelated, uncharged crimes.
cards.hardContent: The Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel is a prophylactic safeguard during custodial interrogation. It is not automatic: the suspect must clearly and unambiguously request counsel, at which point police must cease interrogating about any subject; the protection is not offense-specific. The Sixth Amendment right to counsel, however, is a constitutional trial right that automatically attaches when formal adversarial proceedings begin—through indictment, information, arraignment, or a similar charging event—and applies at all subsequent critical stages. Unlike Miranda, it is offense-specific: it forecloses uncounseled deliberate elicitation only as to the charged offense, allowing officers to question the defendant about other, uncharged crimes (subject to other constitutional limits).
cards.mnemonic: Fifth: you ask, stops all talk. Sixth: charges start, tied to charge.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Fifth Amendment Miranda right to counsel}} arises only if {{c2::unambiguously invoked in custodial interrogation}} and is {{c3::not offense-specific}}. The {{c4::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} {{c5::automatically attaches at formal charges}} and is {{c6::offense-specific}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Sixth Amendment – Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 024-3. Sixth Amendment – Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
cards.front: Sixth Amendment – Ineffective Assistance of Counsel
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Sixth Amendment require to show ineffective assistance of counsel on appeal?
cards.backPlain: 1. Right to effective assistance of counsel 1.1. The Sixth Amendment includes the right to effective assistance of counsel. 2. Ineffective assistance standard 2.1. To establish ineffective assistance of counsel on appeal, the defendant must show: 2.1.1. Deficient performance by counsel; and 2.1.2. A reasonable probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different absent counsel's deficient performance.
cards.cloze: 1. Right to {{c1::effective assistance of counsel}} 1.1. The {{c2::Sixth Amendment}} includes the right to effective assistance of counsel. 2. Ineffective assistance standard 2.1. To establish ineffective assistance of counsel on appeal, the defendant must show: 2.1.1. {{c3::Deficient performance}} by counsel; and 2.1.2. A {{c4::reasonable probability}} that the outcome of the trial would have been different absent counsel's {{c5::deficient performance}}.
cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment guarantees effective assistance of counsel. Ineffective assistance on appeal requires deficient performance and a reasonable probability that, without that deficiency, the trial outcome would have been different.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel includes a right to effective assistance. On appeal, a defendant claiming ineffective assistance must show that counsel's performance was deficient under prevailing professional norms and that this deficiency prejudiced the defense—meaning there is a reasonable probability that the result of the trial would have been different but for counsel's errors.
cards.hardContent: Embedded in the Sixth Amendment right to counsel is a guarantee of effective assistance. A defendant seeking reversal on grounds of ineffective assistance must satisfy a two-prong test: (1) deficient performance—counsel's representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness under prevailing professional norms; and (2) prejudice—a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's unprofessional errors, the outcome of the trial or proceeding would have been different. A mere showing of error or poor strategy is insufficient without the requisite showing of prejudice to the result.
cards.mnemonic: IAC is "DP + RP": Deficient Performance plus Reasonable Probability of different result.
cards.clozeLite: Ineffective assistance on appeal requires {{c1::deficient performance}} and {{c2::prejudice}}—a {{c3::reasonable probability}} the {{c4::trial result would differ but for errors}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Right to Counsel
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 025-1. Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Right to Counsel
cards.front: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Right to Counsel
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Sixth Amendment right to counsel apply to pretrial lineups and showups, and what types of identification procedures are excluded?
cards.backPlain: 1. Right to counsel at pretrial identifications 1.1 A suspect has a Sixth Amendment right to counsel at any post-charge, in-person lineup or showup. 1.2 The right to counsel does not apply to non-live identification procedures, such as: - Photographic lineups (photo arrays) - Fingerprinting or other physical/forensic identification procedures 1.3 Definitions: - Lineup: A witness is shown several possible suspects. - Showup: A witness is asked to identify a single suspect.
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} at pretrial identifications 1.1 A suspect has a right to counsel at any {{c2::post-charge, in-person lineup or showup}}. 1.2 This right {{c3::does not apply}} to {{c4::non-live identification procedures}}, such as {{c5::photographic lineups}} or {{c6::fingerprinting}}. 1.3 A {{c7::lineup}} is when a witness is shown {{c8::several possible suspects}}. 1.4 A {{c9::showup}} is when a witness is asked to identify {{c10::a single suspect}}.
cards.easyContent: After formal charges, a suspect has a right to counsel at in-person lineups and showups, but not at non-live procedures like photo arrays or fingerprinting.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment right to counsel applies to any post-charge, in-person lineup or showup. It does not apply to non-live identification procedures, including photographic lineups and forensic procedures like fingerprinting. A lineup presents several possible suspects to the witness, whereas a showup asks the witness to identify a single suspect.
cards.hardContent: Once formal charges have been filed, the accused has a Sixth Amendment right to counsel at any critical stage of the prosecution, which includes post-charge, in-person lineups and showups. Counsel must be permitted to be present during these live identifications. This right does not extend to non-live identification procedures such as photographic lineups (photo arrays), fingerprinting, or other forensic testing. A lineup exposes the witness to several individuals (including the suspect), whereas a showup involves presenting a single suspect to the witness for identification.
cards.mnemonic: Post-charge, in-person, lawyer in the room.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Sixth Amendment right to counsel}} applies to {{c2::post-charge, in-person lineups and showups}}, but not to {{c3::non-live procedures like photo arrays or fingerprinting}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Due Process Challenges
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 025-2. Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Due Process Challenges
cards.front: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Due Process Challenges
cards.frontPrompt: On what basis can a defendant attack pretrial identification procedures under due process, and how demanding is this standard?
cards.backPlain: 2. Due process considerations for pretrial identifications 2.1 A defendant can attack pretrial identification procedures as a denial of due process if: - The identification procedure is unnecessarily suggestive; and - There is a substantial likelihood of misidentification. 2.2 Whether due process is violated is determined under the totality of the circumstances. 2.3 This is a tough standard; the procedure must be extremely suggestive. 2.4 Example: If the perpetrator is believed to be male and the suspect is the only male in the lineup, the procedure would likely violate due process.
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Due process}} considerations for pretrial identifications 2.1 A defendant can attack a pretrial identification as a denial of due process if it is {{c2::unnecessarily suggestive}} and there is a {{c3::substantial likelihood of misidentification}}. 2.2 Courts assess this under the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 2.3 This is a {{c5::demanding}} standard; the procedure must be {{c6::extremely suggestive}}. 2.4 Example: Due process is likely violated if the perpetrator is believed to be {{c7::male}} and the defendant is the {{c8::only male in the lineup}}.
cards.easyContent: A defendant can claim a due process violation if the identification procedure is unnecessarily suggestive and creates a substantial likelihood of misidentification, judged under the totality of the circumstances and applied very strictly.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Due Process Clause, a defendant can challenge a pretrial identification if the procedure is unnecessarily suggestive and creates a substantial likelihood of misidentification. Courts look at the totality of the circumstances, and the standard is demanding—only extremely suggestive procedures, such as making the defendant the only person matching the basic description, typically qualify.
cards.hardContent: Due process limits apply to any pretrial identification procedure, whether live or not. A defendant may attack the procedure if it is unnecessarily suggestive and creates a substantial likelihood of misidentification. Courts evaluate this claim under the totality of the circumstances, considering factors like the witness’s opportunity to view the perpetrator, degree of attention, accuracy of prior description, level of certainty, and time between the crime and confrontation. The bar is high: the procedure must be extremely suggestive, such as a lineup where the defendant is the only person matching the perpetrator’s basic description (e.g., only male in the lineup when the perpetrator was clearly male).
cards.mnemonic: DUES: Due process, Unnecessary, Extremely suggestive, Substantial misidentification risk.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::Due Process}}, a defendant can attack a pretrial ID if it is {{c2::unnecessarily suggestive}} and creates a {{c3::substantial likelihood of misidentification}}—a {{c4::very demanding}} standard.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Remedy and Independent Source
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 025-3. Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Remedy and Independent Source
cards.front: Pretrial Lineups and Showups – Remedy and Independent Source
cards.frontPrompt: What is the usual remedy for unconstitutional pretrial identification procedures, and how can the government avoid exclusion?
cards.backPlain: 3. Remedy for unconstitutional pretrial identifications 3.1 If a pretrial identification violates the right to counsel or due process, the defendant may move to suppress any subsequent in-trial identifications made by the witness. 3.2 However, suppression is rare because the government can often prove that the identifying witness has an independent source of identification sufficient to overcome the exclusionary rule. 3.3 Independent source doctrine: - Even if the pretrial procedure was unconstitutional, an in-court identification is admissible if the prosecution shows it is based on the witness’s independent recollection (e.g., observations at the time of the crime), not tainted by the improper procedure.
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Remedy}} for unconstitutional pretrial identifications 3.1 The defendant may move to {{c2::suppress}} any subsequent {{c3::in-trial (in-court) identifications}} made by the witness. 3.2 Suppression is {{c4::rare}}, because the government can often show an {{c5::independent source}} for the witness’s in-court identification. 3.3 Under the {{c6::independent source doctrine}}, an in-court identification is admissible if it rests on the witness’s {{c7::independent recollection}} (e.g., observations at the time of the crime) rather than the tainted pretrial procedure.
cards.easyContent: The main remedy is a motion to suppress the witness’s in-court identification, but courts often admit it anyway if the government proves the witness has an independent source for recognizing the defendant.
cards.mediumContent: If a pretrial lineup or showup violates the right to counsel or due process, the defendant can seek to suppress the witness’s in-court identification. Suppression is uncommon, because the government can usually argue that the witness’s identification has an independent source—such as their original observations during the crime—so the in-court identification is not tainted by the illegal procedure.
cards.hardContent: When a pretrial identification procedure is found unconstitutional (for violating the Sixth Amendment right to counsel or due process), the primary remedy is exclusion of any in-court identification by that witness. The defendant moves to suppress the in-trial identification as fruit of the tainted pretrial procedure. However, suppression is relatively rare because the prosecution can salvage the in-court identification by establishing an independent source—proof that the witness’s ability to identify the defendant derives from their original observations at the crime (e.g., good lighting, extended opportunity to view, high degree of attention), rather than from the flawed pretrial identification. If the court is satisfied that this independent source exists, the in-court identification is admissible notwithstanding the earlier violation.
cards.mnemonic: Bad lineup? Block in-court ID—unless crime memories stand alone.
cards.clozeLite: Unconstitutional lineup? Remedy is {{c1::motion to suppress in-court ID}}, unless gov shows {{c2::independent source}} like {{c3::original crime observations}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Grand Jury – Constitutional Role and Indictments
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 026-1. Grand Jury – Constitutional Role and Indictments
