cards.front: Grand Jury – Constitutional Role and Indictments
cards.backPlain: 1. Constitutional role in federal court 1.1 The Fifth Amendment requires a grand jury indictment for most federal felony prosecutions. 1.2 The grand jury’s function is to determine whether there is sufficient probable cause to bring charges against a suspect. 2. Indictment process 2.1 The prosecutor presents evidence (witness testimony and other materials) to the grand jury. 2.2 The grand jury votes on whether to issue an indictment. 2.3 If the grand jury finds probable cause, it issues an indictment authorizing the government to proceed with prosecution. 3. Scope 3.1 The grand jury is a charging body, not a trial body: it does not determine guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, only whether there is probable cause to charge.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the constitutional role of the grand jury in federal felony cases, and how does the grand jury indictment process work?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Constitutional role in federal court}} 1.1 The {{c2::Fifth Amendment}} requires a {{c3::grand jury indictment}} for most {{c4::federal felony}} prosecutions. 1.2 The grand jury’s function is to determine whether there is sufficient {{c5::probable cause}} to bring charges against a suspect. 2. {{c6::Indictment process}} 2.1 The {{c7::prosecutor}} presents evidence (witness testimony and other materials) to the grand jury. 2.2 The grand jury {{c8::votes}} on whether to issue an indictment. 2.3 If the grand jury {{c9::finds probable cause}}, it issues an {{c10::indictment}} authorizing the government to proceed with prosecution. 3. {{c11::Scope}} 3.1 The grand jury is a {{c12::charging body, not a trial body}}: it does not determine {{c13::guilt beyond a reasonable doubt}}, only whether there is {{c14::probable cause}} to charge.
cards.easyContent: In federal felony cases, the Fifth Amendment generally requires a grand jury to decide if there is probable cause to bring charges. The prosecutor presents evidence, and if the grand jury finds probable cause, it issues an indictment authorizing prosecution.
cards.mediumContent: The Fifth Amendment requires a grand jury indictment in most federal felony prosecutions. The grand jury’s constitutional role is to act as a charging body that determines whether there is probable cause to accuse someone of a crime. The prosecutor presents evidence, the grand jury votes, and if it finds probable cause, it issues an indictment. The grand jury does not decide guilt beyond a reasonable doubt—it only authorizes the government to proceed with charges.
cards.hardContent: Under the Fifth Amendment, most federal felony prosecutions must begin with a grand jury indictment. The grand jury serves as a buffer between the prosecutor and the accused by assessing whether there is sufficient probable cause to justify formal charges. During this process, the prosecutor presents evidence—such as witness testimony and documents—to the grand jurors, who then deliberate and vote on whether to return an indictment. If they find probable cause, they issue an indictment that authorizes the government to initiate a criminal prosecution. The grand jury’s authority is limited to deciding whether to charge; it does not adjudicate guilt or innocence, which is reserved for the trial process under the beyond-a-reasonable-doubt standard.
cards.mnemonic: GCP: Grand jury Checks Probable cause, not guilt.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Fifth Amendment}} generally requires a {{c2::grand jury indictment}} for {{c3::federal felonies}} to find {{c4::probable cause}} and {{c5::authorize charges}}, not decide guilt.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Grand Jury – Procedural Rules and Witness Rights
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 026-2. Grand Jury – Procedural Rules and Witness Rights
cards.front: Grand Jury – Procedural Rules and Witness Rights
cards.backPlain: 1. Secrecy 1.1 Grand jury proceedings are conducted in secret. 2. Suspect’s rights 2.1 The suspect (target) has no right to attend grand jury proceedings. 2.2 The suspect has no right to confront or cross-examine witnesses before the grand jury. 3. Witness rights and limits 3.1 Witnesses are not entitled to Miranda warnings because the grand jury is not considered custodial interrogation. 3.2 Witnesses may not challenge a subpoena to testify before the grand jury on the ground that the government lacks probable cause or is using inadmissible evidence. 3.3 Witnesses do not have a right to counsel inside the grand jury room. 3.4 Witnesses may, however, leave the grand jury room to consult with counsel outside before answering questions.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the key procedural rules governing federal grand jury proceedings, and what rights do the suspect and witnesses have (and lack) during those proceedings?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Secrecy}} 1.1 Grand jury proceedings are conducted in {{c2::secret}}. 2. {{c3::Suspect’s rights}} 2.1 The suspect (target) has **no right** to {{c4::attend}} grand jury proceedings. 2.2 The suspect has **no right** to {{c5::confront or cross-examine witnesses}} before the grand jury. 3. {{c6::Witness rights and limits}} 3.1 Witnesses are **not entitled** to {{c7::Miranda warnings}} because the grand jury is not considered {{c8::custodial interrogation}}. 3.2 Witnesses may **not** {{c9::challenge a subpoena}} to testify before the grand jury on the ground that the government lacks probable cause or is using inadmissible evidence. 3.3 Witnesses do **not** have a {{c10::right to counsel inside the grand jury room}}. 3.4 Witnesses may, however, {{c11::leave the room to consult with counsel outside}} before answering questions.
cards.easyContent: Grand jury proceedings are secret. The suspect has no right to attend or confront witnesses, and witnesses get no Miranda warnings or counsel inside the room and generally cannot challenge subpoenas, though they can step out to consult a lawyer.
cards.mediumContent: Federal grand jury proceedings are conducted in secret. The suspect has no right to be present and no right to confront or cross-examine witnesses. Witnesses are not entitled to Miranda warnings because their testimony is not treated as custodial interrogation. They generally cannot challenge subpoenas to appear or testify based on probable-cause or evidentiary objections. Witnesses do not have a right to counsel inside the grand jury room, but they may leave the room to consult with counsel before answering questions.
cards.hardContent: Grand jury practice follows distinctive procedural rules. Proceedings are held in secret, both to protect the reputation of unindicted individuals and to encourage candid testimony. The suspect or target has no right to attend, observe, or confront witnesses; grand jury practice is not an adversarial mini-trial. Witnesses called before the grand jury are not entitled to Miranda warnings because questioning occurs outside the context of custodial interrogation. They generally cannot challenge the grand jury’s subpoena on grounds that the government lacks probable cause or is relying on evidence that would be inadmissible at trial. In addition, witnesses have no right to have counsel present inside the grand jury room while they testify, although they may step out to confer with their attorney between questions. These special rules underscore the investigative, rather than adjudicatory, nature of the grand jury.
cards.mnemonic: S-NOW: Secret, No suspect rights, Only limited witness protections, Warnings not required.
cards.clozeLite: Federal grand jury proceedings are {{c1::secret}}; the {{c2::suspect has no right to attend or confront witnesses}} and witnesses get {{c3::no Miranda warnings or counsel inside the room}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Grand Jury – Fifth Amendment Privilege, Immunity, and Exclusionary Rule
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 026-3. Grand Jury – Fifth Amendment Privilege, Immunity, and Exclusionary Rule
cards.front: Grand Jury – Fifth Amendment Privilege, Immunity, and Exclusionary Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. Fifth Amendment privilege 1.1 Witnesses before the grand jury may invoke the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination and refuse to answer questions that may incriminate them. 2. Immunity 2.1 Prosecutors may grant immunity to compel testimony. 2.2 Use or derivative-use immunity is sufficient: the government may not use the compelled testimony or any evidence derived from it against the witness in a later criminal case (except for perjury or false statements). 3. Exclusionary rule does not apply 3.1 The exclusionary rule does not apply to grand jury proceedings. 3.2 An indictment may be based on evidence that would be inadmissible at trial because it was obtained in violation of the Fourth, Fifth, or Sixth Amendments. 3.3 The remedy for unlawful evidence is generally suppression at trial, not dismissal of the indictment.
cards.frontPrompt: How do the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, grants of immunity, and the exclusionary rule operate in the context of federal grand jury proceedings?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Fifth Amendment privilege}} 1.1 Witnesses before the grand jury may invoke the {{c2::Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination}} and refuse to answer questions that may incriminate them. 2. {{c3::Immunity}} 2.1 Prosecutors may grant {{c4::immunity}} to compel testimony. 2.2 {{c5::Use or derivative-use immunity}} is sufficient: the government may not use the {{c6::compelled testimony}} or any {{c7::evidence derived from it}} against the witness in a later criminal case (except for {{c8::perjury or false statements}}). 3. {{c9::Exclusionary rule does not apply}} 3.1 The {{c10::exclusionary rule does not apply}} to grand jury proceedings. 3.2 An indictment may be based on evidence that would be {{c11::inadmissible at trial}} because it was obtained in violation of the {{c12::Fourth, Fifth, or Sixth Amendments}}. 3.3 The usual remedy for unlawful evidence is {{c13::suppression at trial}}, not {{c14::dismissal of the indictment}}.
cards.easyContent: Witnesses before a grand jury can claim the Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination, but prosecutors can grant use or derivative-use immunity to force testimony. The exclusionary rule does not apply at this stage, so an indictment can rest on evidence that would be suppressed at trial.
cards.mediumContent: In grand jury proceedings, witnesses may refuse to answer incriminating questions by invoking the Fifth Amendment privilege. Prosecutors can respond by granting immunity—most commonly use or derivative-use immunity—which bars the government from using the compelled testimony or its fruits against the witness in later prosecutions (other than for perjury). The exclusionary rule does not apply to grand jury proceedings, so an indictment can be based on evidence that would be inadmissible at trial due to constitutional violations, with the remedy being suppression of that evidence at trial rather than dismissal of the indictment.
cards.hardContent: The Fifth Amendment continues to protect witnesses in the grand jury context. Any witness may invoke the privilege against self-incrimination to avoid answering questions that may reasonably expose them to criminal liability. To overcome this, prosecutors may grant immunity—constitutionally, use and derivative-use immunity suffices, meaning the government cannot use the compelled statements or any evidence directly or indirectly derived from them against the witness in a subsequent criminal case, except in prosecutions for perjury or false statements. At the same time, the usual trial remedy for constitutional violations—the exclusionary rule—does not operate at the grand jury stage. Courts permit grand juries to consider evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth, Fifth, or Sixth Amendments, and will not dismiss an otherwise valid indictment merely because it relies on illegally obtained evidence. The typical remedy is suppression of that evidence at trial, not invalidation of the indictment.
cards.mnemonic: P-I-E: Plead Fifth, Immunity compels, Exclusionary paused at grand jury.
cards.clozeLite: In grand jury proceedings, witnesses may invoke the {{c1::Fifth Amendment privilege}}, overcome by {{c2::use or derivative-use immunity}}; the {{c3::exclusionary rule does not apply}} to indictments.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Pretrial (Preliminary) Hearing – Probable Cause to Detain
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 027-1. Pretrial (Preliminary) Hearing – Probable Cause to Detain
cards.front: Pretrial (Preliminary) Hearing – Probable Cause to Detain
cards.frontPrompt: When is a pretrial (preliminary) hearing required to determine probable cause to detain a suspect, and what is the timing requirement?
cards.backPlain: 1. Purpose of preliminary hearing 1.1 A pretrial (preliminary) hearing may be required to determine whether there is probable cause to detain the suspect. 2. When a preliminary hearing is required 2.1 A preliminary hearing is required if both of the following are true: 2.1.1 The defendant is incarcerated or released on bail (it is not required if the defendant is released only on the condition that she appear for trial), and 2.1.2 There has been no prior determination of probable cause. 3. Effect of prior probable cause determination 3.1 A preliminary hearing is not required if the arrest was made with a warrant, because a magistrate has already determined probable cause. 4. Timing 4.1 If a preliminary hearing is required, it must occur within 48 hours of detention.
cards.cloze: 1. Purpose of preliminary hearing 1.1 A pretrial (preliminary) hearing may be required to determine whether there is {{c1::probable cause}} to {{c2::detain}} the suspect. 2. When a preliminary hearing is required 2.1 A preliminary hearing is required if both of the following are true: 2.1.1 The defendant is {{c3::incarcerated or released on bail}} (it is not required if the defendant is released only on the condition that she appear for trial), and 2.1.2 There has been {{c4::no prior determination of probable cause}}. 3. Effect of prior probable cause determination 3.1 A preliminary hearing is {{c5::not required}} if the arrest was made with a {{c6::warrant}}, because a magistrate has already determined probable cause. 4. Timing 4.1 If a preliminary hearing is required, it must occur within {{c7::48 hours}} of detention.
cards.easyContent: A preliminary hearing to determine probable cause to detain is required when a defendant is in jail or on bail and no magistrate has yet found probable cause; if required, it must happen within 48 hours, and it is not needed if a warrant already supplied a probable cause finding.
cards.mediumContent: A pretrial (preliminary) hearing is used to decide whether there is probable cause to detain a suspect. It is required when the defendant is incarcerated or released on bail and there has been no prior ruling on probable cause; it is not required if the defendant is released only on a promise to appear or if a warrant arrest already involved a magistrate’s probable cause determination. When required, the hearing must occur within 48 hours of detention.
cards.hardContent: A pretrial (preliminary) hearing serves to determine whether probable cause exists to justify continued detention of a suspect. The hearing is constitutionally required when (1) the defendant is incarcerated or released on bail (as opposed to being released solely on the condition of appearing for trial), and (2) there has been no prior determination of probable cause. If the arrest was made pursuant to a warrant, a magistrate has already found probable cause, so no preliminary hearing is required on that basis. When a preliminary hearing is required, it must be held within 48 hours of the defendant’s detention.
cards.mnemonic: PC HEAR in 48 if Jailed or on bail, no prior PC.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::pretrial (preliminary) hearing}} to decide {{c2::probable cause to detain}} is required when {{c3::in jail or on bail with no prior PC ruling}} and must occur {{c4::within 48 hours of detention}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Bail – Constitutional Limits and Denial
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 027-2. Bail – Constitutional Limits and Denial
cards.front: Bail – Constitutional Limits and Denial
cards.frontPrompt: What are the constitutional limits on bail, when is detention without bail allowed, and what must the government show to justify denial of bail?
cards.backPlain: 1. Limits on amount of bail 1.1 Bail cannot be higher than necessary to ensure that the defendant will appear at trial. 2. Detention without bail 2.1 Detention without bail is constitutional. 2.2 However, a decision to refuse bail is immediately appealable. 3. Due process limits 3.1 Arbitrary denial of bail violates due process. 4. Grounds for denying bail 4.1 To justify denial of bail, the government must show either: 4.1.1 The defendant poses a flight risk, or 4.1.2 The defendant poses a danger to the community.
cards.cloze: 1. Limits on amount of bail 1.1 Bail cannot be higher than necessary to ensure that the defendant will {{c1::appear at trial}}. 2. Detention without bail 2.1 {{c2::Detention without bail is constitutional}}. 2.2 However, a decision to refuse bail is {{c3::immediately appealable}}. 3. Due process limits 3.1 {{c4::Arbitrary denial of bail}} violates {{c5::due process}}. 4. Grounds for denying bail 4.1 To justify denial of bail, the government must show either: 4.1.1 The defendant poses a {{c6::flight risk}}, or 4.1.2 The defendant poses a {{c7::danger to the community}}.
cards.easyContent: Bail must not be set higher than needed to ensure the defendant appears for trial, detention without bail is allowed but refusal of bail is immediately appealable, arbitrary denial of bail violates due process, and denial must be justified by flight risk or danger to the community.
cards.mediumContent: Constitutionally, bail may not exceed what is reasonably necessary to secure the defendant’s appearance at trial. Detention without bail is permitted, but any refusal to grant bail is immediately appealable, and arbitrary denial violates due process. To deny bail, the government must establish either that the defendant presents a flight risk or that the defendant poses a danger to the community.
cards.hardContent: Bail is subject to constitutional constraints: the amount may not be greater than necessary to ensure the defendant’s appearance at trial. Although detention without bail is permitted, a court’s decision to refuse bail altogether is immediately appealable, and arbitrary denial of bail violates due process protections. To justify withholding bail, the government bears the burden of demonstrating either that the defendant is a serious flight risk or that the defendant poses a danger to the community.
cards.mnemonic: Bail CAPD: Can’t exceed Appearance need; must show Flight risk or Danger.
cards.clozeLite: Bail cannot exceed what is {{c1::reasonably necessary to secure appearance}}; denial is {{c2::immediately appealable}} and needs {{c3::flight risk}} or {{c4::danger to the community}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Sixth Amendment Right to a Speedy Trial
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 027-3. Sixth Amendment Right to a Speedy Trial
cards.front: Sixth Amendment Right to a Speedy Trial
cards.frontPrompt: When does the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial attach, what factors determine a violation, and what is the remedy if the right is violated?
cards.backPlain: 1. Scope and attachment of the right 1.1 The Sixth Amendment protects the defendant from unreasonable delay between the time charges are filed and the beginning of trial. 1.2 The speedy-trial right attaches once the defendant has been arrested or formally charged. 2. Standard for violations 2.1 Whether the right has been violated is determined by the totality of the circumstances. 3. Factors (Barker v. Wingo) 3.1 Relevant factors include: 3.1.1 Length of delay, 3.1.2 Reason for delay (including whether the defendant caused or consented to the delay), 3.1.3 Whether the delay has prejudiced the defendant, and 3.1.4 Whether the defendant asserted the right. 4. Remedy 4.1 The remedy for a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial is dismissal of the case with prejudice.
cards.cloze: 1. Scope and attachment of the right 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} protects the defendant from {{c2::unreasonable delay}} between the time charges are filed and the beginning of trial. 1.2 The speedy-trial right attaches once the defendant has been {{c3::arrested or formally charged}}. 2. Standard for violations 2.1 Whether the right has been violated is determined by the {{c4::totality of the circumstances}}. 3. Factors (Barker v. Wingo) 3.1 Relevant factors include: 3.1.1 {{c5::Length of delay}}, 3.1.2 {{c6::Reason for delay}} (including whether the defendant caused or consented to the delay), 3.1.3 Whether the delay has {{c7::prejudiced the defendant}}, and 3.1.4 Whether the defendant {{c8::asserted the right}}. 4. Remedy 4.1 The remedy for a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial is {{c9::dismissal of the case with prejudice}}.
cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment speedy-trial right attaches once the defendant is arrested or formally charged and protects against unreasonable delay before trial; courts apply a totality-of-circumstances test using length of delay, reason for delay, prejudice, and assertion of the right, and the remedy for a violation is dismissal with prejudice.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment guarantees a speedy trial by protecting defendants from unreasonable delay between arrest or formal charge and trial. The right attaches at arrest or formal charging and is evaluated under the totality of the circumstances using the Barker factors: length of delay, reason for the delay (including the defendant’s role), prejudice to the defendant, and whether the defendant asserted the right. If a violation is found, the remedy is dismissal of the prosecution with prejudice.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial is triggered once a defendant is either arrested or formally charged and thereafter protects against unreasonable delay before trial. Courts assess alleged violations under a totality-of-the-circumstances framework articulated in Barker v. Wingo, considering (1) the length of the delay, (2) the reasons for the delay, including whether the government or the defendant is responsible, (3) the extent to which the delay has prejudiced the defendant (e.g., oppressive pretrial incarceration, anxiety, or impairment of the defense), and (4) whether and how vigorously the defendant asserted the right. If a court finds that the speedy-trial right has been violated, the exclusive remedy is dismissal of the case with prejudice, barring reprosecution on the same charges.
cards.mnemonic: Speedy LRPA: Length, Reason, Prejudice, Assertion.
cards.clozeLite: Speedy-trial right attaches at {{c1::arrest or formal charge}}; courts apply {{c2::Barker totality factors}} and remedy is {{c3::dismissal with prejudice}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Plea Bargains – Valid Guilty Plea Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 028-1. Plea Bargains – Valid Guilty Plea Requirements
cards.front: Plea Bargains – Valid Guilty Plea Requirements
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule 1.1 A defendant may enter a plea bargain, but doing so waives his Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. 1.2 For a valid plea bargain (guilty plea), the judge must: 1.2.1 Determine that the plea is voluntary and intelligently made, and 1.2.2 Ensure that the defendant understands: 1.2.2.1 The nature of the charge and its critical elements. 1.2.2.2 The maximum authorized penalty and any mandatory sentence. 1.2.2.3 That the defendant has a right to plead not guilty, and 1.2.2.4 That the defendant is waiving his right to a jury trial.
cards.frontPrompt: What constitutional right does a guilty plea waive, and what must the judge ensure for a plea bargain to be valid?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::General rule}} 1.1 A defendant may enter a plea bargain, but doing so waives his {{c2::Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial}}. 1.2 For a valid plea bargain, the judge must: 1.2.1 Determine that the plea is {{c3::voluntary and intelligently made}}, and 1.2.2 Ensure that the defendant understands: 1.2.2.1 The {{c4::nature of the charge and its critical elements}}. 1.2.2.2 The {{c5::maximum authorized penalty}} and any {{c6::mandatory sentence}}. 1.2.2.3 That the defendant has a right to {{c7::plead not guilty}}, and 1.2.2.4 That the defendant is {{c8::waiving his right to a jury trial}}.
cards.easyContent: By entering a plea bargain and pleading guilty, a defendant waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. The judge must ensure the plea is voluntary and intelligent and that the defendant understands the charge, penalties, the right to plead not guilty, and that he is waiving a jury trial.
cards.mediumContent: A guilty plea pursuant to a plea bargain waives the defendant’s Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. To be valid, the judge must determine that the plea is voluntary and intelligently made and must confirm that the defendant understands: (1) the nature and critical elements of the charge; (2) the maximum authorized penalty and any mandatory sentence; (3) the right to plead not guilty; and (4) that he is waiving his right to a jury trial.
cards.hardContent: A plea bargain permits the defendant to plead guilty in exchange for concessions, but entering such a plea waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial. For the plea to be constitutionally valid, the court must determine that it is voluntary and intelligently made—i.e., not coerced and entered with sufficient awareness. The judge must ensure that the defendant understands: (1) the nature of the charge and its critical elements; (2) the maximum possible penalty and any mandatory minimum or other mandatory sentence; (3) that he has the right to plead not guilty and persist in that plea; and (4) that, by pleading guilty, he is waiving his right to a jury trial.
cards.mnemonic: V-KNOW: Voluntary, Knowing of Elements, kNow penalties, Option not guilty, Waiver jury.
cards.clozeLite: A guilty plea {{c1::waives the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial}} and must be {{c2::voluntary and intelligent}} with the defendant understanding {{c3::charge elements}}, {{c4::maximum penalties}}, and {{c5::right to plead not guilty and waiver of jury}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Plea Bargains – Challenging a Guilty Plea
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 028-2. Plea Bargains – Challenging a Guilty Plea
cards.front: Plea Bargains – Challenging a Guilty Plea
cards.backPlain: 2. Challenging a plea 2.1 Appellate courts will not disturb valid pleas unless: 2.1.1 The plea was made involuntarily (e.g., due to a misunderstanding). 2.1.2 The court that took the plea lacked jurisdiction. 2.1.3 The defendant had ineffective assistance of counsel, or 2.1.4 The prosecutor failed to honor the plea agreement.
cards.frontPrompt: Once a guilty plea has been accepted as valid, on what limited grounds may it be set aside or disturbed on appeal?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::Challenging a plea}} 2.1 Appellate courts will not disturb valid pleas unless: 2.1.1 The plea was made {{c2::involuntarily}} (e.g., due to a misunderstanding). 2.1.2 The court that took the plea {{c3::lacked jurisdiction}}. 2.1.3 The defendant had {{c4::ineffective assistance of counsel}}, or 2.1.4 The {{c5::prosecutor failed to honor the plea agreement}}.
cards.easyContent: Once a guilty plea is validly accepted, appellate courts will disturb it only if it was involuntary, the court lacked jurisdiction, counsel was ineffective, or the prosecutor breached the plea agreement.
cards.mediumContent: A valid guilty plea is difficult to attack. Appellate courts will generally not disturb it except on narrow grounds: (1) the plea was involuntary (for example, based on misunderstanding or coercion); (2) the court that accepted the plea lacked jurisdiction; (3) the defendant received ineffective assistance of counsel in connection with the plea; or (4) the prosecutor failed to honor the plea agreement.
cards.hardContent: Once a court has found a guilty plea to be knowing, voluntary, and intelligent, the plea is typically final. Appellate or post-conviction courts will disturb such a plea only on limited grounds: (1) involuntariness, such as where the defendant misunderstood key consequences or was coerced; (2) lack of jurisdiction by the court that accepted the plea, rendering the conviction void; (3) ineffective assistance of counsel in advising about or negotiating the plea, under the usual Strickland prejudice standard; or (4) breach of the plea agreement by the prosecutor, which can justify specific performance, withdrawal of the plea, or other relief.
cards.mnemonic: To attack a plea, think "I JIB": Involuntary, court had no Jurisdiction, Ineffective counsel, Breach by prosecutor.
cards.clozeLite: A valid guilty plea is usually final; it’s disturbed only for {{c1::involuntariness}}, {{c2::lack of jurisdiction}}, {{c3::ineffective assistance of counsel}}, or {{c4::prosecutor’s breach of the plea agreement}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Plea Bargains – Contract Theory and Prosecutorial Leverage
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 028-3. Plea Bargains – Contract Theory and Prosecutorial Leverage
cards.front: Plea Bargains – Contract Theory and Prosecutorial Leverage
cards.backPlain: 3. Contract theory of plea bargaining 3.1 Plea agreements will be enforced against both parties, but the judge is not required to accept or adhere to the agreement. 3.2 The prosecutor can threaten the defendant with a more serious charge than he was initially facing and may follow through on that threat if the defendant does not accept the plea, so long as the prosecutor has probable cause.
cards.frontPrompt: How does contract theory apply to plea agreements, is the judge bound by the bargain, and what charging leverage does the prosecutor have?
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Contract theory of plea bargaining}} 3.1 Plea agreements will be {{c2::enforced against both parties}}, but the judge is {{c3::not required to accept or adhere to the agreement}}. 3.2 The prosecutor can {{c4::threaten the defendant with a more serious charge}} than he was initially facing and may {{c5::follow through on that threat}} if the defendant does not accept the plea, so long as the prosecutor has {{c6::probable cause}}.
cards.easyContent: Plea bargains are treated like contracts and are generally enforced against both sides, but the judge is not required to accept or follow the agreement. A prosecutor may threaten and file more serious charges if the defendant refuses the plea, as long as there is probable cause.
cards.mediumContent: Under contract theory, plea agreements are construed and enforced largely like contracts, binding both the defendant and the prosecutor. However, the judge is not a party to the contract and is not required to accept or follow the sentencing or charge recommendations in the agreement. Prosecutors may use charging leverage by threatening, and if necessary filing, more serious charges when a defendant declines a plea offer, provided there is probable cause to support the enhanced charges.
cards.hardContent: Plea agreements are analyzed under contract principles: terms are construed according to their plain meaning and, once a plea is accepted, both the defendant and the prosecutor can be held to their promises. The usual remedies include specific performance (e.g., resentencing before a different judge in accordance with the bargain) or allowing withdrawal of the plea. However, the trial judge is not bound to accept the plea or to impose the recommended sentence, because the judge is not a contracting party. Prosecutors may exert legitimate leverage by threatening to file, and by actually filing, more serious charges if the defendant refuses a plea offer, so long as the additional charges are supported by probable cause; this does not by itself render the plea involuntary.
cards.mnemonic: PD bound, J free; leverage limited by PC (Probable Cause).
cards.clozeLite: Plea agreements are {{c1::construed like contracts}} and bind {{c2::prosecutor and defendant}}, but {{c3::the judge is not bound}}. Prosecutors may {{c4::threaten or file more serious charges with probable cause}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Jury Trial Right – Sixth Amendment, Presence, and Serious Offense
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 030-1. Jury Trial Right – Sixth Amendment, Presence, and Serious Offense
cards.front: Jury Trial Right – Sixth Amendment, Presence, and Serious Offense
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Sixth Amendment guarantee regarding a jury trial in criminal prosecutions, when is a jury required, and what presence right does the defendant have?
cards.backPlain: 1. Sixth Amendment jury-trial right: - The Sixth Amendment provides a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions. 2. Right to be present at critical stages: - The defendant has a right to be present for all critical stages of the proceeding, including jury selection. 3. When a jury is required – serious offense: - A jury trial is required for a serious offense. - A serious offense is one for which the potential term of imprisonment exceeds 6 months.
cards.cloze: 1. Sixth Amendment jury-trial right: - The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} provides a right to a {{c2::jury trial in criminal prosecutions}}. 2. Right to be present at critical stages: - The defendant has a right to be {{c3::present for all critical stages}} of the proceeding, including {{c4::jury selection}}. 3. When a jury is required – serious offense: - A jury trial is required for a {{c5::serious offense}}. - A serious offense is one for which the potential term of imprisonment {{c6::exceeds 6 months}}.
cards.easyContent: The Sixth Amendment gives a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions, but only for serious offenses—those with possible imprisonment over six months—and the defendant has a right to be present at all critical stages, including jury selection.
cards.mediumContent: The Sixth Amendment guarantees a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions. The defendant has a right to be present at all critical stages of the proceeding, such as jury selection. A jury trial is required only for serious offenses, defined as those for which the potential punishment exceeds six months’ imprisonment.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment provides a right to a jury trial in criminal prosecutions. As part of this right, the defendant is entitled to be present at all critical stages of the criminal process, including jury selection. However, the Constitution requires a jury only for a serious offense—an offense for which the authorized potential term of imprisonment exceeds six months. Petty offenses not meeting this threshold do not trigger a constitutional jury-trial right.
cards.mnemonic: Serious means 6+: Sixth Amendment, over 6 months, and presence at all critical stages.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} guarantees a {{c2::jury trial in criminal prosecutions}} only for {{c3::serious offenses}}—those with {{c4::possible imprisonment over six months}}—and a right to be {{c5::present at all critical stages, including jury selection}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Jury Requirements – Size, Unanimity, and Representative Cross-Section
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 030-2. Jury Requirements – Size, Unanimity, and Representative Cross-Section
cards.front: Jury Requirements – Size, Unanimity, and Representative Cross-Section
cards.frontPrompt: For criminal jury trials, what are the constitutional requirements for jury size, unanimity, and the composition of the jury pool?
cards.backPlain: 1. Jury size: - The jury must contain at least 6 jurors. 2. Unanimity: - For serious offenses, the jury’s verdict must be unanimous. 3. Representative cross-section requirement: - The jury pool (venire) must be a representative cross-section of the community. - The actually chosen, seated jury does not have to be representative of the community, as long as the pool from which it was drawn is representative.
cards.cloze: 1. Jury size: - The jury must contain at least {{c1::6 jurors}}. 2. Unanimity: - For {{c2::serious offenses}}, the jury’s verdict must be {{c3::unanimous}}. 3. Representative cross-section requirement: - The {{c4::jury pool (venire)}} must be a {{c5::representative cross-section of the community}}. - The actually chosen, seated jury {{c6::does not have to be representative}} as long as the pool is representative.
cards.easyContent: Criminal juries must have at least six jurors, must return unanimous verdicts for serious offenses, and must be drawn from a jury pool that is a fair cross-section of the community (even though the final seated jury need not be).
cards.mediumContent: In criminal cases, the jury must have at least six jurors. For serious offenses, the verdict must be unanimous. The jury pool, or venire, must be a representative cross-section of the community, but the particular jurors who end up being seated on the panel need not themselves mirror the community’s composition.
cards.hardContent: The Constitution requires that criminal juries have at least six members. For serious offenses—those with potential imprisonment exceeding six months—the jury’s verdict must be unanimous. Additionally, the jury pool (venire) must be drawn from a representative cross-section of the community, meaning that systematic exclusion of distinctive groups from the pool is forbidden. However, there is no requirement that the particular jurors selected for service on the defendant’s jury themselves reflect that cross-section, so long as the underlying pool is representative.
cards.mnemonic: 3 SIXES: 6 jurors, 6+ months unanimous, 6th needs fair pool.
cards.clozeLite: Criminal juries must have {{c1::at least six jurors}}, {{c2::unanimous verdicts for serious offenses}}, and a {{c3::jury pool that is a fair cross-section of the community}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Voir Dire – Impartial Jury, For-Cause Strikes, and Peremptory Challenges
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 030-3. Voir Dire – Impartial Jury, For-Cause Strikes, and Peremptory Challenges
cards.front: Voir Dire – Impartial Jury, For-Cause Strikes, and Peremptory Challenges
cards.frontPrompt: What rights does a defendant have during voir dire to secure an impartial jury, when can jurors be struck for cause, and what are the limits on peremptory challenges?
cards.backPlain: 1. Right to an impartial jury: - The defendant has a right to an impartial jury. - The defendant may question potential jurors (voir dire) about possible prejudices relevant to the case, such as racial bias or views about the death penalty. 2. For-cause strikes: - Jurors can be struck for cause if their views would prevent or substantially impair them from performing their duties as jurors. 3. Peremptory challenges – general rule: - The parties may generally exercise peremptory challenges for any reason, without having to state a cause. 4. Equal-protection limits on peremptories: - Peremptory challenges may not be used to exclude jurors on account of race or gender. - Using peremptories to remove jurors because of race or gender violates the Equal Protection Clause (Batson-type challenge).
cards.cloze: 1. Right to an impartial jury: - The defendant has a right to an {{c1::impartial jury}}. - The defendant may question potential jurors during {{c2::voir dire}} about possible prejudices relevant to the case, such as {{c3::racial bias}} or {{c4::views about the death penalty}}. 2. For-cause strikes: - Jurors can be {{c5::struck for cause}} if their views would {{c6::prevent or substantially impair}} them from performing their duties. 3. Peremptory challenges – general rule: - The parties may generally exercise {{c7::peremptory challenges}} for any reason, without stating a cause. 4. Equal-protection limits on peremptories: - Peremptory challenges may not be used to exclude jurors on account of {{c8::race}} or {{c9::gender}}. - Such use of peremptories violates the {{c10::Equal Protection Clause}} (a {{c11::Batson}} violation).
cards.easyContent: A defendant is entitled to an impartial jury and can question jurors about bias during voir dire. Jurors whose views would prevent or substantially impair their duties can be struck for cause. Parties can use peremptory challenges for almost any reason, but not to exclude jurors based on race or gender, which violates equal protection (Batson).
cards.mediumContent: The defendant has a right to an impartial jury and may conduct voir dire to question potential jurors about relevant prejudices, such as racial bias or attitudes toward the death penalty. Jurors whose views would prevent or substantially impair their ability to serve fairly may be removed for cause. In addition, parties may exercise peremptory challenges without giving a reason, but they may not use them to strike jurors because of race or gender; doing so violates the Equal Protection Clause and can be challenged under Batson.
cards.hardContent: To secure the Sixth Amendment right to an impartial jury, the defendant is permitted to question prospective jurors during voir dire about potential biases that are relevant to the issues in the case, such as racial prejudice or views about capital punishment. Jurors may be removed for cause where their views would prevent or substantially impair the performance of their duties as jurors, such as following the law and considering the evidence fairly. Beyond for-cause challenges, parties have a limited number of peremptory challenges that can be exercised for virtually any reason and without explanation. However, peremptory challenges are constrained by equal protection: they may not be used to exclude jurors solely on account of race or gender. A pattern or explanation suggesting such discriminatory use of peremptories can give rise to a Batson challenge under the Equal Protection Clause.
cards.mnemonic: IMPARTIAL JURY: Ask Bias, Axe Bias; Batson Bars Biased Peremptories.
cards.clozeLite: Defendant may {{c1::question jurors in voir dire}} about bias; biased jurors are {{c2::struck for cause}}. {{c3::Peremptories}} need no reason but {{c4::can’t be race or gender-based (Batson)}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Judge-Directed Verdicts in Criminal Jury Trials
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 030-4. Judge-Directed Verdicts in Criminal Jury Trials
cards.front: Judge-Directed Verdicts in Criminal Jury Trials
cards.frontPrompt: In a criminal jury trial, when may a judge direct a verdict, and why is there a constitutional limit on directing a guilty verdict?
cards.backPlain: 1. No judge-directed guilty verdict: - A judge cannot direct a verdict of guilt in a criminal jury trial. - Directing a guilty verdict would deprive the defendant of the constitutional right to have a jury determine guilt. 2. Judge-directed acquittal allowed: - A judge may direct a verdict of acquittal (e.g., by granting a motion for judgment of acquittal) when the evidence is legally insufficient to support a conviction.
cards.cloze: 1. No judge-directed guilty verdict: - A judge {{c1::cannot direct a verdict of guilt}} in a criminal jury trial. - Directing a guilty verdict would deprive the defendant of the {{c2::constitutional right to a jury determination of guilt}}. 2. Judge-directed acquittal allowed: - A judge {{c3::may direct a verdict of acquittal}} (e.g., via a motion for judgment of acquittal) when the evidence is {{c4::legally insufficient}} to support a conviction.
cards.easyContent: In a criminal jury trial, a judge can never direct a verdict of guilt because the jury must decide guilt, but the judge may direct a verdict of acquittal if the evidence is insufficient.
cards.mediumContent: A criminal defendant has a constitutional right to have guilt determined by a jury, so the judge may not direct a verdict of guilt. However, if the prosecution’s evidence is legally insufficient, the judge may direct a verdict of acquittal (often through a motion for judgment of acquittal).
cards.hardContent: Because the Sixth Amendment guarantees a jury trial in criminal prosecutions, the judge may not override the jury’s role by directing a verdict of guilt; doing so would deny the defendant the right to have guilt determined by the jury. By contrast, the judge may direct a verdict of acquittal—such as by granting a motion for judgment of acquittal—when, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, no rational juror could find guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
cards.mnemonic: Judge can clear but not convict: acquittal yes, guilt no.
cards.clozeLite: In a criminal jury trial, a {{c1::judge may not direct a verdict of guilt}}, but may {{c2::direct a verdict of acquittal}} if {{c3::evidence is legally insufficient}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Right to Confront Witnesses – Confrontation and In-Person Testimony
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 031-1. Right to Confront Witnesses – Confrontation and In-Person Testimony
cards.front: Confrontation Clause – In-Person Testimony & Courtroom Control
cards.backPlain: 1. General confrontation right: 1.1 The Sixth Amendment gives the defendant the right to confront adverse witnesses. 2. In-person testimony and cross-examination: 2.1 The defendant has a right to have adverse witnesses testify in person and be subject to cross-examination. 3. When in-person confrontation is not required: 3.1 In-person testimony is not required if BOTH are satisfied: 3.1.1 Exclusion of in-person testimony is necessary to further an important public policy; and 3.1.2 The reliability of the testimony is otherwise assured (e.g., certain procedures in child-abuse cases). 4. Courtroom control: 4.1 The defendant can be removed from the courtroom for disruptive behavior without violating the confrontation right, so long as the court provides reasonable alternatives (e.g., allowing the defendant to observe remotely) consistent with due process.
cards.frontPrompt: Under the Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause, what is the general right regarding in-person testimony, and when can in-person confrontation be dispensed with or the defendant removed from the courtroom?
cards.cloze: 1. General confrontation right: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} gives the defendant the right to {{c2::confront adverse witnesses}}. 2. In-person testimony and cross-examination: 2.1 The defendant has a right to have adverse witnesses {{c3::testify in person}} and be subject to {{c4::cross-examination}}. 3. When in-person confrontation is not required: 3.1 In-person testimony is not required if BOTH are satisfied: 3.1.1 Exclusion of in-person testimony is necessary to further an {{c5::important public policy}}; and 3.1.2 The {{c6::reliability of the testimony}} is otherwise assured. 4. Courtroom control: 4.1 The defendant can be {{c7::removed from the courtroom}} for {{c8::disruptive behavior}} without violating the confrontation right, so long as reasonable alternatives consistent with {{c9::due process}} are provided.
cards.easyContent: The Confrontation Clause generally requires adverse witnesses to testify in person and be subject to cross-examination. In-person confrontation can be dispensed with if necessary to further an important public policy and the testimony is otherwise reliable, and a disruptive defendant may be removed from the courtroom.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Sixth Amendment, a criminal defendant has the right to confront adverse witnesses, which ordinarily means those witnesses must appear in court and be subject to cross-examination. In-person testimony can be replaced by alternative procedures only if doing so is necessary to further an important public policy and the reliability of the testimony is otherwise assured, such as special arrangements in child-abuse cases. A defendant who is disruptive may be removed from the courtroom, and this does not violate the confrontation right if reasonable steps are taken to preserve fairness and due process.
cards.hardContent: The Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause grants a defendant the right to confront adverse witnesses. This typically requires live, in-court testimony and the opportunity to cross-examine those witnesses. However, in-person confrontation is not absolute. The Supreme Court has allowed departures from face-to-face testimony when (1) the exclusion of in-person testimony is necessary to further an important public policy, and (2) the reliability of the testimony is otherwise assured, as in some child-abuse prosecutions where the child victim testifies via closed-circuit television. Additionally, a defendant who engages in seriously disruptive behavior may be removed from the courtroom without violating the confrontation right, provided that the court uses reasonable measures to maintain the integrity and fairness of the proceedings.
cards.mnemonic: FACE: Face-to-face, Abuse policy, Cross-exam, Eject disruptor
cards.clozeLite: Confrontation usually requires {{c1::in-person, live testimony}} and {{c2::cross-examination}}; face-to-face can be waived for {{c3::important public policy with reliable testimony}} or a {{c4::disruptive defendant removed from court}}.

cards.subject: Criminal Procedure
cards.topic: Right to Confront Witnesses – Bruton Rule on Co-Defendant Confessions
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 031-2. Right to Confront Witnesses – Bruton Rule on Co-Defendant Confessions
cards.front: Confrontation Clause – Bruton Rule & Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 1. Bruton rule – basic principle: 1.1 In a joint jury trial, a co-defendant’s confession that directly implicates the defendant is inadmissible against the defendant, because the defendant cannot effectively confront and cross-examine the confessing co-defendant regarding that statement. 1.2 The same confession may be considered in a bench trial (no jury), because the judge is presumed able to consider it only for the proper party. 2. Exceptions: when a co-defendant’s confession may be admitted: 2.1 The confessing co-defendant testifies at trial and is subject to cross-examination. 2.2 The defendants are tried separately (severance of trials) so the confession is not presented against a non-confessing co-defendant. 2.3 The confession is properly redacted so that all portions referring to the co-defendant are eliminated and it does not obviously point to the other defendant. 2.4 The co-defendant’s confession is used only to rebut the defendant’s claim that the defendant’s own confession was obtained coercively, and is not used as direct evidence of the defendant’s guilt.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the Bruton rule regarding co-defendant confessions at a joint jury trial, and what are the main exceptions that allow such confessions to be admitted?
cards.cloze: 1. Bruton rule – basic principle: 1.1 In a {{c1::joint jury trial}}, a {{c2::co-defendant’s confession}} that directly implicates the defendant is {{c3::inadmissible against the defendant}}, because the defendant cannot effectively confront and cross-examine the confessing co-defendant regarding that statement. 1.2 The same confession may be considered in a {{c4::bench trial}}, because the judge is presumed able to consider it only for the proper party. 2. Exceptions: when a co-defendant’s confession may be admitted: 2.1 The confessing co-defendant {{c5::testifies at trial}} and is subject to {{c6::cross-examination}}. 2.2 The defendants are {{c7::tried separately}} ({{c8::severance of trials}}). 2.3 The confession is properly {{c9::redacted}} so that all portions referring to the co-defendant are eliminated and it does not obviously point to the other defendant. 2.4 The co-defendant’s confession is used only to {{c10::rebut the defendant’s claim}} that the defendant’s {{c11::own confession was obtained coercively}}, and is not used as direct evidence of the defendant’s guilt.
cards.easyContent: Under the Bruton rule, at a joint jury trial a co-defendant’s confession that implicates the defendant is inadmissible against the defendant. It can come in if the co-defendant testifies and is cross-examined, the trials are severed, the confession is effectively redacted, or it is used only to rebut a claim that the defendant’s own confession was coerced.
cards.mediumContent: The Bruton rule limits the use, at a joint jury trial, of a co-defendant’s confession that incriminates another defendant, because the non-confessing defendant cannot effectively confront the out-of-court accusatory statement. Such a confession is generally inadmissible against the other defendant when offered before a jury, though it may be considered by a judge at a bench trial. The confrontation problem is cured if the confessing co-defendant testifies and is subject to cross-examination; if the defendants are tried separately so the confession is presented only against the confessor; if the confession is redacted to eliminate all references that would reasonably identify the co-defendant; or if the confession is used solely to rebut the defendant’s claim that his own confession was coerced.
cards.hardContent: The Bruton doctrine implements the Confrontation Clause in the context of joint jury trials. A co-defendant’s confession that facially or directly implicates another defendant is generally inadmissible against that defendant at a joint jury trial because the confessing co-defendant is not on the stand for cross-examination and the jury cannot realistically follow a limiting instruction to consider the confession only against the speaker. However, if the trial is conducted before a judge (a bench trial), the judge is presumed to consider the confession only against the confessor, so Bruton does not bar its use. The confrontation problem is resolved, and the confession may be admitted, if: (1) the confessing co-defendant takes the stand and is subject to cross-examination; (2) the trials are severed so that the confession is not placed before a jury evaluating a non-confessing co-defendant; (3) the confession is effectively redacted so that it no longer identifies or obviously points to the other defendant; or (4) the confession is admitted solely to rebut the defendant’s argument that his own confession was coerced, not as direct proof of his guilt.
cards.mnemonic: Bruton is brutal to joint trials: no naming co-defendants without cross, sever, redact, or rebut.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::Bruton}}, at a {{c2::joint jury trial}} a co-defendant’s {{c3::confession implicating the defendant}} is inadmissible unless {{c4::co-defendant testifies or trials severed}} or {{c5::confession is effectively redacted}}.

cards.topic: Right to Confront Witnesses – Testimonial Hearsay and Prior Cross-Examination
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 031-3. Right to Confront Witnesses – Testimonial Hearsay and Prior Cross-Examination
cards.front: Confrontation Clause – Testimonial Hearsay & Prior Opportunity for Cross
cards.backPlain: 1. Testimonial hearsay and the Confrontation Clause: 1.1 The Sixth Amendment restricts the admission of prior testimonial statements by witnesses who do not testify at trial. 2. Unavailable declarant and prior opportunity to cross-examine: 2.1 Prior testimonial statements of an unavailable witness are admissible against the defendant only if: 2.1.1 The witness is unavailable; and 2.1.2 The defendant had a prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant when the statement was made (e.g., at a prior hearing or deposition). 3. Relationship to hearsay law: 3.1 Even if a statement fits a hearsay exception, it cannot be admitted against a criminal defendant if it is testimonial, the declarant is unavailable, and the defendant lacked a prior opportunity to cross-examine. 3.2 The Confrontation Clause is an independent constitutional limit on testimonial hearsay in criminal cases.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the Confrontation Clause limit the use of prior testimonial statements of an unavailable witness, and what role does a prior opportunity for cross-examination play?
cards.cloze: 1. Testimonial hearsay and the Confrontation Clause: 1.1 The {{c1::Sixth Amendment}} restricts the admission of prior {{c2::testimonial statements}} by witnesses who do not testify at trial. 2. Unavailable declarant and prior opportunity to cross-examine: 2.1 Prior testimonial statements of an {{c3::unavailable}} witness are admissible against the defendant only if: 2.1.1 The witness is unavailable; and 2.1.2 The defendant had a prior opportunity to {{c4::cross-examine}} the declarant when the statement was made (e.g., at a prior hearing or deposition). 3. Relationship to hearsay law: 3.1 Even if a statement fits a {{c5::hearsay exception}}, it cannot be admitted against a criminal defendant if it is {{c6::testimonial}}, the declarant is {{c7::unavailable}}, and the defendant lacked a prior opportunity to {{c8::cross-examine}}. 3.2 The Confrontation Clause is an independent {{c9::constitutional}} limit on {{c10::testimonial hearsay}} in criminal cases.
cards.easyContent: Prior testimonial statements of an unavailable witness can be used against a criminal defendant only if the defendant previously had a chance to cross-examine that witness. Even if the statement fits a hearsay exception, it is barred if it is testimonial, the witness is unavailable, and there was no prior opportunity for cross.
cards.mediumContent: The Confrontation Clause restricts the use of prior testimonial statements when the declarant does not testify at trial. Such statements are admissible against a criminal defendant only if the declarant is unavailable and the defendant had an earlier opportunity to cross-examine the witness, such as at a prior hearing or deposition. If those conditions are not met, testimonial hearsay is excluded, even if it would otherwise qualify under an evidentiary hearsay exception. Thus, the Confrontation Clause imposes an independent constitutional limit on testimonial hearsay.
cards.hardContent: Under the Sixth Amendment Confrontation Clause, the admission of testimonial hearsay from a non-testifying witness is tightly limited. When a declarant is unavailable at trial, the prosecution may introduce that declarant’s prior testimonial statements against the defendant only if the defendant had a previous opportunity to cross-examine the declarant, such as at a preliminary hearing, prior trial, or deposition. This constitutional requirement applies on top of the rules of evidence. Even if a statement falls within a recognized hearsay exception, it is still inadmissible against the defendant if it is testimonial in nature, the declarant is unavailable, and the defendant never had a chance to cross-examine the declarant. The Confrontation Clause thus operates as an independent bar to certain uses of testimonial hearsay in criminal prosecutions.
cards.mnemonic: TUC: Testimonial, Unavailable, prior Cross-exam required.
cards.clozeLite: Prior {{c1::testimonial}} statements of an {{c2::unavailable witness}} are admissible only if the defendant had a prior {{c3::opportunity to cross-examine}}.

cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 032-1. Eighth Amendment – General Rule and Disproportionality
cards.front: Eighth Amendment – General Rule and Disproportionality
cards.frontPrompt: What does the Eighth Amendment prohibit, and how does disproportionality limit criminal punishment, including for juveniles?
cards.backPlain: 1. General Eighth Amendment rule: 1.1 The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment. 1.2 This includes a prohibition on punishments that are grossly disproportionate to the offense. 2. Disproportionality examples and juvenile sentencing: 2.1 A punishment can be grossly disproportionate, for example, a life sentence for minor vandalism. 2.2 Life without parole is not permissible for juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes.
cards.cloze: 1. General Eighth Amendment rule: 1.1 The {{c1::Eighth Amendment}} prohibits {{c2::cruel and unusual punishment}}. 1.2 This includes a prohibition on punishments that are {{c3::grossly disproportionate to the offense}}. 2. Disproportionality and juveniles: 2.1 An example of gross disproportionality is a {{c4::life sentence for minor vandalism}}. 2.2 {{c5::Life without parole}} is not permissible for {{c6::juveniles convicted of non-homicide crimes}}.
cards.easyContent: The Eighth Amendment bans cruel and unusual punishment, including punishments that are grossly disproportionate to the crime. Life without parole is unconstitutional for juveniles convicted of non-homicide offenses.
cards.mediumContent: The Eighth Amendment prohibits cruel and unusual punishment, which includes punishment that is grossly disproportionate to the offense. A life sentence for a minor crime, like minor vandalism, would be an example. The Court has also held that life without parole cannot be imposed on juveniles for non-homicide crimes.
cards.hardContent: The Eighth Amendment’s prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment incorporates a proportionality principle: punishments must not be grossly disproportionate to the gravity of the offense. For example, a life sentence for minor vandalism would violate this principle. In the juvenile context, the Supreme Court has held that life without the possibility of parole is impermissible for juveniles convicted of non-homicide offenses, reflecting the Eighth Amendment’s heightened concern with disproportionate punishment for less culpable offenders.

cards.topic: Death Penalty – Procedural and Statutory Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Criminal Procedure 032-2. Death Penalty – Procedural and Statutory Requirements
cards.front: Death Penalty – Procedural and Statutory Requirements
cards.frontPrompt: What Eighth Amendment–based procedural and statutory requirements must be satisfied before the death penalty can be imposed?
cards.backPlain: 2. Death penalty requirements under the Eighth Amendment: 2.1 The death penalty may only be imposed if the victim dies as a result of the defendant’s crime. 2.2 A statute authorizing the death penalty must not be unconstitutionally vague. 2.3 The sentencer (usually the jury) must be allowed to consider mitigating circumstances. 2.4 Mitigating circumstances include, for example, the defendant’s abusive childhood or mental impairment. 2.5 There must be at least one statutory aggravating circumstance (e.g., prior convictions) supporting the death sentence.
cards.cloze: 2. Death penalty requirements: 2.1 The death penalty may only be imposed if the {{c1::victim dies}} as a result of the defendant’s crime. 2.2 A statute authorizing the death penalty must not be {{c2::unconstitutionally vague}}. 2.3 The sentencer (usually the jury) must be allowed to consider {{c3::mitigating circumstances}}. 2.4 Examples of mitigation include the defendant’s {{c4::abusive childhood}} or {{c5::mental impairment}}. 2.5 There must be at least one {{c6::statutory aggravating circumstance}} (e.g., prior convictions) to support imposing death.
cards.easyContent: The death penalty is allowed only when the victim dies, the death statute is not vague, the jury can consider mitigation, and at least one statutory aggravating factor supports the sentence.
cards.mediumContent: For a death sentence to comply with the Eighth Amendment, the offense must result in the victim’s death, the governing statute cannot be unconstitutionally vague, and the sentencer must be able to consider any mitigating circumstances, such as an abusive childhood or mental impairment. In addition, there must be at least one statutory aggravating circumstance—like prior serious convictions—to justify imposing death.
cards.hardContent: The Eighth Amendment’s regulation of capital punishment imposes specific procedural and statutory requirements. First, the death penalty is generally reserved for crimes where the victim dies as a result of the defendant’s conduct. Second, statutes authorizing capital punishment must provide clear, non-vague standards to guide sentencing discretion. Third, the sentencer, typically a jury, must be permitted to consider and give effect to any relevant mitigating evidence about the defendant or the offense, such as an abusive upbringing or mental impairment. Finally, the capital statute must require at least one statutory aggravating circumstance, such as prior violent convictions or especially heinous circumstances of the crime, to narrow the class of those eligible for the death penalty.
cards.mnemonic: For death: D-V-M-A – Death, non-Vague law, Mitigation, Aggravator.
cards.clozeLite: Death sentence requires {{c1::victim’s death}}, a {{c2::non-vague capital statute}}, {{c3::consideration of mitigating evidence}}, and {{c4::at least one statutory aggravator}}.

cards.front: Death Penalty – Categorical Exclusions and Felony-Murder Limits
cards.frontPrompt: Which categories of defendants and felony-murder situations are barred from receiving the death penalty under the Eighth Amendment?
cards.backPlain: 3. Limitations on imposing the death penalty under the Eighth Amendment: 3.1 The death penalty cannot be imposed if the defendant was under 18 years old when the crime was committed. 3.2 The death penalty cannot be imposed if the defendant is mentally disabled. 3.3 The death penalty cannot be imposed if the defendant is insane at the time of execution. 3.4 The death penalty cannot be imposed for felony murder if either: 3.4.1 The defendant was not a major participant in the underlying felony, or 3.4.2 The defendant did not act with depraved indifference to human life.
cards.cloze: 3. Categorical exclusions and felony-murder limits: 3.1 The death penalty cannot be imposed if the defendant was {{c1::under 18 years old}} at the time of the offense. 3.2 It cannot be imposed if the defendant is {{c2::mentally disabled}}. 3.3 It cannot be imposed if the defendant is {{c3::insane at the time of execution}}. 3.4 In {{c4::felony murder}} cases, the death penalty is barred if either: 3.4.1 The defendant was not a {{c5::major participant}} in the underlying felony, or 3.4.2 The defendant did not act with {{c6::depraved indifference to human life}}.
cards.easyContent: The death penalty cannot be imposed on defendants who were under 18 at the time of the crime, are mentally disabled, or are insane at execution, and it is limited in felony-murder cases to major participants who acted with depraved indifference to human life.
cards.mediumContent: Under the Eighth Amendment, the death penalty is categorically barred for three groups: offenders who were under 18 when the crime was committed, mentally disabled offenders, and offenders who are insane at the time of execution. In felony-murder cases, even when a death occurs, a defendant is ineligible for the death penalty if he was not a major participant in the underlying felony or did not act with depraved indifference to human life.
cards.hardContent: The Eighth Amendment imposes categorical restrictions on capital punishment based on the offender’s characteristics and degree of culpability. The Supreme Court has held that the death penalty may not be imposed on offenders who were under 18 years old at the time of the crime, on mentally disabled offenders, or on offenders who are insane at the time of execution. These categories reflect judgments that such defendants have diminished culpability or that executing them would be inconsistent with contemporary standards of decency. Additionally, in felony-murder cases, the Eighth Amendment forbids imposing the death penalty on defendants who were not major participants in the underlying felony or who did not act with depraved indifference to human life, thereby limiting death eligibility to the most culpable felony-murder participants.
